description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: German Unrest Expected to Bring Tightening of Law on Immigration
description: Political shock waves from Rostock, where racist demonstrators besieged and burned a hostel housing foreign asylum-seekers last week, have jolted German politicians into actions that may transform the country's political landscape.

title: A G.E. JOINT VENTURE GETS $400 MILLION JET ENGINE ORDER
description: CFM International, a venture of the General Electric Company and Snecma of France, said yesterday that it had received a $400 million aircraft engine order from Gulf Air. Gulf Air selected CFM's CFM56-5C engines to power six Airbus Industrie A340 aircraft it ordered and another six A340's it has an option to buy, CFM said. Airbus, a European consortium, announced the order and options earlier but did not place a value on the transaction. Gulf Air is a venture of four Middle Eastern countries: Oman, Qatar, Bahrain and Abu Dhabi.

title: We Can Turn Monster Schools Into Mini-Schools Right Now; Why Teachers Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: New Challenge For Civic Leader
description: In taking up the task of leading the private-sector effort to rebuild South Florida after the hurricane, Alvah H. Chapman Jr. is stepping into a role that he has shouldered on other occasions for his adopted state of Florida.

title: Camps for Car Thieves Win Endorsement
description: Several community advocates met today with state officials to try to enlist support for new social programs aimed at young people who now make a hobby of stealing cars.

title: Jets Pull Off a Reverse: Pickel In, Malamala Out
description: Although it was the players' first official day off of the 1992 regular season, the Jets' front office tried to stay busy behind the scenes yesterday, pulling some strings and tying some loose ends for Sunday's opener against the Atlanta Falcons in the new Georgia Dome.

title: Becker Is Making His Points on a Mellower Note
description: Seven years later, Kevin Curren looks across the net at his former teen-age nemesis, Boris Becker, and mostly sees signs of adulthood in the makings of a reddish beard, the attempted containment of a rebellious temper, the abandonment of the need to dive across a hard-court surface for a single point in a tennis game.

title: Syria Said to Pledge in Writing to a 'Peace Settlement' With Israel
description: Syria has presented Israel with a document in which Damascus, for the first time, committed itself in writing to reach a "peace settlement" with Israel and acknowledged that Israel had "security concerns" that could be addressed, Israeli officials said today.

title: Teachers in 3 States Strike, Signaling Wider Unrest
description: Teachers in three states have gone on strike in work stoppages that could spread to three other states. And union leaders and education analysts say the bitter mood among teachers goes beyond wage and compensation issues.

title: New Test Can Find Cystic Fibrosis Gene Without Blood Samples
description: The first noninvasive test to diagnose cystic fibrosis, or detect the presence of the gene that causes the disease in people who might pass it on to their children, is to be available soon.

title: High Lead Levels Found Near 3 East River Bridges
description: Soil near the Brooklyn, Manhattan and Williamsburg bridges shows high concentrations of lead, the City Health Department reported yesterday, including levels that exceed Federal safety recommendations.

title: Ramsay-HMO Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included the effect of a $ 512,205 payment, or 5 cents a share, made to the Health Care Financing Administration in the third quarter for the over payment of Medicare premiums from April 1, 1985 to Oct. 31, 1987.c-After an extraordinary charge of $ 207,434 for both the quarter and year which reflects write off of deferred loan costs associated with early repayment of bank debt less applicable taxes.

title: General Mills Plans to Buy Nabisco's Lineup of Cereals
description: General Mills, maker of the breakfast of champions and the aspiring champion of breakfasts, announced yesterday that it planned to add RJR Nabisco's ready-to-eat cereal business to its lineup.

title: Questions Arise as Tents Go Up in Stricken City
description: Flanked by broken buildings and downed trees, a village of olive-drab tents that is to shelter 1,500 hurricane victims has risen on a field across from City Hall.

title: No Headline
description: "When it comes to right-wing extremists, the world is watching Germany closely because of its past. Hostility and hatred of foreigners is the last thing we can afford." -- FOREIGN MINISTER KLAUS KINKEL. [ A8:2. ]

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY SILENCE AFTER A SHOOTING?

title: Off-Duty Officers Failed To Step Forward in Killing
description: Six to 10 off-duty police officers were socializing in a strip of Queens bars when an off-duty Housing Authority police officer was shot to death on the street in July but did not come forward to volunteer information about the incident, as they are required to do by departmental regulations, New York City's acting Police Commissioner said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Traffic Alert
description: A water main break on South Street near Broad Street in Manhattan yesterday forced the closing of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. These parts of the drive will be affected for two weeks for repairs:

title: The Pop Life; Seizing A Chance To Make Changes
description: Garth Brooks is the record industry's equivalent of a 900-pound gorilla, in a position to do whatever he wants whenever he wants to do it. Mr. Brooks, the country singer who is easily America's most popular musician, has sold 21 million records in four years. He's had at least one album in Billboard's top 10 for months. His next concert, to be on Saturday night at the Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., is sold out, as his shows usually are. (They usually sell out within a few hours.)

title: 23 States Face Suits on School Funds
description: As schools reopen this week from the summer break, many begin the new year under a cloud: Increasing numbers of states face lawsuits over their failure to close spending gaps between rich and poor school districts or their failure to give adequate aid to all schools.

title: Dartmouth Redesigns Medical Training To Give Future Doctors a Human Touch
description: Nervous students in surgical gloves and aprons filed into a flourescent-lighted laboratory here and lined up alongside steel tables where cadavers lay ready for dissection.

title: We Can Turn Monster Schools Into Mini-Schools Right Now
description: To the Editor:

title: As Serbs See War: Foreign Plots and Ingratitude
description: Isolated and embittered, the people of Serbia seem gripped by a kind of national psychosis fed by the Balkans' grim history and by visions of intricate international plots to humiliate them.

title: No Pressure? No Problem. New Tires Run Flat.
description: For years, tire companies have sought to produce a passenger-car tire that would continue to run even after deflating. But the race among the world's giant tire producers recently grew more intense when both the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan announced the separate development of what they call run-flat tires.

title: Oshawa Group reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 8
description: b-Included $ 13 million in restructuring and strike costs for both the quarter and 6 months.Results are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: A Child Wants to Cook? Lead the Way if You Can, and Quickly
description: Cooking teachers will tell you children love to cook: all that stirring and mixing and beating and most of all, the cutting. A knife! Power!

title: Marie Paxton Is Dead; Actress on Broadway
description: Marie Paxton, an actress who appeared in many Broadway plays, died on Aug. 16 at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center after a brief illness. She lived in New York City.

title: Outside Lawyer Appointed General Counsel at Salomon
description: Salomon Inc., filling its last significant management post in the aftermath of the Treasury market scandal, announced yesterday that it had selected a lawyer from outside the securities industry to serve as general counsel.

title: Bobby Fischer Ends Silence With Rancor
description: Brooding and bitter, the American chess genius Bobby Fischer emerged today from two decades as a recluse to dismiss the world's leading chess players as "the lowest dogs around" and to spit, almost literally, in the face of the United States Government.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: AMERIANA BANCORP, New Castle, Ind., completed the acquisition of Deer Park Financial Corp. ARVIN INDUSTRIES , Columbus, Ind., and Houston Space Industries International signed a letter of intent to combine their research, aeronautics and industrial space operations.

title: Transactions
description: Football National Football League

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9 GERMANY RETHINKS ASYLUM POLICY

title: 2-Year-Olds and Up Had a Fine Summer
description: If you saw a herd of horses, trainers, riders and grooms driving south along the New York Thruway yesterday, you saw the annual migration from Saratoga Springs back to New York City, where the season will be resumed this afternoon at Belmont Park after five weeks in stately splendor and commercial success under the shade trees upstate. For the next seven weeks, New York will offer you nine races a day six days a week, with 28 stakes and nearly $6 million in purses.

title: China Arrests a Student Leader Back From Exile in the U.S.
description: The police today detained a prominent Chinese student leader who had returned from exile in the United States and was preparing to meet with foreign reporters to discuss his plans for setting up a chapter in China of the pro-democracy organization he heads.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * City of Ashland, Ky., is offering $30 million of tax-exempt pollution control refunding revenue bonds for an Ashland Oil Inc. project through Goldman, Sachs & Company. The bonds due in in 2009 are priced at par to yield 6.70 percent and rated Baa-1 by Moody's.

title: How to Help the Victims of the Hurricane
description: Following is a list of organizations seeking donations for the hurricane relief effort:

title: Dan Maloney to Join Rangers?
description: The Rangers aren't making any announcement yet, but it is expected that they will soon hire DAN MALONEY as an assistant coach. Maloney, formerly the head coach of Winnipeg and Toronto, would replace WAYNE CASHMAN, who left ROGER NEILSON's New York staff for a similar position with the expansion Tampa Bay Lightning. Maloney is no relation to DON MALONEY, the general manager of the Islanders. In an 11-year playing career with four teams, Dan Maloney had 451 points and 1,489 penalty minutes. He coached in Winnipeg from 1986-87 through part of the 1988-89 season. Before that, he coached the Maple Leafs in 1984-85 and 1985-86.

title: Krelitz Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $ 49,000, or 1 cent a share, and $ 66,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.Krelitz Industries Inc. attributed the fiscal 1992 net loss primarily to increased selling, general and administrative expenses. It said these expenses included internal nonrecurring computer systems costs of about $ 1 million that were determined not to have a continuing benefit to the company.

title: What's Next? Emotion Runs High
description: Chess players differ widely over the likely impact of the exhibition match between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky beginning today in Sveti Stevan, Yugoslavia. Will it turn out to be just a singular event that leaves scarcely a blip on the history of the game? Or will it have important repercussions for the future?

title: University and a College in Miami Put Off Openings Until Sept. 14
description: The havoc created by Hurricane Andrew has delayed the start of classes at the University of Miami and Miami-Dade Community College more than two weeks, until Sept. 14.

title: Dr. Irving Philips, 70, a Leader in Child Psychiatry
description: Dr. Irving Philips, an educator in child psychiatry and president of the International Association for Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, died on Saturday at his home in San Francisco. He was 70 years old.

title: Electronic Arts
description: Electronic Arts, the entertainment software manufacturer in San Mateo, Calif., said yesterday that it had awarded its $8 million sports video game account, previously handled in-house, to Goldberg Moser O'Neill in San Francisco. The two other finalists in the two-month review were Foote, Cone & Belding in San Francisco and Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore.

title: ITT Canada reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $ 5.5 million in charges relating to a plant closing and an adjustment in life insurance benefits.c-Net incomeResults are in Canadian dollars.The company is a unit of ITT Corp.

title: Laurentian Bank reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New Delhi Journal; Gandhi Epic Still Unfolds: Now, a Widow's Wrath
description: Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born widow of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, has swept aside the enigmatic veil and stoic silence with which she has long guarded her private life with a bittersweet account of life at the heart of one of the world's most influential political dynasties.

title: Yanks Start Showing An Interest in Cone
description: David Cone pitching in the Bronx? Several miles from Shea Stadium? The former heart and soul of the Mets pitching for the hated Yankees? It could happen.

title: GO TO ANNOUNCE SOFTWARE LINKS TO JAPANESE COMPANIES
description: The Go Corporation, Foster City, Calif., developer of the Penpoint operating system for pen-based computers, plans to announce today that six Japanese computer makers will adopt its system. The companies are: Canon, Fujitsu, Matsushita Electric Industrial, IBM Japan, OKI Electric and Toshiba. The companies have agreed that together with American software publishers, they will sell Japanese language applications for the Penpoint operating system.

title: Study Documents How Anger Can Impair Heart Function
description: The things that make your blood boil may be damaging your heart.

title: As Raider Controversy Swirls, Marinovich Is Tranquil
description: The gentle ocean breezes have a way of beckoning, especially in the late afternoons of a California summer. Sometimes, when the day is over and the freeways are full, they can be irresistible. Sometimes, when there is work to do, they must be ignored.

title: The Torturers of Lingyuan
description: In the early evening of April 22, 1991, a prison van left the Great North Prison in Shenyang, carrying 11 political prisoners who were convicted for their part in the pro-democracy movement. Among them were Liu Gang, a physicist, and Zhang Ming, an engineer -- Beijing student leaders on the most-wanted list -- and Tang Yuanjuan, also an engineer. They were sent to the Lingyuan No. 2 Labor Reform Detachment in Liaoning Province, known to the outside world as the Lingyuan Motor Vehicle General Assembly Plant. It makes Linghe tractors and trucks under the brand name Huanghe (Yellow River).

title: Big Crop of Small Apples Is Forecast This Season
description: The apple-harvesting season is moving into high gear in New York State, with predictions that the McIntosh crop will be larger than usual, though the apples themselves will be smaller than normal.

title: Michael A. Braun, 79, Lawyer in War Cases
description: Michael A. Braun, a prominent lawyer who defended accused war criminals during the American military's postwar occupation of Japan, died on Thursday in Tokyo. He was 79 years old and lived in Tokyo.

title: 5 Gunshots From an Officer Hit Hostage, Investigator Says
description: One police officer fired all five of the bullets found in the body of a hostage who was killed by the police in a shootout with gunmen in Queens last month, an investigator in the case said yesterday.

title: Navratilova Fights to Get the Last Laugh
description: Shaun Stafford never did figure out the true identity, champ or chump, of the apparition she faced on the stadium court last night at the United States Open.

title: Penn Traffic reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from early retirement of debt of $ 72,000 and $ 6,296,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.c-Net lossd-Included an extraordinary charge from early retirement of debt of $ 900,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 13,000,000.The company said last year's income from continuing operations included a $ 46.2 million after-tax charge taken in the third quarter of 1991.Corrected from Friday, August 28 editions.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Al Roker; Bright and Warm And Hold the Thunder
description: Al Roker is ignoring the weather. On a rare blue-sky day made for salad and sidewalk cafes, he is in his favorite steakhouse, ordering his usual: a 30-ounce prime rib, hold nothing.

title: Networks Intensify The Courtship Of David Letterman
description: David Letterman is the most wanted man in television. Though no decision can be made about his future television home, the intensity of the courtship of this NBC late-night star by other prospective suitors has increased in recent weeks and so has NBC's own interest in doing everything it can to keep Mr. Letterman from going elsewhere.

title: Citizens Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 601,018, or 4 cents a share, and $ 772,839, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Charles L. Weltner, 64, Chief Justice of Georgia
description: Chief Justice Charles L. Weltner of the Georgia Supreme Court, who as a young Congressman a quarter-century ago sacrificed a promising political career by defying his state's segregationist Democratic leadership, died Monday at his home in Atlanta. He was 64 years old.

title: Nissan's Rating Might Be Lowered
description: In a move that could lead to increased borrowing costs for the Nissan Motor Company, the Standard & Poor's Corporation has placed the company's debt rating on credit watch for possible downgrading.

title: Cabano Transportation reports earnings for Year to April 25
description: b-Included $ 2,769,000 of non-recurring income.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Negotiators Agree on Accord To Ban Chemical Weapons
description: Negotiators have completed a landmark agreement that would ban the production, use and stockpiling of chemical weapons and are preparing to submit it to the United Nations for endorsement, senior officials of the Bush Administration said today.

title: Giant Food Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
Hawkins Chemical Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

description: The toll on oil and gas operations in the Gulf climbed sharply, signaling higher natural gas prices. Page D1.

description: b-Net incomeResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: After Andrew, Another Unannounced Visitor: George Bush
description: When Ramon Rodriguez and Adela Antonini whistled at George Bush from the doorway of their windowless apartment, they never expected that the President would just drop by, unannounced.

title: Executive Changes
description: ACU-TRAC INC., Easton, Md., a coupon management and data base company, named Charles P. Jones executive vice president. AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP, New York, appointed Allan B. deSchweinitz senior vice president and director of fraud investigations in the cost containment division.

title: Edmund H. Kerr, 67, An Investment Lawyer
description: Edmund H. Kerr, a senior partner in the international law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, died yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 67 years old.

title: Corrections
description: A heading in an article on Aug. 23 about Geraldine A. Ferraro's financial affairs misstated her response to a 1987 subpoena from the Queens District Attorney's office. The subpoena, during a trial of her husband, John A. Zaccaro, demanded official papers from her years in Congress. As the article said, Ms. Ferraro and lawyers for the House of Representatives resisted the subpoena as unconstitutionally broad. It was later narrowed, and Ms. Ferraro complied with it. The trial ended in the acquittal of Mr. Zaccaro on a charge of seeking a bribe from a cable television company.

title: Morris Carnovsky Is Dead at 94; Acting Career Spanned 60 Years
description: Morris Carnovsky, a pipe-smoking character actor who endured the blacklist of the 1950's to triumph in Shakespeare, died yesterday at his home in Easton, Conn. He was 94 years old.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats; CLINTON SAYS BUSH IMPERILS ELDERLY
description: Opening a planned three-day attack on his Republican opponent, Gov. Bill Clinton spent the day among the elderly today, trying to put the fear of George Bush into them.

title: Will the Magic's Center Make a Trade Disappear?
description: The proposed three-way trade involving the Knicks, the Los Angeles Clippers and the Orlando Magic was still not completed yesterday. The question now is this: Will the trade happen this week, next week or next month, or will it ever happen at all?

title: Hunting for Scapegoats in South Florida
description: As Hurricane Andrew gave its final shriek and retreated into the Everglades last Monday, I knew we were really in trouble.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: News Analysis - Incumbency's Ace; Returning to Devastated Area, Bush Uses Powers of Office to Help Others, and Himself
description: With a few deft words, President Bush threw the full weight of incumbency behind Florida's hurricane victims today, and showed in the process why even Presidents who lag in the polls are electoral forces to be reckoned with.

title: Teen-Agers and 110 Pounds of Powerful Explosives
description: It was no terrorist attack in the making, the Suffolk County police said yesterday, though the consequences could have been terrible.

title: Intercan Leasing reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Antoinette M. Kraushaar, Art Dealer, Dies at 89
description: Antoinette M. Kraushaar, the owner of one of New York City's oldest art galleries, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89 years old.

title: Mr. Bush Inherits the Wind
description: Americans are, as President Bush said last night, a nation of neighbors, and they join in his heartfelt concern for the victims of Hurricane Andrew. Even so, no matter how much Federal aid he might now dispatch to South Florida, he cannot avoid responsibility for Washington's slow response.

title: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS IS TAKING A 4TH-QUARTER CHARGE
description: The Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation said yesterday that it would reduce pretax earnings by $5.5 million in the fourth quarter, which ended July 31, for the restructuring and consolidation of operations. The coffee, food service and beverage company said the charge would amount to about $3.6 million, or 36 cents a share, after taxes. The majority of the charge will be noncash, Chock Full o' Nuts said, but it did not elaborate.

title: Aryt Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net lossThe company did not report any sales in the year-ago quarter and 6 months periods.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the air embargo on Iraqi flights over southern Iraq misstated the Pentagon's rules for journalists accompanying American forces. They have agreed not to write about future operations, the rules of engagement or other classified information, but they are not required to show their articles to military officers before they are transmitted.

title: COMPANY NEWS: Dipping vs. Snacking; Can a Tortilla Chip Ever Be Too Thin?
description: In snack-food parlance, it is called "out-of-bag snackability." Today's tortilla chips, it would seem, don't have it. Too thick. Too plain. Too many munchers left hankering for a bowl of salsa after the first mouthful.

title: Food Industry Views the Thrifty Bean With New Admiration
description: Long a key part of most ethnic cuisines and increasingly gaining favor among the nation's chefs, beans are moving squarely into the mainstream of the American diet.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Congressional Race; Dueling Incumbents Revisit House Bank Scandal
description: The House bank scandal is being replayed in a fierce Congressional contest here between two incumbents who clashed in the partisan war that the scandal unleashed in Washington.

title: Critic's Notebook; Why It Took TV So Long To Focus on the Somalis
description: Scenes of catastrophe are so common on the television screen that the heartbreakers of a year or two ago are constantly being overwhelmed by last week's. But the enormity of the horror in Somalia, only now receiving the attention it has long demanded, will not soon be erased from memory. And along with pity for a suffering people, many viewers must feel anger and frustration.

title: Hudson's Bay Co. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Perez Again Gets Run Support And Shuts Down the Brewers
description: Melido Perez scratched his eyes, blinked and stared at the scoreboard. Could the Yankees really be scoring runs for him? Again?

title: Griffin Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: 6 Counties That Shine In Ratings For Bonds
description: Although fiscal success stories are hard to find in the New York region, they do exist: 6 of the nation's 28 most credit-worthy county governments, for example, are in the suburbs of New York City.

title: A New Line of Work For Nadia Comaneci
description: As an Olympic champion gymnast, NADIA COMANECI had all the exposure she could imagine. In a sense, that might pale beside how much more she will receive as a spokeswoman for Jockey underwear for women, which she became as of yesterday.

title: People
description: * Sean Fitzpatrick, executive vice president of McCann-Erickson North America, Troy, Mich., said on Monday that he would leave the November Company, the private firm creating advertising for the Bush re-election campaign, confirming a report this week in Adweek. Mr. Fitzpatrick said his departure was for personal reasons.

title: Burst Pipe Disrupts Wall Street
description: A 30-inch water main burst in the Wall Street area early yesterday, flooding the basements of two major office towers, forcing the closing of the southern part of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and disrupting the morning for tens of thousands of downtown workers and commuters.

title: Haitian Factions Hold Talks in Washington
description: Representatives of Haiti's exiled leader entered direct talks today for the first time with the military Government that overthrew President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in a coup nearly a year ago.

title: Petrolite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. to Buy Russian Bomb Uranium
description: The United States announced on Monday that it had agreed in principle to buy billions of dollars' worth of bomb-grade uranium from scrapped Soviet nuclear arms in an attempt to bolster the shaky Russian economy and to reduce the risks of nuclear accidents and theft.

title: New F.T.D. Service Goes to Thompson
description: The Florists' Transworld Delivery Association in Southfield, Mich., said yesterday that, as expected, J. Walter Thompson Detroit had won a $14 million advertising account to introduce a national telephone ordering service tying F.T.D. florists to a single "800" number. An article this week in Adweek said the association would announce the awarding of the account to Thompson Detroit.

title: Bosnia's Tragedy, and Bobby's
description: Think of Bosnia overrun by Serbian-backed militias. Then think of the chess genius Bobby Fischer violating United Nations sanctions, and decency itself, to play a chess match for profit in Serbia against his old rival Boris Spassky.

title: Market Place; A Squeeze Hurts A Health Niche
description: PROFITING from pressures to get patients out of expensive hospital beds quickly, companies that provide intravenous nutrition and drugs in the home have been on a roll. Sales of these so-called home-infusion companies tripled in three years to $3.2 billion in 1991 and may reach $4 billion this year, analysts said.

title: Rocky 2: Democracy on the Ropes
description: In a troubling decision yesterday, a Federal judge dismissed without a hearing claims that local election officials thwarted Larry Rockefeller's effort to force a Republican primary against Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York. The judge thus undercut the right of candidates and voters to free and fair elections.

title: Barbara and Me
description: Barbara Bush and I have a lot in common. We have both been married for 44 years. We each have five children and 12 grandchildren. We look somewhat alike, with white hair, ample hips and wrinkles from the sun and smiling. Sometimes I, too, wear three stands of pearls.

title: Design Notebook; A Ranch House Built for a Life That Used to Be
description: Everything looks smaller now. The mountain on Forest Avenue scaled on the way to school is just a slight pitch in the sidewalk, the big highway that stretched from the front of the house all the way to Chicago is only a road.

title: R-2000 Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: The Hurricane's Reshaping Of the Landscape Isn't Over
description: The pounding South Florida took from Hurricane Andrew reshaped the man-made and natural environments below Miami in ways that may significantly alter the beauty and sense of place of the area for years to come.

title: The Ferraro Marathon: 24-Hour Campaigning
description: If there was anything surreal about being in an almost-deserted greenhouse on the eastern tip of Suffolk County chatting about mutant tomatoes at 4:30 A.M., it was lost on Geraldine A. Ferraro.

title: Prediction of a Heart Attack May Prevent Trial of Clifford
description: A heart specialist's prediction that Clark M. Clifford might suffer a fatal heart attack if he is forced to stand trial has raised the distinct possibility that the 85-year-old lawyer-lobbyist may avoid prosecution on state and Federal bank fraud charges.

title: Young Finds Job Closing In On Him
description: Each appearance is a test for Anthony Young: of his arm, of his character, of an imagined future for the Mets that might not necessarily include John Franco in the bullpen.

title: Harmful Politicking in California
description: Despite a serious recession, California remains wealthier than many nations. Yet for two months it has had to pay some employees and many bills with i.o.u.'s, and its credit rating has plummeted. The episode has embarrassed California's politicians. It also challenges them to a higher order of statesmanship the next time around.

title: U.S. Cooling Toward Sandinistas' Successors
description: Nicaragua's relations with Washington have badly deteriorated over accusations that President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has ceded too much authority to the leftist Sandinista Front.

title: FOOTBALL: Pass-Fail Tests: Montana Is Unhappy and Hostetler Is Wobbly; Simms Sharper In Split Practice
description: A subpar Jeff Hostetler, returning 11 days after a back and pelvic injury, took the starter's snaps today as the Giants began the heavy work for the season opener.

title: In Queens, the Little Garden That Could
description: THE accent is very British. The design is very British. Only the locale is very New York backyard. But then, Prof. Roger Hart is a transplant from Nottingham, England.

title: Agency Rent-A-Car reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
In Rostock, Asylum-Seekers Lived in Powder Keg
description: Werner Matula was not surprised last week when rightist youths firebombed a hostel for foreign refugees seeking asylum in Germany. Like many people in this rust-bucket port on the Baltic Sea, he was expecting it.

title: Corrections
description: The diagram in the bridge column yesterday showed North's hearts incorrectly. North held K-Q-9-6.

title: Ruling Near in California on TV in the Classroom
description: A judge in San Jose today heard final arguments in a lawsuit the State Superintendent of Public Instruction hopes will shut down the California operation of Channel One, the Whittle Communications television program of news and commercials aimed at high school students.

title: As Quake Wreaks Havoc, Chamorro Appeals to U.S.
description: A natural disaster added to the pressures facing President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro today as she struggled to deal with demands from Washington that she rid her Government of the influence of the opposition Sandinista Front.

title: Have A Seat On The Bird
description: BRUCE NEWMAN has been called the Cecil B. De Mille of antiques dealers. His appreciation of the flamboyant has made him a natural collector of fantasy furniture, an extravagant and eccentric genre whose pieces often have animal shapes and were produced in exotic materials, mainly in Europe, from 1800 to World War I. He and his wife, Judith, have donated 14 prize examples to the Brooklyn Museum. They will go on view Sept. 24.

title: Calendar: Art Deco Revisited
description: New York Icons Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street; (212) 534-1672, ext. 206.

title: McEnroe Sees A New Order
description: John McEnroe, after marveling at Jimmy Connors's eagerness to celebrate his 40th birthday on the Stadium Court rather than in the tranquillity of retirement, says he knows he will not be around for 20 Opens.

title: Sonora Gold reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: M.I.T. RULED GUILTY IN ANTITRUST CASE
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the Massachusetts Institute of Technology had violated antitrust laws by participating in a decades-long conspiracy with other elite universities to fix the amount of student financial aid packages.

title: 63 Days After Its Cash Ran Out, California Passes Austere Budget
description: California's protracted budget crisis sputtered to an unhappy end early this morning when the weary State Assembly capitulated to Gov. Pete Wilson and approved the final elements of an austere budget 63 days after the state ran out of cash.

title: Fay's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
description: The company said share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split distributed on June 19, 1992.

title: Ingersoll-Rand Picks President
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company said it had named James E. Perrella, 57 years old, president and a member of the board of directors.

title: Home, Sick Home
description: Those who'd like to know more about "family values" would be well advised to turn on the television set tomorrow night. There, in a documentary called "Scared Silent: Exposing and Ending Child Abuse," they'll learn a terrible truth about the American home -- that it can sometimes be lethal to children.

title: Indonesia's Puppeteer May Seek a New Term
description: Indonesian politics are often compared to the ancient shadow puppetry known as wayang, with the role of the mysterious, all-controlling puppeteer assigned to the nation's leader for more than 25 years, President Suharto.

title: Transplanted New York Town Houses
description: IT took two New Yorkers to come out to L.A. and make the perfect New York town house," said Jeffrey Kalban, formerly of Long Island. He and Ivan Cohen, who was born in Brooklyn, are the architects of a 75-unit town house project in Pico Canyon, a new community in the northwest reaches of Los Angeles County.

title: FOOTBALL: Pass-Fail Tests: Montana Is Unhappy and Hostetler Is Wobbly; 49ers' Legend May Want Out
description: He hasn't formally asked to be traded, but Joe Montana, apparently upset that he was put on the injured-reserve list this week and cannot return to the team until October, is wondering about his future with the San Francisco 49ers.

title: The Cartoon's Characters Squish And Twist? It Must Be a Plympton
description: When the cartoonist Bill Plympton looks at a face, all sorts of things cross his mind. Weird things, like pulling both ears until they stretch a couple of feet, and then tying them in a knot. Or winding a face up like the rubber band for a model-airplane propeller. Or expanding the nostril until the nose inhales the entire head.

title: Arbitron Ends National TV Ratings System
description: The Arbitron Company shut down its experimental national television ratings system yesterday, citing a lack of support from advertisers and network television. The decision leaves the A. C. Nielsen Company without competition in the national television ratings.

title: Hospital Workers Need Protection Against New TB Strains; Quarantine Now
description: To the Editor:

title: DuBose Defends Himself
description: Notre Dame's DEMETRIUS DuBOSE, suspended for two games by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, yesterday defended his decision to accept a $600 loan from two football boosters.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ACCESS AMERICA TELEMANAGEMENT, acquired United Telemanagement Inc., creating the second-largest telemanagement company in the country, with more than $17 million in annual sales. HELEN OF TROY CORP., El Paso, a personal-care products concern, declared a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid as a 50 percent stock dividend on its common stock. The dividend is payable on Oct. 1 to shareholders of record on Sept. 15.

title: Coleman Is Planning to Strike Back
description: Vince Coleman, convinced that his suspension for his confrontation with Manager Jeff Torborg was unwarranted, has asked the Players Association to file a grievance against the Mets with baseball's arbitrator.

title: Norman Frenkiel, 87, Authority on Geriatrics
description: Dr. Norman N. Frenkiel, an authority on geriatrics, died on Saturday at the Hebrew Home at Riverdale in the Bronx. He was 87 years old and had lived at the home since 1989.

title: Polymerix Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Wisdom of Africa
description: Black Africa has much to teach its former masters in Europe. This may surprise those who think the only news from Africa concerns famine, war, pestilence and tyranny. Those scourges exist, but Africa has managed to keep a fifth affliction, ethnic separatism, from shattering national boundaries. Black Africa offers a lesson on the wisdom of respecting the territorial integrity of all states, whatever the mix of peoples.

title: In Election Year, Politics Greases Arms Decisions
description: The sale of F-16's to Taiwan announced by President Bush today is the latest in a series of arms decisions that experts say appear to be based as much on political considerations as on military ones.

title: Doctor in Brooklyn Held In Sex Abuse
description: A Brooklyn pediatrician was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing three teen-age patients at his office over the last 15 months, the police said.

title: Home Video
description: In this election year, when family values have become a point of contention, the video business is particularly wary of attack. Since the early 1980's some people have regarded video stores as primarily purveyors of pornography and violence, and that viewpoint found fresh expression last month on "Live With Regis and Kathie Lee."

title: CHRONICLE
description: Would James Beard, who died in 1985 and who did so much to elevate American cuisine, be dismayed at the prospect of a chili cook-off in his own backyard?

title: Gas Losses In Storm Increased
description: The Federal Government today nearly tripled its estimate of the natural gas output temporarily lost to the nation in the wake of Hurricane Andrew's battering of production and pipeline equipment in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Don't Pity Japan's Part-Time Rice Farmers; 'Comfort Women'
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal Home Loan Bank is offering $158 million of 5.74 percent notes due 1997 at a price of 100 through Merrill Lynch. The notes have a yield spread of 25 basis points over the Treasury's five-year note.

title: Investing Into the Wind: An Odd, Volatile Game
description: In May 1991, about 80 homeowners in the Hampshire Homes development of southern Miami filed suit against the Lennar Corporation, accusing Florida's largest home builder of shoddy construction with substandard materials. The company fixed some decoration and trim, but said the suits were groundless and the homes structurally sound.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Merry-Go-Round Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Review/Pop; Rebel Image, Sensitivity And Anger
description: If a carefully smoothed-out rebel image attached to a medium-size musical talent can create a pop star, then Mark Curry, a singer and songwriter from Sacramento, Calif., has a chance for big-time success.

title: Rabbi Eliezer Berkovits; Jewish Theologian, 84
description: Rabbi Eliezer Berkovits, an authority on Jewish theology and philosophy, died Aug. 20 at his home in Jerusalem. He was 84 years old and had lived in Jerusalem since 1973.

title: Special Teams Suit McMillan and Burkett
description: When Bruce Coslet announced the Jets' team captains for the coming season, it was no surprise to see wide receiver Al Toon and middle linebacker Kyle Clifton named for the third straight year.

title: Russian Coach Leaves
description: VIKTOR TIKHONOV is out as coach of the Russian national hockey team after nearly 15 years running the squad that represented the former Soviet Union, the weekly Moscow News reported. It said that BORIS MIKHAILOV, who had been Tikhonov's chief assistant, was named to replace him.

title: Threat Only When on Crack, Homeless Man Foils System
description: Peering from their apartment windows, the residents of West 96th Street have watched Larry Hogue's slow descent into madness. At first, he was just another shambling homeless man who muttered to himself, slept barefoot in the snow and ate from the garbage.

title: NEW HOME HUMBLE, BUT IS WELCOMED
description: Late this afternoon, with the harsh Florida sun pushing temperatures into the 90's, Moises Flores and his family got a look at their new home: Tent D-2 in the olive-drab canvas village that now rises from the municipal sports field across the Dixie Highway from City Hall.

title: Sears Will Pay $8 Million To Settle Repair Complaints
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company has agreed to pay $8 million to settle civil charges that its auto repair shops systematically overcharged customers for routine repairs in California.

title: Money, and Gripes, in Loan Program
description: When a natural disaster strikes, many businessmen and uninsured homeowners turn to the Federal Government for help in rebuilding, and in the 39 years of its existence the Government's main disaster loan program has distributed more than $15 billion.

title: British Privacy Debate Swayed U.S. Decisions
description: To the Editor:

title: Chairman of Bethlehem Steel Is Retiring
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel producer, announced yesterday that Walter F. Williams, who has been the company's chairman since 1986, will retire at the end of October. Curtis H. Barnette, Bethlehem's senior vice president and general counsel, will become the company's chairman and chief executive.

title: INSIDE
description: Growing Fears on Europe

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Biennial Confusion

title: Loewen, Ondaatje, McCutcheon reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss of $ 892,000 from the planned sale of LOM Western Securities Ltd.c-Net incomeResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: HOW DOES FLORIDA'S GARDEN GROW?
description: The gardening spirit is battered but very much alive in Dade County, Fla. Growing, page C2.

title:
OFF CAMERA WITH: Edd Hall;
The Man Behind the Voice Behind Jay Leno
description: EDD HALL, the man with television's dream announcer job, became a little less faceless last month when Jay Leno sat him down for a grilling on "The Tonight Show." Mr. Hall had been dreading it, but, he said, it wasn't so bad. "It's like having blood taken out of your arm," he reflected. "It really hurts, but I don't hate it anymore."

title: Don't Sell Out Lebanon
description: Lebanon, the first nation in the Arab Middle East to institute modern democratic precepts, has a history of vigorous electoral contests reflecting a more than century-old liberal tradition. Indeed, this long attachment to democratic values indicts the farce -- rather, the tragedy -- of what are passing for elections in Lebanon on Sunday.

title: Henley International reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
description: President Bush put his authority over foreign policy to work on behalf of his political campaign today, handing nearly $8 billion in contracts and grants to hard-pressed farmers and arms workers.

title: Lawmaker's Foe Says She's a New Broom
description: As Gary L. Ackerman, the four-term Representative described in "The Almanac of American Politics 1992" as "an authentic New York character," sweeps across his new Congressional district, seeking votes and raising money, he faces an unlikely challenge from Rita Morris, a plain-talking 68-year-old librarian who seems to have sprung straight out of a Frank Capra movie to ride the crest of voter discontent.

title: A Fischer Display of Power, Logic and Coolness
description: Bobby Fischer has taken up where he left off 20 years ago. In defeating Boris Spassky yesterday, the maverick grandmaster was as relentlessly logical over the chessboard as ever.

title: Bonds Countering Dollar's Plunge
description: When the dollar plunged to new lows against the German mark in late August, the bond market went with it, giving up much of the gains it made in July and early August. And there was concern that a continued fall in the dollar would pull the bond market even lower.

title: Rights Agency Accuses Times and Pressmen's Union of Job Discrimination
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission charged the pressmen's union and The New York Times with discrimination yesterday in the hiring of substitute workers in the newspaper's press room.

title: Don't Pity Japan's Part-Time Rice Farmers; Rejecting Profligacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Felix Guattari, a Psychoanalyst And Philospher, Is Dead at 62
description: Felix Guattari, a psychoanalyst and philosopher who influenced the post-1968 generation of French intellectuals, died on Saturday at La Borde, the clinic 100 miles south of Paris where he had worked for four decades. He was 62 years old.

title: Local Star May Take Rutgers a Long Way
description: A year ago, Bryan Fortay dropped into Doug Graber's lap, as unexpected as a found doubloon. Soon these words were sweeping around the many Rutgers campuses: "Transfer. . . . Miami. . . . Quarterback."

title: Review/Jazz; Tommy Flanagan, Surprises at His Finger Tips
description: Tommy Flanagan's trio is death to bass players. Mr. Flanagan, a preternaturally graceful pianist and one of jazz's finest improvisers, arranges his material to extract the fullest meaning from accents, breaks, unison bass and piano lines and metrical changes. Each piece is filled with tricky tempo changes, written passages and rhythmic undulations that have to be memorized. But even tougher, Mr. Flanagan is fearless, easily moving away from the basic harmonic contours of a composition, all done with the expectation that the bassist can hear his improvisations and follow them. At Condon's on Tuesday night, there were moments when Peter Washington, who was filling in for the trio's regular bassist, George Mraz, looked as if he'd stepped into a void.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Civil War Survivor At Ole Miss
description: WHEN Union troops rode into Oxford, Miss., in 1864 and burned buildings in the town square, the observatory of the University of Mississippi was one of the few structures they spared.

title: Budget Chief For Nassau Steps Down
description: Palmina Grella has worked in the Nassau County budget office for 23 years and knows as much about county finances as anyone in government, friends and officials agree. So her sudden resignation on Tuesday as budget director, amid the worst financial crisis in the county's history, came as a shock.

title: Sports of The Times; Torborg Finally Gets Mad
description: THE fans can burn their tickets or stomp all over the expensive little Mr. Met doll they bought in a moment of temporary insanity. What can the manager do? He can get hot, which Jeff Torborg did Tuesday night after Vince Coleman was thrown out of a game and then turned his anger on the manager.

title: U.S. Adopts New S.& L. Accounting Rules
description: The Office of Thrift Supervision adopted new accounting and reporting rules for the nation's savings and loan associations today, over industry protests.

title: Dinkins to Appoint Task Force on Lead Threat in Soil
description: As city officials and experts differed over the dangers of high lead concentrations found in soil near the Brooklyn, Manhattan and Williamsburg bridges, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced yesterday that he would form a task force to investigate the problem and recommend solutions.

title: Hospital Workers Need Protection Against New TB Strains
description: To the Editor:

title: Growing
description: Perhaps nowhere on earth is the gardening spirit more alive than in Dade County.

title: Rabin Strongly Criticizes Palestinian Negotiators
description: Saying Israel is offering Palestinians in the occupied territories the best deal for self-rule they have ever received, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin strongly criticized Palestinian peace negotiators today for raising issues that he said cannot lead to an agreement.

title: AN AGGRESSIVE TRADE POLICY
description: Agriculture specialists saw a new aggressiveness in trade policy in the expansion of the wheat-subsidy program. Business Day, page 2.

title: TechKnits Inc. reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
Gambinos Miss Court Date, Forfeiting $5 Million
description: Two brothers facing charges of smuggling heroin for John Gotti have disappeared, failing to appear at their arraignment in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Tuesday and thus forfeiting $5 million in bail.

title: Books of The Times; Two Whodunits Set in a Dreary, Cynical Russia
description: Two Leaps Across a Chasm A Russian Mystery By Nikolai Aleksandrov Translated by Anthony Olcott. 322 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons. $20. Rough Beast An Ivan Duvakin Novel By Anthony Olcott 243 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons. $20.

description: b-Net loss

title: Ernest A. Jones, 77; Directed the Growth Of a Top Ad Agency
description: Ernest Albin Jones, for many years one of the country's foremost advertising executives, died on Monday at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Pontiac, Mich. He was 77 years old and lived in another Detroit suburb, Bloomfield Hills.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats; Days After 'Final' Word on Draft, Clinton Faces Renewed Questions
description: A week after Bill Clinton issued what he declared was his final statement "to set the record straight" on how he stayed out of the military during the Vietnam War, the Democratic Presidential nominee today found himself again facing questions about how he managed to avoid the draft.

title: Events: Landscape Overview
description: Landscape Legacy Arthur A. Houghton Jr. Gallery at Cooper Union, 41 Cooper Square (Astor Place); (212) 353-4157.

title: Economic Scene; One Currency: Pain or Gain?
description: THE fall of the dollar is yesterday's news in America, a mere digression from enduring issues like witchcraft and family values. But the rise of the German mark -- the flip side of the dollar's humbling -- is not about to be brushed aside in Europe.

title: Partisan Points of Light
description: THOSE wanting to shed light on this year's political campaigns may want to check out these "Party Animal" lamps ($48 each), made by Form Farm Inc. of New York.

title: Parthenons of a Sort
description: ONCE upon a time, Manny Lepowski, alias Ellery Queen, wrote a letter to his childhood friend Morris Lapidus, the Miami architect: "It's like my boyhood dreams of being a modern Shakespeare. You want to build Parthenons and out comes a Miami hotel."

title: Ascii of Japan Says It Has Lined Up Lenders
description: Kazuhiko Nishi, the entrepreneur who helped create Japan's personal computer industry, has rescued his company from the threat of bankruptcy.

title: Assembly Speaker Pressed To Help Stop Car Thefts
description: The Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly told a group of black clergymen today that the Legislature must respond to the increasingly violent car-theft problem in the Newark area, but he said an effective response requires more discussion between community leaders and lawmakers.

title: Leonard W. Mayo Is Dead at 92; Educator Who Helped Disabled
description: Leonard Withington Mayo, an educator who spent a lifetime helping people with disabilities and who was an adviser on their needs to five Presidents, died on Tuesday at his home in Chagrin Falls, Ohio, a suburb of Cleveland.

title: It's Time to Meet: What's the Agenda?
description: A lawyer not directly involved in the ownership dispute involving Commissioner Fay Vincent was wondering the other day if the anti-Vincent faction really had a majority of clubs supporting its position.

title: AUGUST WAS BUSIEST MONTH EVER FOR AMERICAN AIR
description: American Airlines said yesterday that the half-fare promotions that expire throughout the airline industry this month had made August the busiest month in its history. American flew 10.5 billion revenue passenger-miles, up 21.7 percent from August 1991, with domestic revenue passenger-miles up 24.8 percent, to 7.9 billion. Revenue passenger-miles represent the number of miles flown by paid passengers.

title: POLISH EX-PREMIER KILLED
description: Piotr Jaroszewicz, a former Polish Communist Prime Minister, and his wife were found dead in their home. Polish officials said Mr. Jaroszewicz was tortured and strangled. Page D18.

title: De Beers May Be Losing Grip on Diamond Market
description: Less than a month ago De Beers Consolidated Mines, the secretive South African company that dominates the world diamond trade through a cartel that controls 80 percent of the world's uncut diamonds, seemed to have coasted miraculously through a recession that had rattled other luxury industries.

title: Yankees Come Up Cold As Brewer Rookie Sizzles
description: The tiny crowds at County Stadium do not make it feel like pennant fever has afflicted this city. But Cal Eldred's sparkling pitching has been the stuff that October dreams are made.

title: Executive Changes
description: ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY LABORATORIES INC., Bothell, Wash., a maker of diagnostic ultrasound systems, appointed Harvey N. Gillis senior vice president of finance and administration, and chief financial officer of the company. COMPUTONE CORP., Roswell, Ga., a maker of circuit boards, appointed Edward L. Marinaro chairman and chief executive, and Robert J. Niehaus president and chief operating officer.

title: Mary Norton, 88, Author of the 'Borrowers' Series
description: Mary Norton, a writer of children's books whose series about the tiny Borrowers was acclaimed by adults and devoured by legions of children, died on Saturday at her home in Hartland, England. She was 88 years old.

title: Municipal Financial reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: High Schools For Students Who Disrupt
description: To deal with the persistent problem of the disruptive, even violent, student, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez has ordered the creation this fall of four small, alternative high schools to be attended by youngsters facing long-term suspension from their regular schools.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Every year for nearly half a century, a group of old friends has gotten together on the day before Labor Day to sing "Happy Birthday" to JEAN DALRYMPLE, the producer, director, actress and author.

title: Spaghetti Warehouse Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from the early extinguishment of debt of $ 187,166 for both the quarter and year.

title: Insurer Limits New York Policies
description: Beginning Sept. 15, Nationwide Insurance Company will stop issuing individual and small-group health insurance policies in New York State, in response to a sweeping measure, adopted by the State Legislature in July, that dictates that insurance companies charge uniform rates, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: Overwhelmed by Kindness, Louisiana Begins Rebuilding
description: A week after Hurricane Andrew slashed through Louisiana, plastic sheets are spread on hundreds of roofs like oversized Band-Aids, utility crews jam the streets and National Guard troops direct traffic as the storm's victims begin the painful march from recovery to rebuilding.

title: Tax-Exempt Yields Gain but Taxables Slip
description: The yields offered by money market funds were mixed in the latest week, as the supply of municipal debt remained heavy and money markets regained composure after last week's decline in the dollar, according to The IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report, which surveyed 857 funds.

title: Jimbo and New York: In Perfect Harmony
description: In the Open cockpit, Jimbo is our boy, never more than now that he is too old to have a future and too worn to thrill us to climax, the championship. He is everything that's skewed and wonderful about this city, greedy and needy and bold and begging and gifted and mean. Watching Jimbo play, the crowd tries to channel his spirit, bottle it and take it home, like air or sunshine from somewhere nice. Then sniff it as needed. Anything is possible with the spirit of Jimbo; you could imagine yourself hot-wiring a parked car to move it and steal its space. Drop a buck in a homely's paper cup, then drive him off your block. Nupe the whales.

title: Kemper Names President
description: The Kemper Corporation today named Stephen Timbers president and chief operating officer of the $15 billion financial services holding company.

title: Experts Discount Threat of Typhoid and Cholera
description: The chances of an epidemic of typhoid or cholera in the areas struck by Hurricane Andrew are remote, but disease prevention experts are on the scene to track down any cases of potentially communicable intestinal or respiratory illness, said a specialist in disaster epidemiology at the Federal Centers for Disease Control.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 THREAT TO DIAMOND CARTEL

title: This Is My Room, And That's My Stuff
description: The books children like to read, the friends they cultivate and the furniture they want to relax on are not always what their parents have in mind. In an informal survey, children 6 to 18 years old and their parents were asked about accessories for a child's bedroom, and the responses were nicely soothing: two generations can agree, when furnishings are basic, functional, well designed and whimsical but definitely not corny.

title: Saratoga Dew Greets Belmont
description: New York's racing scene switched smoothly from Saratoga to Belmont Park yesterday, and the star of the show on opening day was the filly with the evocative name, Saratoga Dew, who won the Gazelle Handicap for her seventh victory in nine starts.

title: Standard Logic Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
A CANCER LEGACY FROM CHERNOBYL
description: Children who were exposed to radiation from the Chernobyl nuclear power plant disaster are developing thyroid cancer sooner and in larger numbers than expected, researchers report.

title: Seagram Co. Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a $ 29 million pre-tax restructuring charge for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Amelia Lobsenz; Executive, 70
description: Amelia Lobsenz, a public-relations executive who ran her own firm in Manhattan for the last 36 years, died on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived in Old Brookville, L.I., and Manhattan.

title: Don't Like That Brick Wall? How About the Seine?
description: Karen Loew has figured out how to do for the claustrophobic Manhattan apartment what Michelangelo did for the Sistine Chapel: Turn it into a room with a view. Not by putting a corner-to-corner fresco on the ceiling. Not by putting top-to-bottom mirrors on the walls. But by painting window shades. Yes, plain old-fashioned pull-down window shades.

title: Critic's Notebook; Air-Conditioner: Century's Instrument Of Musical Change
description: The 18th century had its clarinet, the 19th its saxophone, but our time has invented and nurtured a wind instrument of its own, the air-conditioner. It has changed our musical lives and not always for the better. If by summer's end the music-loving ear now finds itself only vaguely curious about the new season only a few weeks away, thank in part this 20th-century machine.

title: Simcoe Erie Investors reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Accounts
description: * The French Government Tourist Office, New York, to Ketchum Advertising New York, which retains the tourism advertising account, with billings estimated at $4 million. The agency has had the account since 1989. Ketchum bested three other New York agencies in a mandated review: Bloom FCA, Della Femina McNamee Inc. and Wells Rich Greene BDDP. * Federal Express Corp., Memphis, to TFB/BBDO, Palo Alto, Calif., to manage a new communications program for the automated systems marketing division. TFB/BBDO bested Tallant LaPointe & Partners, San Francisco, in a review on the account. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Ways to Store Delicate Items Safely
description: When storing delicate or sensitive items, from photographic negatives to prom gowns, good intentions are rarely enough. "Damage can occur precisely when you think you've got something safely stored away," said Bruce Hutchison, who heads the Textile Conservation Laboratory at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan.

title: Partisan Air Clouds a Trenton Hearing on the Loss of Medicaid Funds
description: Despite the vow of its chairman that no "witch hunt" is in store, a legislative committee began hearings today on the apparent loss of nearly a half-billion dollars in Medicaid money, with Republicans pointing fingers directly at Gov. Jim Florio.

title: Falcon Products reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Vanbiesbrouck Reaches Pact To Remain With the Rangers
description: JOHN VANBIESBROUCK and the Rangers have agreed to a new contract. Terms were not disclosed, but it was learned that Vanbiesbrouck will earn an average of about $1 million per year. The contract is for two years plus an option season. Last season, Vaniesbrouck earned $375,000.

title: Normal Economic Existence Is Years Away in Storm Area
description: Despite the vast scale of Federal aid to hurricane victims that President Bush has announced, southern Dade County will take years to rebuild the houses and businesses it needs, say economists, business owners and local officials.

title: N.H.L. and ESPN Together Again
description: For the last four years, the National Hockey League has been a sports television version of "Nothin' Exposure." Pro hockey became almost invisible for the majority of viewers in the United States when it left the more widely available ESPN cable network and moved to SportsChannel America.

title: Connors's Birthday Gift Is Same as Last Year's
description: It was a tough act to follow, but since it was his own act, he could hardly turn down the opportunity for a sequel. With effortless charisma and infinite determination, Old Man Open, a k a Jimmy Connors, dominated a scene that was part prize fight, part Broadway opening and part sorcery late last night as he went to battle against Jaime Oncins of Brazil in their first-round match of the United States Open.

title: Republic Goldfields reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $ 125,500 gain from the conversion of Echo Bay Mines Ltd.'s debt to equity.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bridge
description: All but one of the matches at the NEC World Championships here today were close affairs. The exception was the match in which the American open team overwhelmed Egypt, the first African country ever to advance to the playoff stage of a world event. The Egyptians were handicapped by illness, and lost 71 imps in the second quarter of 16 deals. They trailed by the huge margin of 97 with 16 deals remaining.

title: I.B.M. Spins Off PC Business Into New Company
description: In the clearest evidence yet of its determination to shake up its bureaucratic corporate culture, I.B.M. said yesterday that it was establishing a separate company to develop manufacture, distribute and market personal computers.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Vice President; Quayle Tries to Separate Family Values and 'Murphy Brown'
description: Vice President Dan Quayle sought today to rein in a political debate on family values that seems to have spun out of his control since he opened it last May with an attack on the television show "Murphy Brown."

title: Nelson Vending Tech reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Awarding Cash Prizes to Stamp Out Boredom in Billboards
description: THE idea is simple, yet ingenious. A poster shows a mighty dam holding back a Niagara-sized amount of water, and across the top of the dam is a single word -- "Huggies."

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: EXPERIENCE may be the best teacher, but for house and apartment owners with little spare time, learning home maintenance by doing is often difficult. Following are some tricks of the trade that can make repairs and other projects a bit easier. Measuring

title: Essay; I Am a Pencil
description: One sign, up near the stage in the amphitheater, reads "Stills," inviting not moonshiners but still photographers.

title: Work, Work, Work, But Lendl Triumphs
description: Call it a state of suspended animation, but the United States Open seemed to hold its breath yesterday in anticipation of the second coming of the birthday boy, Jimmy Connors, this event's resident demi-octogenarian.

title: Seeking Sponsors For AIDS Program
description: A television production company that has created a syndicated special aimed at educating teen-agers about the virus that causes AIDS is disappointed: only about half the commercial time on the program has been sold so far.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New Credit Card From G.E. To Offer Merchant Coupons
description: The GE Capital Corporation introduced a new credit card yesterday that offers discount coupons and rebates from 24 large companies, including Kmart, Macy's, Northwest Airlines, Sprint and Hertz.

title: U.N. Agencies Ordered to Continue Efforts in Iraq
description: The Security Council defied President Saddam Hussein tonight by ordering United Nations aid agencies to continue efforts to supply food and medicine to needy Iraqis despite the Baghdad Government's attempt to shut down an international aid program intended to help victims of the international economic embargo against Iraq.

title: Don't Pity Japan's Part-Time Rice Farmers

title: Appointments at Kidder
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company, a unit of the General Electric Company, appointed two longtime employees, John B. Ward and Edward J. Laux, as co-heads of its Institutional Equity Trading Group. Mr. Laux will assume responsibility for capital commitment and Mr. Ward for sales trading. Both will report to Thomas Ryan Jr., executive managing director of Kidder's equity group.

title: ETS International reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 28,778, for the latest year and $ 9,364 for the year-earlier period.The company is listed on the Emerging Company Marketplace.

title: Rub-On Varnishes: Farewell to Brushes
description: The blessing of the recent rub-on varnishes can be truly appreciated only by those who grew up with the old-formula brush-on variety. A refinisher's life then was not easy, for no matter how much effort was taken to work in a dust-free environment, every speck of dust that existed seemed to settle on the finish as it dried, ever so slowly. If the specks were not picked out with a stick, they became entombed in the hardened layer of finish.

title: Review/Television; Boomers Entering Middle Age In a Series
description: So what happens to the thirtysomethings when they become forty almosts? That is the question explored, not to say tortured, by "Middle Ages," the new series that has its two-hour premiere tonight and will take its place in the CBS schedule next Thursday at 10 P.M.

title: YELTSIN RESISTANT ON JAPAN DISPUTE
description: Two weeks before a visit to Japan, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia said today that politics made it untimely for him to hand over disputed Pacific islands to Japan, and he complained that Tokyo was putting inappropriate pressure on him to do so.

title: A Jail Garden's Harvest: Hope and Redemption
description: The leeks, raspberries, swiss chard and rose fir potatoes that Cathrine Sneed and her inmate gardeners coax from the soil are not merely fruits and vegetables.

title: Fischer Wins First Game of Match With Spassky
description: With verve and vigor, Bobby Fischer returned to competitive chess today after a 20-year absence as a recluse and crushed his old rival Boris Spassky in the opening game of an exhibition series.

title: ROCKWELL PLANS ADDITIONAL INVESTMENT IN AUTO UNIT
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that it would invest an additional $1 billion in its automotive business by 1997, matching its previous five-year investment. "Our current five-year plan for automotive is to increase sales to $3 billion by 1996," said Donald R. Beall, chairman and chief executive.

title: NASA Picks Cray Research Over NEC in Computer Deal
description: Cray Research Inc. said today that it had won a bitterly contested battle with NEC, the Japanese supercomputer maker, and had begun negotiations with the NASA Ames Research Center for the sale of a $74.5 million supercomputer.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: PAUL BURGETT recalls the excitement he felt his first few days as a freshman violin major at college. He'd won much acclaim as a high school musician in his hometown, and was sure that college would be only a way station on his fast track to an international concert career. Then he heard the other students practicing.

title: U.S. Wheat Subsidies Are 'Message' to Europe
description: In the ambitious expansion announced today in the Government's subsidy program for wheat exports, the Bush Administration is not only ingratiating itself electorally with farmers but also displaying a new, sharp-elbowed aggressiveness in trade policy, agriculture specialists said.

title: Newbridge Networks reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Engle Homes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said results for 1991 and the latest nine months are pro forma to reflect the Jan. 21 initial public offering. At that time, Engle changed to a C corporation from an S coporation.

title: Market Place; Rising Challenger In Tough Market
description: THE consumer electronics business in and around Manhattan is not for the faint of heart or small of ego.

title: Polish Premier Sticking to Tough Line on Strikers
description: She has been vilified by strikers and criticized by members of her own political party for her unyielding stance toward workers, but Prime Minister Hanna Suchocka shows no signs of backing down.

title: Serbian Party Fails to Remove Yugoslav Premier
description: Clearly embarrassed, Serbia's governing party abandoned an attempt tonight to remove Yugoslavia's concession-minded Prime Minister after Yugoslavia's President called the ouster attempt "ill considered and politically damaging."

title: Citicorp Criticized on Mortgages That Expose It to Too Much Risk
description: A highly unusual unauthorized release of a document that sums up a Federal examination of Citicorp's mortgage business paints a critical picture of the way that subsidiary is run.

title: Japan Is Tough, but Xerox Prevails
description: A case study in how to beat the Japanese: When the Xerox Corporation began designing its new high-speed photocopying machine, the Model 5100, it had world markets in mind, especially the Japanese.

title: Seek Peace Without Khmer Rouge, Sihanouk Says
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia said today that the United Nations peace plan for his shattered nation should go forward with or without the Khmer Rouge, who have refused to disarm their forces in the countryside.

title: In Fight Over Tennis Courts, a Village Examines Its Priorities
description: THE opinions are flying as fast here as the tennis balls at Flushing Meadows. Would it be unseemly for this village to build more tennis courts, given the tough economic climate?

title: Final Text of Trade Pact May Be Behind Schedule
description: American, Canadian and Mexican negotiators have run into trouble in reaching agreement on the final text of the North American Free Trade Agreement announced by President Bush on Aug. 12.

title: WALL STREET PLACES ITS BETS
description: The swings taken by a home builder's stock after the hurricane show Wall Street's odd ways of betting on disaster. Business Day, page D1.

title: Yamaguchi to Turn Pro
description: KRISTI YAMAGUCHI, an Olympic gold medalist, is turning pro, but she may still defend her figure skating title at the 1994 Lillehammer Games. Yamaguchi has until next Feb. 19 to apply for reinstatement as an amateur to the United States Figure Skating Association, according to an International Skating Union rule passed in June. (AP)

title: Behind the Hate in Oregon
description: In Oregon, something similar to an "ethnic cleansing" is under way. It has transformed a once tolerant, progressive state into a repressive, frightful place.

title: Police Held Not Liable In Shooting
description: A Queens grand jury yesterday found no criminal liability on the part of the police officer who killed a hostage by firing five bullets into him during a shootout with gunmen. No charges will be filed against the officer.

title: I.B.M. and Canon Are Said to Plan Venture
description: I.B.M. and Canon are planning to team up in developing certain small computers, a Canon executive said today.

title: China Flunks a Freedom Test
description: China would like Americans to applaud its economic reforms while averting their eyes from abuses like arbitrary arrest, torture and slave labor. But such selective vision now becomes much harder after two disturbing events.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League BALTIMORE ORIOLES -- Recalled Luis Mercedes, outfielder, from Rochester of the International League.

title: Casey's General Stores reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
New Concern On Number Of Officers Near Slaying
description: Police officials are concerned that more off-duty officers than they originally believed were socializing along a strip of bars in Queens when an off-duty housing officer was killed and that the officers did not come forward to tell what they knew, a law-enforcement official said yesterday.

title: Metall Mining reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Aug. 21 about a power failure in Hoboken, N.J., and parts of Jersey City and Union City N.J., misidentified a spokeswoman for Public Service Electric and Gas of Newark. She is Michelle O'Neill.

title: British Say Europe Pact Dies if French Vote No
description: Britain would consider the treaty on European union a dead letter and withdraw it from ratification if voters in France reject the accord in a nationwide referendum later this month, a senior British official said today.

title: Scheib (Earl) Inc.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
No Headline
description: "M.I.T.'s attempt to disassociate the Overlap process from the commercial aspects of higher education is pure sophistry. No reasonable person could conclude that the Ivy Overlap agreements did not suppress competition." -- Federal District Judge LOUIS C. BECHTLE. [ A1:5. ]

title: Jerusalem Journal; Draft Yeshiva Boys? Parents Fire Up an Old Battle
description: As 17-year-old Yitzhak Fischer left the Israeli Army recruitment center, having just registered for the draft that awaits him in a few months, two young men walked in.

title: Raytech Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Included a foreign translation gain of $ 700,000.

title: Melvin L. Rosen, 42, Organizer Of Programs to Fight AIDS Crisis
description: Melvin L. Rosen, a prominent battler against AIDS and the immediate past chairman of Beth Simchat Torah synagogue in Manhattan, died on Monday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 3 Haitians With H.I.V. Are Allowed to Enter U.S.
description: Waiving regulations that bar foreigners with the virus that causes AIDS from entering the United States, the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization has allowed three infected Haitians held at the United States Navy base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, to come to American hospitals for treatment.

title: Jaroszewicz, a Polish Ex-Premier, And His Wife Are Killed at Home
description: Piotr Jaroszewicz, a former Prime Minister of Poland, and his wife were found dead in their home in a suburb of Warsaw, Polish officials said yesterday, describing the deaths as homicides. Mr. Jaroszewicz was 82 years old; the age of his wife, Alicja Solska, could not be learned yesterday.

title: CUC International reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said all share earnings reflect the 3-for-2 stock split.

title: Mrs. Bush's Red Ribbon
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows, performances and art exhibitions in the New York metropolitan region that close soon: Closing This Weekend

title: China Warns U.S. on Taiwan Jet Deal
description: China threatened today to withdraw from international arms-control talks if President Bush goes through with his decision to sell 150 fighter jets worth $6 billion to Taiwan, but the White House brushed off the warning.

title: Christiana Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
