description: Two years after a new City Charter tightened controls on corrupt contractors, New York City continues to award large contracts to companies with questionable integrity and poor performance records, Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said in a report released yesterday.

title: Johnston Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net lossShare earnings and shares outstanding are restated for a 3-for-2 stock split of February 1992.Sales represented net sales.

title: Regis Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included an operating loss of $ 181,000 associated with Essanelle, as well as a loss of $ 2,031,000 on the sale of these salon operations. It also included a one-time special officer bonus of $ 4,833,000.The 1991 year's sales included sales of $ 21,055,000 associated with the company's divested Essanelle salon operations.

title: Timothy Egan Lenahan, Architect, 34
description: Timothy Egan Lenahan, an architect who had practiced with Robert A. M. Stern, died on Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 34 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Reviews/Film; A 1970's Caper Movie With Heroes of the Time
description: "Sneakers" looks like a movie that just surfaced after being buried alive for 20 years. It's an atrophied version of a kind of caper movie that was so beloved in the early 1970's, starring Robert Redford and Sidney Poitier, both of whom were very big back then, though they now appear embarrassed to be imitating their youthful selves in such creaky fashion.

title: Charles de Bretteville, 79, Banker And Businessman in California
description: Charles de Bretteville, a leading businessman who became chairman of the Bank of California, died Friday at Community Hospital in Monterey, Calif. He was 79 years old and lived in nearby Pebble Beach.

title: Sharpton's Search for Votes
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton seems to be campaigning in a different world than his white rivals in the Democratic Senate primary.

title: Gunfire Erupts in Bronx, And Two Bystanders Die
description: An argument at a block party in the Bronx escalated into gunfire late Monday night, killing two bystanders, including a woman who was seven months pregnant, and injuring a man, the police said.

title: G.M. Expected to Announce Details of New Credit Card
description: Think of it as a frequent drivers card.

title: Saks Names A New Vice Chairman
description: The management shake-up at Saks Fifth Avenue that has produced a number of high-profile departures in recent months continued on a more positive note yesterday when Gary Witkin, executive vice president and director of the department-store division of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, was named vice chairman of the specialty retailer.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Profile; Quayle's Right Hand: a Contrarian Tries to Remold Boss's Image
description: When everyone else at Harvard was marching against the war in Vietnam, William Kristol was defending it as a righteous cause. When they were rallying for the equal rights amendment, he was testifying against it at a Senate hearing. While others were lampooning Richard M. Nixon, he was wearing a Spiro Agnew sweatshirt around campus "just to shock people."

title: Digitran Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
More Than Dances and Picnics Greet Freshmen; Orientation at Columbia Includes Forums on Tolerance, Free Speech and Date Rape
description: The gymnasium was a jumble of faces, hundreds of them, black, white, Asian, Hispanic, male, female, all of them young, all of them listening to a sincere-looking Columbia University student who was talking about the night he came to terms with being gay.

title: Fans Feel 'Cheated' By 7 Hours Of Matches
description: The 20,831 fans who showed up for the day session yesterday at the United States Open got an eyeful of tennis for their $27 investment -- nearly seven hours' worth of action. A 4-hour-20-minute marathon between the defending champion, Stefan Edberg, and Richard Krajicek, was followed by a two-hour upset of Gabriela Sabatini by Mary Joe Fernandez that didn't end until almost 6 P.M.

title: Review/Film; State Says Delbert Killed Bill; Delbert Says Bill Just Plain Died
description: On June 6, 1990, William Ward, 64 years old, was found dead in the bed he had shared for most of his life with his brother, Adelbert, 59, known as Delbert, in the unheated shack on the upstate New York dairy farm where they lived with their brothers Roscoe, 70, and Lyman, 62. Bill suffered from several ailments, and the death was originally thought to have been the result of natural causes. An autopsy then suggested that there had been foul play.

title: Women and Chess
description: To The Living Section:

title: No Headline
description: "Two weeks ago there were thousands of unemployed construction workers around here. Right now, anybody who is not working is just plain lazy." -- THOMAS MENDEZ, a contractor in Boca Raton, Fla. [ A1:6. ]

title: The Pop Life
description: Linda Ronstadt's Beginnings

title: Running Schools Amid Homework Assignments
description: WHEN classes begin today for some 993,000 students in New York City schools, Keysha McNeil will face one of the biggest challenges of her 16-year-old life. As the first student representative on the Board of Education to serve a full academic year, she must give voice to the cacophony of dreams, needs and aspirations of her fellow students.

title: Alive and Well in Washington Heights
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: In the Background; Democrats Charge 'Dirty Tricks' Over Draft Issue
description: As President Bush's re-election campaign intensified its public assault on Gov. Bill Clinton's draft record today, Democrats accused their opponents of resorting to "dirty tricks" to press the issue behind the scenes.

title: Surprising Portrait Of Psychotherapists As Abuse Victims
description: A SURPRISINGLY high number of psychotherapists have been victims of sexual or physical abuse, a new study shows.

title: Lendl, Chang and Edberg Each Win Marathons
description: It was the longest of days, with marathons the mode in three of four men's Round of 16 contests, and last night at the United States Open a resolute Ivan Lendl and a bombastic Boris Becker dueled into the witching hour in what is believed to be the longest match here in 22 years.

title: PWA IS READY TO SELECT RESCUE PLAN FOR AIRLINE
description: The PWA Corporation, parent of Canadian Airlines International, said yesterday that it expected to decide today between two competing proposals to help the airline out of its financial troubles. "We're expecting a decision to be made," said a PWA spokesman, Jack Lawless.

title: Topro Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company was formerly the Enterinvestment Corp.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League MILWAUKEE BREWERS -- Recalled Bruce Ruffin, pitcher, and Jim Tatum and Jose Valentin, infielders, from Denver of the American Association. NEW YORK YANKEES -- Recalled Sterling Hitchcock, pitcher, from Albany of the Eastern League. National League NEW YORK METS -- Recalled Pat Howell and D.J. Dozier, outfielders, and Kevin Baez and Jeff McKnight, infielders, from Tidewater of the International League. PHILADELPHIA PHILLIES -- Signed Jose DeLeon, pitcher, to a two-year contract. Transferred Wes Chamberlain, outfielder, from the 15-day to the 60-day disabled list. PITTSBURGH PIRATES -- Extended the contract of Ray Miller, pitching coach, through the 1994 season. ST. LOUIS CARDINALS -- Recalled Bien Figueroa, Stan Royer and Craig Wilson, infielders, and Chuck Carr, outfielder, from Louisville of the American Association. Football National Football League CHICAGO BEARS -- Placed Glen Kozlowski, wide receiver, on injured reserve. Signed Bob Christian, running back, and Barry Wagner, wide receiver, to the practice squad. TAMPA BAY BUCCANEERS -- Placed Tony Covington, safety, on injured reserve. Re-signed Chris Barber, defensive back. Hockey National Hockey League NEW YORK RANGERS -- Agreed to terms with Mike Richter, goaltender; Jay Wells, defenseman; and Tie Domi, right wing. ST. LOUIS BLUES -- Named Yuri Karmanov part-time European scout. WASHINGTON CAPITALS -- Signed Dimitri Khristich, left wing.

title: Sun May Sell Coal Business As It Focuses on Oil Refining
description: Following similar consolidations by other big energy companies, the Sun Company said yesterday that it might sell off its coal-mining and coke-making operations.

title: Ozawa Goes Home for Festival To Help Musicians Stay in Japan
description: When Seiji Ozawa first returned to Japan as a guest conductor in the early 1960's, his brash, Americanized style so angered the musicians of the NHK Symphony that they secretly decided to boycott the concert and sent cancellation notices to the ticket holders. When the young conductor arrived at the concert hall for what should have been a glorious homecoming, he faced a vacant stage and nearly empty auditorium.

title: Georgia Bonded Fibers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 49,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 99,000, or 6 cents a share, for the year, both from change in accounting for cost of goods sold and inventory.Georgia Bonded Fibers said that it attributed increased earnings to improvements in manufacturing equipment which increased productivity and lowered product cost, and to about $ 2 million in investments for production improvements in the U.S. and Europe.

title: Five for Congress
description: It will be even harder than usual for New York voters to cast an informed vote for Congress in next Tuesday's primary election. As usual, many districts remain so dominated by Democrats that winning will be tantamount to victory in November. And as usual, there's little time for appraisal, what with the primary coming so soon after the summer doldrums.

title: Olympia, Bondholders In 55 Water St. Accord
description: Olympia & York, the troubled Canadian developer, reached an agreement in principle yesterday calling for bondholders of 55 Water Street to take over ownership of the Manhattan office building.

title: Mets Plan to Shake Up Their Scouting System
description: The bureaucratese was polite and antiseptic, the official announcement loaded with terms like "efficiency" and "restructuring." What the Mets, in announcing a reworked scouting and talent development operation, said today was this:

title: Sports of The Times; Dear David: Don't Even Think of It
description: THE smartest man in sports is David Stern. He can explain cable television and salary caps and the future of international basketball better than anybody I know.

title: Little Nuclear Secrets
description: The Bush Administration has objected to a moratorium on nuclear testing for safety reasons. As Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney told the Senate recently, "The purpose of all U.S. nuclear tests of our weapons henceforth is to evaluate and improve the safety of our much smaller nuclear deterrent and to maintain the reliability of U.S. forces."

title: Georgia Sale By Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had completed the sale of the offices, equipment and subscription lists of The Gwinnett Daily News, a suburban Atlanta newspaper it had owned since 1987. The newpaper was published on Sunday for the last time.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Avatar Holdings Inc., Coral Gables, Fla., a real estate and utility holding company, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission on a proposed offer to exchange up to $34.5 million of new 9 percent senior debentures due in 2000 for all of 8 percent senior debentures due in 2000 outstanding.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column in The Living Section last Wednesday referred incompletely to Federal policy regulating the use of the word caviar on food labels. Only sturgeon roe can be called simply caviar. The roe of other fish can be labeled caviar only in conjunction with the name of the fish. For example, caviar made from salmon roe can be marketed as "salmon caviar."

title: Doubleday May Sell His Share Of the Mets
description: One day after declaring the actions taken to force Commissioner Fay Vincent to resign "inexcusable, illegal and immoral," Nelson Doubleday, co-owner of the Mets, reiterated his desire to disassociate himself from the game by selling his interest in the team.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY A CASE STUDY IN FAILURE

title: Suspect Changes Plea to Guilty In Kidnapping of Oil Executive
description: The man accused of abducting a top Exxon official pleaded guilty today to seven counts of conspiracy and extortion, describing in detail a ransom scheme that went brutally awry and ended, he said, with the victim dying in his arms.

title: Cellular Phone Industry Reports Growth
description: Despite a persistent recession that has hit its most loyal customers especially hard, the cellular telephone industry reported record growth in the six months ended June 30, with nearly 8.9 million subscribers. The number of subscribers grew 17.6 percent from the December 1991 half and 39 percent from the half a year earlier.

title: Control the Tow Truck Cowboys
description: The fatal collision of a speeding tow truck and a car in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn fully warrants aggressive investigation of the truck driver and the towing company involved. Initial reports suggest that he had a long record of reckless driving that the company ignored.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush Makes Appeal to Jews

title: Edison Brothers Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Kim Chung Yul, 75, South Korean Premier
description: Kim Chung Yul, a former Prime Minister of South Korea who helped prepare the country for its first general elections, died on Monday. He was 75 years old and lived in Seoul.

title: For Fewer Chemicals
description: To The Living Section:

title: Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: Share earnings were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock dividend paid on July 27, 1992.The company broke-even in the latest fourth quarter.

title: Vending Machines, the Next Generation in Dining
description: IT'S not hard to see the flaws in vending machines. They swallow money and never return it. They promise to drop a package of candy but freeze in mid moment, cruelly dangling something that cannot be reached. Or they offer food that is appealing only to the desperate.

title: VARITY UNIT TO SELL MF INDUSTRIAL TO MANAGEMENT
description: The Varity Corporation said yesterday that its Massey Ferguson group had agreed to sell its industrial machinery business, MF Industrial, to a group led by the unit's management for about $18 million. MF Industrial, based in Manchester, England, had sales of about $91 million in 1991. Varity, based in Toronto, said in a statement that the sale was part of its restructuring program. The proceeds will be used to reduce debt.

title: Lewis Freedman Memorial
description: A memorial service for Lewis Freedman, a television producer and program executive for CBS and PBS, is to be held on Friday at 11 A.M. at the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, at Lincoln Center. Mr. Freedman died on June 25 at age 66.

title: Ferraro And Abrams Exchange Complaints
description: As the New York Senate primary race entered its final week yesterday, State Attorney General Robert Abrams tried to raise additional questions about the family finances of Geraldine A. Ferraro, a rival for the Democratic nomination. She responded that they were desperate charges without substance.

title: Stuarts Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
BOEING EXERCISES OPTION ON BOMBARDIER CONTRACT
description: Bombardier Inc. said yesterday that the Boeing Company of Seattle had decided to exercise an option for Bombardier to continue building rear fuselage sections for the Boeing 767 jetliner. Bombardier said the extension was worth about $58 million.

title: Check-Off for Debt Lets Citizens Fight Back
description: To the Editor:

title:
Time for a Test Ban?;
The Road to Real Security
description: Most cold war mantras have been dropped, but one continues to come through loud and clear: so long as the U.S. relies on nuclear weapons for deterrence, we must continue underground testing to insure that our stockpile remains reliable and safe.

title: Home Is Where You Take Your Shirts, Still
description: JAMES R. HAYNES, a writer who admits to a fear of starch, walked into the Tom Yip laundry on the Lower East Side of Manhattan the other day. As usual, he exchanged a heap of dirty button-down cotton shirts for a tidy brown paper bundle of clean ones. And as usual, his end of the conversation with Joe Yip, the owner, ran along these lines: "Hi! . . . How ya doin? . . . Remember no starch . . . See ya."

title: In Twain We Trust
description: Some background on the motto "In God We Trust" may be useful in judging the current debate over the role of the Deity in American party politics. Now imprinted on all our coins and bills, and supplanting "E Pluribus Unum" as the official national motto, "In God We Trust" first appeared on a bronze two-cent piece near the end of the Civil War. It was authorized, in response to public sentiment, by Salmon P. Chase, Abraham Lincoln's Secretary of the Treasury.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Late-Night ABC Talk Show Will Aim at Home Shoppers
description: ABC will experiment with a late-night talk show next month that will bring a home shopping format to network television for the first time, network executives said yesterday.

title: Virus Threat Is Overstated, An I.B.M. Study Concludes
description: The threat of a computer virus infecting tens of thousands of personal computers has been significantly exaggerated, according to a new study by an I.B.M. computer scientist, which was released yesterday.

title: Friends Back Suspect In Beating of Trucker
description: From the stoop of the house where Damian Williams was reared, just a short run from the intersection where he is accused of severely beating a truck driver at the start of the Los Angeles riots, a rhythmic chant rang out: "Free the L.A. Four."

title: A Season for Shooting 'Problem' Geese
description: Like football games and falling leaves, goose hunting is a symbol of autumn in western New York. But this year gunfire was heard even before Labor Day, a result of a special 10-day hunting season aimed at thinning the goose population in three counties.

title: Eating Well
description: FOR the second year in a row, the plum torte recipe is appearing in the Eating Well column. The legion of fans of this simple, homey dessert probably do not care where it turns up, so long as they have it when the purple plums are at their peak. It was 10 years ago that the recipe first appeared in The New York Times.

title: Duties on Chryslers Seen
description: The European Commission is likely to impose import duties of up to 20 percent on Chrysler Corporation cars made in Austria, a commission official said. The decision is expected to be taken at the European Community executive commission's meeting on Wednesday. The Austrian Government has exceeded European Commission limits in giving state subsidies to Chrysler in the production of Voyager mini-vans, the official said.

title: Boom Time for One Industry Amid South Florida's Rubble
description: Benjamin Strunk had no steady job and was getting by "just doing odds and ends, helping out friends" in his hometown of Tazewell, Tenn., when Hurricane Andrew hit southern Florida two weeks ago. One look at pictures of the devastation, and Mr. Strunk knew that if he could get here, he had work for as long as he wanted.

title: When Bell Rings, All Kidding Stops
description: A left turn and there was Hector Camacho, running past the incandescent marquees for which Las Vegas Boulevard is famous: bright lights decreeing sexy shows, cheap buffets and Liza headlining at the Desert Inn.

title: Lots of Rebellion and a Little Hot Sauce For the Spirited Bob Dylan of Brazil
description: "I TALK too much," the songwriter Caetano Veloso warned as he sat down to lunch at the Brazilian Pavilion in midtown on Friday. "Everybody from Bahia is like this. We are always touching each other, too. We are a bit too much."

title: Food Notes
description: Baby Foods With Meat

title: Bank Yields Fall Again For Week
description: Yields of bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit were down sharply in the latest week ended today, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a Florida-based publication.

title: HONDA IS RAISING PRICES 2.5% FOR 1993 ACURA MODELS
description: The American Honda Motor Company's Acura car division said it would increase the prices of its 1993 models an average 2.5 percent, or $582, from similarly equipped 1992 models.

title: Corrections
description: Headlines on Thursday about a Federal antitrust judgment against the Massachusetts Institute of Technology referred imprecisely to the judge's ruling. The case was civil, not criminal; thus there was no finding of guilt.

title: Check-Off for Debt Lets Citizens Fight Back; Georgia on My Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Katherine S. Ginsburg, Doctor, 34
description: Katherine Swan Ginsburg, a doctor at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston and an instructor at the Harvard Medical School, died Friday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. She was 34 years old and lived in Newton Centre, Mass.

title: Books of The Times; Unconventional Houses, by Design and Inclination
description: Frank Lloyd Wright By Meryle Secrest 634 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: ROCKWELL AGREES TO SPACE VENTURE WITH RUSSIANS
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to pursue space ventures with a Russian aerospace company. The Russian concern, NPO Energia, will develop hardware to allow American space shuttle vehicles to dock with Russia's Mir space station. The companies also plan to talk with NASA about using the Russian Soyuz TM spacecraft as a return vehicle for the Space Station Freedom project scheduled for later this decade.

title: Corrections; Fish Soup Recipe
description: The recipe for fish soup with vegetables in the 60-Minute Gourmet column in The Living Section last Wednesday misstated the quantity of potatoes and fish. Here is a corrected version. Fish Soup With Vegetables 2 tablespoons olive oil 1/2 cup finely chopped onions 2 teaspoons finely chopped garlic 1/2 cup finely chopped fennel 1/2 cup coarsely chopped leeks 1 cup carrots diced into 1/4-inch cubes 1/4 teaspoon red pepper flakes 1/2 teaspoon saffron threads or 1 teaspoon ground turmeric 4 sprigs fresh thyme or 2 teaspoons dried 1 bay leaf 1 1/2 cups fresh fish broth or water 1 cup dry white wine 1 cup crushed canned tomatoes Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste 1 cup potatoes diced into 1/4-inch cubes 1 1/4 cups white-fleshed, nonoily fish, like monkfish, tilefish, cod or any combination of them, cut into 1-inch cubes 1/2 pint sea scallops (cut in half crosswise if large) 1/2 cup light or heavy cream 1/4 cup chopped fresh basil or parsley.

title: 2d Baboon Liver Transplant Planned
description: Surgeons at the University of Pittsburgh said today that they planned to proceed with a second liver transplant from a baboon to a human, despite the death of the world's first such recipient from a severe stroke on Sunday.

title: Former East German Agent Denies Charges
description: A senior official of the former East German security police, arrested in Athens on Sunday, denied charges of complicity in murder and terrorism, a Greek official said today.

title: Credit Markets; U.S. Bond Yields Fall to Lowest in Years
description: The bond market rallied sharply again yesterday, continuing the surge set off Friday by the weak employment report and sending some yields to lows not seen in years.

title: Court Allows Damage Lawsuit Over a Disputed Imprisonment
description: A man who spent 19 years in prison in an armored-car murder he apparently did not commit can sue New York City for damages, a Federal appeals panel in Manhattan ruled yesterday.

title: Agassi Set to Battle Courier
description: Grudge match or not, the Andre Agassi-Jim Courier quarterfinal tonight is being billed as the United States Open's legitimate if premature final. Courier holds a 5-4 edge in their rivalry and has won their last four confrontations, two of them at the French Open, which became Courier's launching pad toward a No. 1 ranking and Agassi's Waterloo in the 1991 final.

title: Amtech Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 150,186 from litigation relating to a proxy challenge for control of the board and a charge of $ 146,015 for costs relating to ongoing litigation concerning the company's former president, Marty Simons, who has alleged wrongful termination of his contract. The charge for the Simons litigation included an accrual for the estimated cost to complete the company's defense.

title: Fatal Beating Points Up a System in Crisis
description: Randi Anderson, 5 years old and 3 feet 7 inches tall, scrawled on the walls of her foster home with lipstick. She stole money from her foster mother's purse. She broke all her toys. She hoarded food. She defecated on the floor.

title: Quarterback Is the Least Of Handley's Concerns
description: The sign-wavers and the talk-show phone-callers and other observers of Giants life probably think Ray Handley is coy. It just might be that he is being brutally honest.

title: CHRONICLE
description: One week before she is to be formally installed as the third president of the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York, Dr. FRANCES DEGEN HOROWITZ will pay homage to her predecessor Dr. MINA REES, the first president of the center and an eminent mathematician and computer scientist.

title: Oshman's Sporting Goods reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-Included after-tax LIFO charges of $ 62,000 and $ 123,000, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.c-Net lossd-Included after-tax LIFO charges of $ 87,000 in the quarter and $ 151,000 in the 6 months. The 6 months also included income of $ 1,188,000, or 21 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Geraghty & Miller Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represented gross revenue.

title: Wine Talk
description: SLOWLY, and much too quietly, New York State has become an important producer of serious chardonnay wine. Not California-style chardonnay and not exactly Burgundian, either, but good wine, much of it, and it's high time it got to be better known.

title: Liberty Cup Is Canceled
description: Corporate support of yachting events brings with it a tenuous existence, as organizers of New York's Liberty Cup Match Racing Regatta acknowledged recently. The group, the Harbor Festival Foundation, canceled this year's event at the last minute.

title: Stewart Enterprises Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The shares outstanding reflected the company's initial public offering in October 1991.

title: Topics of The Times; Slopping Swill in the Senate Race
description: Not all the charges that Geraldine Ferraro's rivals for the Democratic Senate nomination from New York have aimed at her are, as she claims, "garbage." But the latest salvos against her from Attorney General Robert Abrams and City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman are surely rubbish. They claim, unfairly and absurdly, that Ms. Ferraro's 1975 prosecution of a woman who performed an illegal abortion on her own daughter indicates a wobbly commitment to abortion rights.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Reports on Repair of Rigs Hurt Prices of Natural Gas
description: Natural gas prices fell sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, after unconfirmed reports over the weekend said that some hurricane damage to oil-and-gas production platforms and pipelines would be repaired faster than expected.

title: Timothy J. Adams, Journalist, 64
description: Timothy J. Adams, a retired journalist, died Sunday at his home in the Chevy Chase section of Washington. He was 64 years old.

title: Lead Levels Force Closing Of a School
description: School officials yesterday ordered a Greenwich Village elementary school closed for the first day of school today after tests by the teachers' union indicated that there were high levels of lead in the dust on the floors.

title: President and Congress Square Off On North American Trade Accord
description: The White House and Congress squared off today on the North American Free Trade Agreement as President Bush released the text of the pact and sent his top trade official to the Senate to begin lobbying for it.

title: Topics of The Times; Fishing for Votes on Saturday
description: Six states and the Virgin Islands held primary elections yesterday. Seven more states will vote next week -- again on Tuesday. Delaware is different. It votes this Saturday.

title: Yount Stirs Crowd but He's One Hit Away
description: He doesn't know most of the names. On the day Robin Yount of the Milwaukee Brewers came within one hit of becoming the 17th major league player to reach 3,000, he sat before his locker and tried to think of the names.

title: Bridge
description: The Vugraph commentators, and 600 spectators, were confused. It was the final of the NEC world team championship, in Salsomaggiore, Italy, last Friday and there was clearly something wrong with the bidding. The giant electronic screen indicated that South had opened one no-trump with seven high-card points and a balanced hand.

title: Gooden Impressive Despite Defeat
description: It is not a glorious fight, the one Dwight Gooden has taken up as the 1992 season gasps to its conclusion. But the minimal goal -- to avoid the first losing season of his life -- has required maximum effort. And now, his record suddenly more a casualty of his club's shortcomings rather than his own, it appears beyond reach.

title:
Real Estate;
Building Gets New Chance In New York
description: AFTER shifting its ownership and clinching the Macmillan/McGraw-Hill School Division as a major new tenant, 10 Union Square East is back in the race for users of Manhattan office space.

title: Chefs International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
EXXON'S MALAY OIL FIND YIELDS 7,400 BARRELS A DAY
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that an oil discovery off the Malay Peninsula had produced about 7,400 barrels a day in tests. The find, about 170 miles off Trengganu in the South China Sea, was the third that Exxon made this year in an area known as Block PM-8. The latest well, known as the Penara-1, was completed on Aug. 6, and found oil at depths between 5,085 feet and 7,700 feet. An appraisal will probably be required to determine the size of the reserves, the company said.

title: Campus Journal; Incoming Students Find Lessons in Reaching Out
description: A new footbridge over the Genesee River makes it a snap to get from the University of Rochester to the city's well-worn southwest corner, otherwise known as the 19th Ward.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALCO STANDARD CORP., Wayne, Pa., acquired Allstate Business Systems, Atlanta. Terms were not disclosed. APPLIED MICROBIOLOGY INC., New York, acquired Aplin & Barrett Ltd., a subsidiary of Burns, Philp & Co.

title: At Ford, a Surprise in the Wings?
description: As the Ford Motor Company gets ready to name a new chief executive, a once-remote prospect, Alexander J. Trotman, has suddenly emerged as the favorite to succeed Harold A. (Red) Poling when the 67-year-old chairman retires next year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10 WAR STORIES OF A SERB

title: Data-Design Labs reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontined operations of $ 296,000, or 4 cents a share, which included provision of $ 4,597,000 for losses expected to be incurred from the disposition of Catel Telecommunications. In the fiscal 1992 second quarter, an additional provision of $ 296,000 was made for this discontinued operation.c-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 6,235,000 and $ 7,478,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, which represented Catel Telecommunications' operating losses, plus establishment of Catel's discontinuance reserve, and extraordinary gains on extinguishment of debt, of $ 4,084,000, or 61 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 4,807,000, or 72 cents a share, for the year.Latest losses from continuing operations of $ 1,189,000 and $ 22,305,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, included provisions for restructuring of $ 2,274,000 in the quarter and $ 13,839,000 in the year from the closing of the company's Anaheim printed circuit board plant and related relocation and debt restructuring charges.Year-ago losses from continuing operations of $ 5,147,000 for the quarter and $ 12,644,000 for the year included gains of $ 2,287,000 in the quarter from the termination of a pension plan, and $ 750,000 in the year, from the termination of the company's defined benefit pension plan. Also included is a gain of $ 990,000 from deferred income taxes of which were eliminated as a result of the decision to terminate the pension plan.

title: Father Charged in Baby's Death
description: An 18-month-old girl who died in upper Manhattan on Monday night was beaten to death by her father, the police said yesterday.

title: After the Storm: Homestead Journal; Gone With the Wind: the Stuff of Everyday Life
description: Is this Nicaragua after the earthquake, Sarajevo during the war or Dade County after the hurricane? Is it Dodge City or Florida City? Is it A.D. or B.C.?

title: SKY-DIVING CRASH LINKED TO ENGINE
description: After a day sifting through the rubble of a plane crash that killed 12 members of a sky diving club near here on Monday, Federal investigators said today that they found evidence of engine trouble.

title: Review/Film; Music Meets Attitude: Lounge Lizards Concert
description: Three-quarters of the way into Garret Linn's engaging concert film, "John Lurie and the Lounge Lizards Live in Berlin," the leader of the nine-member band puts down his alto saxophone to relate a surreal vignette. A man wakes up in a white room that he doesn't recognize, peers in a mirror and decides his lips are so thin that he ought to try collagen treatments. When his wife walks in, he is disappointed to find that she looks so dowdy, but he realizes he loves her, and they both start laughing so hard at a secret joke that they collapse onto the carpet. The man impulsively apologizes to his wife for his meager sexual endowment. She says it's all right, but asks him if it is the reason he has massacred so many people.

title: Chrysler to Move Its Headquarters
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which had previously said it would not move its corporate base from Highland Park, Mich., announced today that it would transfer its headquarters operations to its technology center in Auburn Hills, about 50 miles to the north.

title: Earle Palmer Brown Puts New Emphasis on New York
description: LIKE straphangers elbowing their way into a subway car at rush hour, the executives at Earle Palmer Brown are looking to carve out a larger space in the overcrowded New York market.

title: NEW IRAQI ENVOY APPOINTED AT U.N.
description: President Saddam Hussein is sending an envoy with considerable experience in Washington to represent Iraq at the United Nations, apparently with the daunting task of persuading the United States to ease pressure on Baghdad.

title: Agencies Are Faulted In Tow Crash
description: Despite Christopher Devita's lack of a valid driver's license and his long record of reckless driving, a flawed system failed to keep him off the road.

title: Bowne & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: Reviews/Film; Ruse Serves Artificiality, Elaborately
description: Eleanor Antin, the creator of "The Man Without a World," is a film maker and performance artist who goes to extraordinary lengths to explore artistic issues involving history, identity and authenticity. In the 1970's, she invented an exotic alter ego named Eleanora Antinova, an aging black American ballerina who once danced in Diaghilev's Ballets Russes. Eventually, Ms. Antin published a book that described what it was like to live in the world as a fictional character for whose portrayal she went around New York wearing tan makeup and a gray wig.

title: Chattem Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Pro Bono Accounts
description: * The Art Commission of the City of New York to Cadwell Davis Partners, New York, to promote public awareness of the "Save Outdoor Sculpture" program.

title: To Appreciate Food as the Japanese Do, Begin With Respect
description: THE heart of the Japanese approach to food -- and to life -- can be found in kaiseki, a centuries-old Zen ritual that is gaining appreciation in the United States.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PETE ROSE has weathered some stormy moments during his flamboyant baseball career, notably his banishment from the game for gambling. On Sunday, he had quite a time on the real high seas when he skippered a powerboat to victory in the Miller Offshore Grand Prix off Virginia Beach, Va.

title: Benihana National reports earnings for Qtr to July 19
Market Place; Low-Fat Problem At Ben & Jerry's
description: BEN & JERRY'S is, to say the least, an unconventional corporation. It brags of paying its suppliers more than market prices and of paying its executives less. Its annual report includes a "social performance report" dissecting how well it did in serving its community.

title: FOES OF ISRAEL WIN IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: Lebanese factions dedicated to armed struggle against Israel have won Parliament elections by a landslide in southern Lebanon.

title: Insider Jail Terms Set Aside
description: In what may be the final postcript to the Wall Street securities scandals of the 1980's, a Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday set aside the prison sentences and $155,000 fines of two defendants closely linked to Michael R. Milken's junk bond empire.

title: Carpenter Is Adding To Jet Receiver Riches
description: Ask the Jets' Rob Carpenter what happened to him in Cincinnati and New England last season that caused him to wash out in both places and you're likely to get a puzzled look and a shrug of the shoulders.

title: Church Disowns Fischer
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Connecticut Visit; Clinton Tours Plant to Talk About the Issue: Jobs
description: Gov. Bill Clinton campaigned in Connecticut today, focusing on the need to make American manufacturing more competitive. Whether or not people agreed with his proposals, he was talking about what many wanted to hear: jobs and the economy.

title: Snapper, With Southwestern Zest
description: IN some parts of the country, the field tomatoes are no more. They have been replaced by the boxed variety. You know the kind: the box tastes better than the tomato. When that time of year arrives, it's time to revert to canned tomatoes.

title: Women Turn to Self-Help Groups For Abortions, Despite the Risks
description: Using aquarium tubing, a mayonnaise jar, a drugstore syringe and a dentist's saliva ejector, three of Lucila C.'s friends gave her an abortion last spring.

title: Jacob Bean Is Dead; Curator of Drawings At the Met Was 68
description: Jacob Bean, a connoisseur of Italian and French drawings who was the curator of drawings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 31 years, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Check-Off for Debt Lets Citizens Fight Back; The Word 'God'
description: To the Editor:

title: Cairo Journal; Arab Favorite for Nice Times (and Naughty Ones)
description: The temperature is nearly 100 degrees, the bridges over the Nile are a hopeless tangle of bleating horns and snorting motors, and the yellowish air is thick with dust and diesel fumes and something that smells faintly of donkeys.

title: Judicial Nomination Sunders Old Allies
description: As the Senate prepares to vote Wednesday on the nomination of Edward E. Carnes to be a Federal appeals court judge, some civil rights groups are trying to dispel the perception of a split in their ranks on the nomination, which they say they unequivocally oppose.

title: Sands Regent reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Accounts
description: * Viva International Group, Fairfield, N.J., to Griffin Bacal Inc., New York, to handle the eye-wear company's account, previously at Graf Bertel Dominique, New York. Billings were estimated at $1.5 million.

title: Mandela Mourns Ciskei Dead and Is Criticized Too
description: Nelson Mandela today deplored the killing of more than two dozen supporters of the African National Congress in a protest march against the South African black homeland of Ciskei on Monday, but he found the congress itself accused of bearing some responsibility for the deaths.

title: Electronic Toll-Taking Is Being Put to the Test
description: This week, when motorists line up at toll plazas on the Garden State Parkway in Hillsdale, N.J. and the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in Spring Valley, N.Y., they may notice a privileged few vehicles passing through with barely a pause. But instead of cursing the interlopers, the waiting drivers may want to wave and wish them a pleasant journey.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the new Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the condition and status of the old school building. The former Stuyvesant remains open, housing the High School for Environmental Studies, the Mabel D. Bacon High School, citywide special education classes and adult evening classes.

title: Who Reports What on Iraq: Pentagon Eases Reins a Bit
description: Like trauma victims trying to put a recurring nightmare to rest, the American military and American news organizations have been struggling to overcome the Persian Gulf war's legacy of mutual mistrust as reporters cover the latest military operation here.

title: When the Tool Fits
description: To The Living Section:

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans; Bush Tells Jews That Rival Would Have Harmed Israel
description: Opening a fall campaign to woo Jewish voters, President Bush today told a Jewish gathering that Israel's survival would now be threatened had the United States been led by Gov. Bill Clinton, who "waffled" and "wavered" on whether to confront Iraq.

title: Blue Range Resource reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cowboys Are Back To Their Old Ways
description: It is amazing what one victory during prime time on national television can do for a team's reputation and psyche.

title: Jury Gets N.F.L. Case Today
description: Closing arguments were concluded here today in the National Football League trial over free agency. The eight-woman jury received instructions afterward from United States District Court Judge David Doty and will begin deliberations Wednesday morning.

title: DURR-FILLAUER TO MERGE WITH BERGEN BRUNSWIG
description: Durr-Fillauer Medical Inc. agreed yesterday to merge with the Bergen Brunswig Corporation, one of the nation's largest medical products wholesalers, for $33 a share, or about $470 million. The agreement ends two months of talks and lawsuits between Durr, a regional pharmaceutical and medical products company based in Montgomery, Ala., and Bergen, based in Orange, Calif. Bergen originally offered to acquire Durr for $26 a share, or $365 million, on July 7. Durr's shares gained 37.5 cents in over-the-counter trading yesterday, to $32.975.

title: Heinz (H.J.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Included pretax gain of $ 221.5 million from the sale of Hubinger Co.

title: Check-Off for Debt Lets Citizens Fight Back; Clinton's Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharpton's Sober Plea
description: THE RADIO SCRIPT Announcer: How much is it worth? As much as it cost. It cost the lives of young men and women. It cost the days, months and years spent in jails. It cost beatings by Klansmen and others. It cost a lot to get because it's worth a lot. It? Your vote.

title: Calcium and Health
description: To The Living Section:

title: Check-Off for Debt Lets Citizens Fight Back; Arkansas Successes
description: To the Editor:

title: Florio Vows to Help Newark Fight Car Theft
description: Gov. Jim Florio today pledged that the state would send reinforcements into the battle against car theft here, outlining a plan that includes guaranteed jail sentences for chronic offenders.

title: Hal Riney Wins G.E. Credit Card
description: The GE Capital Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company, said yesterday that Hal Riney & Partners in New York had been selected to handle an initial advertising campaign for the credit card that GE Capital introduced last week. A spokesman for GE Capital in Stamford, Conn., declined to discuss billings or list the finalists considered for the account. Trade publications said that the billings were estimated at $6 million and that the finalists included Ross Roy Advertising in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., whose affiliate, Ross Roy Direct, is handling the card's larger direct- marketing account, and Lintas New York.

title: Players Feeling Uncertain
description: Major league players are peppering their union leaders with questions about lockouts and collusion in light of greater expectations that the Basic Agreement will be reopened a year early and in wake of the owners' ouster of Fay Vincent, a commissioner perceived as conciliatory to labor.

title: Volt Information reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included $ 1,043,000 tax benefit from the Internal Revenue Service's revision of the company's tax liabilities for 1980-88, and partially offset by a $ 263,000 charge for additional taxes applicable to an extraordinary gain taken in the first and second quarters from the retirement of debt.c-Net income and included tax benefit mentioned above; an extraordinary gain of $ 538,000, or 11 cents a share, from the retirement of debt; and a gain of $ 5,099,000, or $ 1.05 a share, from the settlement of litigation.

title: Would-Be Teachers Who Are Being Turned Away
description: As teachers return to schools this week, their ranks still chronically short of the brightest college graduates, of math and science specialists, of minority members and of men, there is mounting evidence that more of these people want to teach but are not being hired.

title: Sabatini Is Surprised As Fernandez Gains Showdown With Seles
description: No wonder Mary Joe Fernandez kissed Gabriela Sabatini on both cheeks after she upset her, 6-2, 1-6, 6-4, in two hours yesterday in the quarterfinals of the United States Open.

title: A Magazine President
description: Donald M. Elliman Jr., a Time Inc. executive for 25 years, was named president and publisher of Sports Illustrated yesterday. Mr. Elliman, 48 years old, is the first person to be named a president at any of the company's New York-based magazines. As publisher, he succeeds Mark Mulvoy, who will continue to be managing editor. Mr. Elliman has been president of the sales and marketing division of Time Inc.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE calendar may proclaim summer nearly over, but dedicated barbecue chefs are a hardy lot, and Labor Day marks little more than two-thirds of the way through the outdoor cooking season.

title: Study of Poor Children Shows a Painful Choice: Heat Over Food
description: Boston City Hospital today released the findings of a three-year study showing that the number of emergency room visits by underweight children increased by 30 percent after the coldest months of the year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Finland's Move Jars Markets
description: A decision by Finland to devalue its currency rippled through the world's financial markets today, setting off yet another surge in the value of the German mark and pushing most European stock prices lower.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Lewis W. Gillenson referred imprecisely to family members. Rochelle Clayman, who survives, was his second wife; his children, Wendy, Amy and Joshua, are from his first marriage.

title: Steinbrenner, Howe and Rose: What Now?
description: The departure of Commissioner Fay Vincent could lead to changes in the status of National League realignment and one or more baseball people. If the executive council, which runs the major leagues in the absence of a commissioner, so desires, it could rescind Vincent's order for the National League to realign and permit George Steinbrenner to return to the Yankees before March 1.

title: Tartabull's Banner Night: 9 R.B.I.
description: If only it were still July. If only tonight's game meant as much to the Yankees as it did to the second-place Orioles. If only Danny Tartabull's sensational offensive display had more impact than merely keeping the Yankees within 14 games of first place.

title: Re-evaluate Animal-Human Transplants
description: To the Editor:

title: T.W.A. Cuts Service, Trying To Emerge From Chapter 11
description: Trans World Airlines announced cutbacks in service yesterday as part of an effort to return to profitability by slimming down and reducing costs.

title: Compaq Deal To Expand Retail Sales
description: In another move to expand its sales to individuals and small businesses, the Compaq Computer Corporation said today that three retailers -- CompUSA, Office Depot and Circuit City Stores -- had agreed to sell its personal computers and other products.

title: Yeltsin Heading for Tokyo and an Unfinished Battle
description: Most countries responded to the collapse of Soviet Communism last year by abandoning years of hostility to support the new Government in Moscow. Japan's response was more complex: the Government insisted that, until a World War II territorial dispute was resolved, Japan would not recognize that anything had really changed in Moscow.

title: Rangers Sign 3 and Bargain With Leetch
description: The Rangers signed three more players yesterday, and continued negotiations for their last big-name holdout, BRIAN LEETCH. General Manager NEIL SMITH completed a two-year deal, terms not disclosed, for goaltender MIKE RICHTER. No details were given on pacts with defenseman JAY WELLS and forward TIE DOMI. Richter's signing means that the Rangers once again will have two top goaltenders, and a competition in the crease, when their camp opens in Glens Falls, N.Y., on Sunday.

title: Judge Ousted From Tobacco Case Over Industry's Complaint of Bias
description: The Federal judge who has been at the center of major liability cases on the risks of smoking for the last decade has been removed from one of those cases by a Federal appeals court, which said that his own words suggested bias against the tobacco industry.

title: 2 Ballet Troupes Discuss Merger
description: The board of American Ballet Theater is to meet today to discuss solutions to the company's financial troubles and its immediate cash-flow problems. One plan that has been under intensive discussion in recent weeks is a merger with the Joffrey Ballet, also financially hard-pressed and with a cash-flow problem. The Joffrey board also meets today to discuss such a merger, a possibility first reported last week in The Washington Post.

title: SIEGE IS RESUMED IN BOSNIAN TOWN
description: Serbian forces that lifted their siege of the Muslim-controlled Bosnian town of Gorazde late last month have returned to the offensive, contending that the withdrawal led to Muslim killings of Serbian civilians.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: WHEN tomatoes are ripe and local -- mostly from my garden -- I press my microwave oven into service in putting up sauce for the cardboard-tomato winter ahead. I love using the microwave, not only because it is cool and quick, but also because I don't risk scorching the sauce as I did when I cooked it endlessly on top of the stove.

title: Quentin N. Burdick, 84, Is Dead; U.S. Senator From North Dakota
description: Quentin N. Burdick, who had represented North Dakota in the United States Senate for the last 32 years, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital in Fargo, his hometown. He was 84 years old.

title: Personal Health
description: EACH year about three million Americans receive a kind of liquid organ transplant when they undergo a blood transfusion. The transfusions, which average two to four units, or pints, of blood per patient, are typically given to replace blood lost as a result of surgery, a hemorrhage or an accidental injury.

title: ESCOBAR SUGGESTS HE MAY SURRENDER
description: Pablo Escobar, the fugitive Colombian cocaine lord who escaped in July from a luxurious prison, has said he will consider surrendering, but warned that any attempt by the United States to abduct him would bring grave consequences.

title: Review/Theater; Pastiche of Columbus, Politics and Puppets, Tinged With Pathos
description: Peter Schumann's Bread and Puppet Theater has never shrunk from taking on issues whose scope more than matches the dimensions of the giant puppet masks and figures that the company commonly uses in its productions. And in "Columbus: The New World Order," the two-and-a-half-hour play that inaugurated the Public Theater's international festival of puppetry on Monday afternoon, the topic is nothing less than Christopher Columbus's voyage to the New World in 1492 and its consequences. With Mr. Schumann being devoutly pacifist and left-wing, the fable that unfolds is a brutal tale of conquest, destruction and oppression that ends with an ambiguous warning.

title: 2 Turkish Fighter Jets Forced Down in Iran
description: Iranian jet bombers forced two Turkish military planes to land in Iran last week "in an attempt to end invading flights from Turkey," according to reports published today.

title: Check-Off for Debt Lets Citizens Fight Back; It's Unconstitutional
description: To the Editor:

title: Wild for Harry, But Not in '48
description: George Bush is campaigning against Congress as Harry S. Truman did. He is promising a come-from-behind victory like the one Harry S. Truman staged in 1948. He invokes the spirit and oratory of Harry S. Truman in almost every speech.

title: Snapple Beverage Picks Kirshenbaum
description: The Snapple Beverage Corporation in Valley Stream, L.I., yesterday named Kirshenbaum & Bond in New York to handle its advertising account, with billings of $15 million. The initial 10 contenders in a five-week-long review had been narrowed to 3: the incumbent, the Marketing Communications Corporation in Essex, Conn., which joined forces with Hal Riney & Partners in New York to make its presentation; Bozell New York, and Kirshenbaum.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKING $7.6 BILLION TO AID HURRICANE VICTIMS
description: President Bush asked Congress today for $7.6 billion to help the victims of Hurricane Andrew, acknowledging that the measure will raise the Federal deficit but declaring that the suffering in Florida and Louisiana outweighed the financial burden.

title: Sharpton's Headache: To Get Out the Vote
description: He barrels across the streets of Bedford-Stuyvesant, past a woman who blows him a kiss, past the girl on a pay phone who abruptly exclaims into the receiver, "I see Al Sharpton." On these nighttime Brooklyn sidewalks where a white face is as rare as an eclipse of the moon, the black preacher passes the street vendors who call, "How you doing, brother? You got my support." Then he enters the Slave Theatre for a meeting of the black faithful who first coalesced around the racially incendiary case of Tawana Brawley.

title: Lead in Schools and Its Perils
description: Lead, the toxic substance that tests detected in dust on the floor of Public School 3 in Manhattan, can be particularly harmful to children because it can impair nervous systems that are still in development.

title: Candidates on Television
description: The candidates for the Democratic Senate nomination in New York have scheduled these television appearances in coming days: Today: 7 P.M., WABC-TV, Channel 7 (and other stations around the state), debate among the four candidates.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball MLB -- Named Bud Selig, Milwaukee Brewers owner, chairman of the executive council. National League

title: 'A Toast to Miss Tully'
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is to celebrate the 90th birthday of its founding chairwoman and patron, Alice Tully, on Monday at 8 P.M. at the hall that bears her name at Lincoln Center. Scheduled to join members of the society for the evening's program, entitled "A Toast to Miss Tully," are the pianists Richard Goode, Andre Previn and Charles Wadsworth; the organist Anthony Newman; the cellist Yo-Yo Ma; the violinist Isaac Stern; the flutist Paula Robison; the tenor Robert White, and the soprano Dawn Upshaw. On the program are works by Bach, Debussy, Godard, Wolf, Mozart and others. Mr. Wadsworth, who was the society's artistic director from its founding in 1969 until 1989, is to be the master of ceremonies. Tickets are $100. Information: (212) 875-5787.

title: 'Brainy Bunch' Begins Anew
description: To those who think Stuyvesant High School students are a brainy but elitist bunch who have been overindulged by New York City's cash-strapped city government, those students have a message:

title: Weary Drivers Praise a Thruway Travel Plaza
description: TO discerning travelers like Frederick Winslow, everything that is wrong with a long road trip can be summed up in these words: highway rest stops. "Gulp-and-gallop places," Mr. Winslow called them, conjuring up images of cramped cafeterias hawking greasy burgers and flat sodas, places with bathrooms whose lack of cleanliness could ruin whatever appetite a traveler had.

title: AMGEN SAYS ARIBITRATOR RULED IN ITS FAVOR, OVER ORTHO
description: Amgen Inc. said the arbitrator in the company's longstanding dispute with the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation had issued an opinion finding Ortho in default of its contractual obligation to develop and register Amgen's hepatitis-B vaccine and interleukin-2 products. The dispute stems from a 1985 technology license agreement between Amgen, a biotech company based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., and Ortho, a unit of Johnson & Johnson, which is based in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: 3 Die in Clash of Iranian Soldiers and Police
description: At least 3 people were killed and 10 wounded on Tuesday when Iranian soldiers and the Teheran police fought over a building in the northern part of the capital, witnesses said today.

title: Democrats Say: One of the Above; New York Senate Primary Leaves Voters Angry but Unsure
description: Anna Jaeger, a registered Democrat who lost her job as a waitress last year, has not decided which of the four United States Senate candidates to vote for in her party's primary next Tuesday. While the most important issues to her are "jobs, jobs, jobs," she is not sure there are any major differences between the candidates on how to create them.

title: Hughes Shifts Missile Work To Arizona From California
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company said today that it would move its missile production and several thousand jobs, including work on the Tomahawk, Stinger, and Standard missiles, from a number of sites in Southern California to a single plant in Tucson, Ariz.

title: Newborn Boy's Body Is Found in Gym Bag
description: A newborn boy was found dead yesterday afternoon in a black gym bag that had been left among some weeds near the eastern edge of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LTV CORP., Dallas, will move its headquarters to Cleveland. McGRAW-HILL INC., New York, bought the Utility Data Institute, a 12-year-old company that compiles and distributes data on construction, production, operation and maintenance costs and other information about electricity. The price was not disclosed.

title: Term Limits Can Only Make Congress Worse; Curbing the President
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Seeks Jews' Backing
description: Addressing the B'nai B'rith convention, Gov. Bill Clinton said the Administration was virtually devoid of Jews in high posts. Page A20.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Bay Area Still Has a Chance
description: Bill White, the National League president, disclosed today that the city of San Francisco still has a chance to keep the Giants. "I will accept an offer from people in San Francisco and then the league will have to decide what to do," White told a news conference after a meeting of league owners. "I would pass it to the ownership committee, and that offer would be compared with the offer from St. Petersburg."

title: Topics of The Times; Food Label Footwork
description: The Congressional mandate for more honest food labels applies only to foods regulated by the Food and Drug Administration. But in a breakthrough a year ago, the Department of Agriculture agreed to harmonize its labeling rules for meat and poultry products with those of the F.D.A.

title: Calendar: Manuscripts, Architecture and Glass
description: Collection Highlights Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street; (212) 685-0008 .

title: David Hyatt, at 76; A Former President Of Interfaith Group
description: David Hyatt, a former president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, died Tuesday at Mount Zion Hospital in San Francisco, his hometown. He was 76 years old.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: REMODELING a house, apartment or condominium before putting it up for sale is not always worth the investment if the home already compares with better-than-average homes in the area.

title: FERRARO FIRES BACK
description: THE TELEVISION SCRIPT

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans; BUSH AGAIN VOWS NO TAX INCREASE
description: Traveling to Pennsylvania and New Jersey suburbs, President Bush renewed his no-new-taxes pledge today, promising he would not raise taxes again, "ever."

title: Mobbed in Milwaukee: Yount Gets No. 3,000
description: Engulfed by a sense of drama that exceeded his expectations and embraced by the frenzied affection of his fans, Robin Yount of the Milwaukee Brewers tonight became the 17th player in major league history to reach 3,000 hits.

title: It Seems Like Solitaire As Sampras Breezes
description: He called it the case of the missing opponent, and amateur sleuth Pete Sampras later said it was a pleasant problem that every athlete ought to face once or twice in the turbulent course of chasing the Grand Slam grail.

title: Georgia Hospital's Tax-Exempt Issue
description: A $139.6 million tax-exempt financing by the Fulco Hospital Authority of Georgia was priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 6.55 percent for a certificate due in 2022 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch.

title: The President and Topic A
description: The economy remains overwhelmingly the most important issue in the election campaign, yet President Bush has ducked it. Today he has the chance -- perhaps his last -- to propose a credible plan for recovery.

title: Estonia Is Reasonable On Citizenship Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; A Smoking Gun?
description: Did the Bush Administration, eager to build up Saddam Hussein, interfere in the Atlanta U.S. Attorney's investigation of Iraq's corruption of our Department of Agriculture? Has the Attorney General committed an impeachable offense in refusing to permit a special prosecutor to investigate obstruction of justice, as Congress requested?

title: Sports of The Times; The Capping of Baseball's Popularity
description: IT is not even necessary to get inside the head of the average American kid to know that baseball is facing a humbling, if not apocalyptic, decline in the 21st century. Just look at what these kids are wearing on top of their heads.

title: Spassky Defeats a Vacillating Fischer in Game 5
description: A fired-up Boris Spassky convincingly defeated an indecisive Bobby Fischer yesterday in Game 5 of their exhibition match in Sveti Stevan, Yugoslavia. Spassky's victory, his second in a row, gives him a 2-to-1 lead; the first player to achieve 10 victories wins the match.

title: OLYMPIA IS SAID TO PLAN TO SEEK BANKRUPTCY EXTENSION
description: A lawyer for some of Olympia & York Developments Ltd.'s bondholders said the developer was planning to ask for an extension of its bankruptcy protection until Dec. 30. Olympia & York is expected to ask an Ontario court tomorrow to allow it to file its final restructuring plan on Oct. 27. Olympia is currently scheduled to emerge from bankruptcy protection on Oct. 21. The hearing "should be lively," the lawyer said.

title: Only Uncertainty Is Certain in French Vote
description: After two weeks in which the "no" surged, the "yes" rebounded and the "no" inched back, polls tracing French voting intentions in a referendum on Europe this month have so far produced only one certainty: the outcome will be up in the air until the votes are counted.

title: This Fall, the Barely Adult Set Is the Object of Network Desire
description: In the 1992-93 season, network television will enter a new age. The age is about 22.

title: Polls Don't Lie. People Do.
description: Recent polls have produced drastically different results. In surveys taken between Aug. 26 and Aug. 31, the gap separating Bill Clinton and George Bush ranged from 19 points in a Washington Post/ ABC News poll to 5 points in a Louis Harris poll.

title: Donald M. Sterzin Adman, 42
description: Donald M. Sterzin, creative director of Carlson & Partners Advertising, died on Aug. 30 at New York Hospital. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Judge Denies Bid to Close In-School TV Program
description: A California judge said today that he would not shut down the San Jose operation of Channel One, although he imposed new restrictions to make clear that neither teachers nor students can be forced to watch the the controversial in-school news and entertainment program.

title: Cable Bill Agreement Is Reached
description: In a big step toward reregulation of the cable television industry, House and Senatenegotiators agreed today on a measure that would require local cable systems to negotiate licenses from local broadcast stations to retransmit their signals.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg Business News in the Company News column of Business Day on Saturday about Orion Pictures' quarterly loss misattributed two films. "Driving Miss Daisy" and "Rain Man" were not produced by Orion.

title: Biggest Sale By America's Top Hatter
description: Would-be Harrison Fords have worn his Indiana Jones fedoras. And legions of young people have slipped on all manner of his baseball caps to identify with the cachet of their favorite sports teams. But Irving Joel, who in three decades has built the country's largest designer, manufacturer and marketer of headwear, made by far his biggest sale this week.

title: Lachance Keeps Tabs on Two New Prospects
description: As a member of the United States Olympic team last winter, defenseman Scott Lachance doubled, unofficially, as a scout. Back with the Islanders for his first full season, Lachance has mental files on two potential teammates, Vladimir Malakhov and Darius Kasparaitis.

title: Term Limits Can Only Make Congress Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dangerous Delusion About AIDS
description: The disbelief and denial felt by people who have learned they have a grave illness should gradually give way to acceptance of the reality of the diagnosis. This transition is essential to establish an effective partnership between patient and physician as they decide on appropriate treatment. At the same time, the disbelief and denial are almost always coupled with deep anger at the unjustness and capriciousness of illness.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Timothy Egan Lenahan misstated the date of his death. It was Monday.

title: Economic Scene; Safer Mousetraps, Or Better Ones?
description: IS Congress, stung by White House charges that it is a doormat for special interests, ready to take a whack at what many consider the toughest of Washington lobbies -- the nation's trial lawyers?

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Newspaper Ashes

title: Connecticut Prices Serial-Bond Issue
description: Connecticut yesterday sold $216.8 million of general-obligation tax-exempt bonds tentatively priced through the First Boston Corporation to yield a maximum of 6 percent for bonds due in 2008 and 2009 .

title: As Students Return, Districts Face Similar Ills
description: Youngsters in the New York City region returned to class yesterday, more absorbed by the first day of a new school year than by the widespread absence of teacher contracts and no-frills budgets that reflect sour economic times.

title: Scotch and Soda, and a Couple of Cubes
description: GLASS can be made into many shapes: round, oval, square or rectangular. And from 1928 to 1932, Reuben Haley, a glass designer at the Consolidated Lamp & Glass Company in Coraopolis, Pa., designed cubistic glassware.

title: Storm's Staggering Load on Banks
description: The rebuilding of the southern Florida economy after Hurricane Andrew may require billions of dollars more in financing than the amount covered by insurance and even the new aid proposed by President Bush.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Jersey Visit; Bush Finds Fertile Ground for Attacking Governors
description: President Bush today opened a second front in his campaign against what he called tax-and-spend liberals when he attacked Gov. Bill Clinton by way of Gov. Jim Florio.

title: Effort by Iran to Arm Bosnians Is Reported
description: In the first documented evidence of military support by an Islamic country for the predominantly Muslim Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a planeload of Iranian guns, ammunition and military personnel has been intercepted in Croatia, Western officials said.

title: Tax-Exempt Yields Rise; Taxables Decline
description: Yields offered by money market funds were mixed in the latest week as the supply of municipal debt remained heavy and the money markets reflected the cautious easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve on Friday.

title: Thompson Tries Talking Way Into Job
description: The kid is full of superstitions and energy. His rap is a crazy, personal patois of slang and literate metaphor. He is asked a single question and he offers oral history by way of response.

title: Plan Set in Northwest-KLM Link
description: Northwest and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines asked yesterday for United States Government permission to become the first two large international carriers to combine their operations and, in effect, operate as one airline.

title: INSIDE
description: New House-Bank Chapter

title: Zaccaro Scarce on Campaign Trail
description: Wheeeere's Johnny? This may be the Year of the Woman, but for the two women seeking the Democratic nomination for United States Senate from New York, it's not the Year of the Spouse. Elizabeth Holtzman does not have one. And Geraldine Ferraro's husband, John A. Zaccaro, shuns publicity, although during his wife's campaigns it has usually managed to find him.

title: Orioles Find Yanks Are Hardly A Pushover
description: It could have been a series where the Yankees snoozed through three straight games and watched the Orioles chase the Toronto Blue Jays. They could have muttered excuses and claimed there was nothing redeeming to play for.

title: Warner-Lambert Offers 6.66% Yield
description: Warner-Lambert offered $200 million of 10-year notes yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Irving Allen Lee, Actor And Director, 43, Dies
description: Irving Allen Lee, a Broadway and television actor and director, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 43 years old.

title: A Lot More Than Dust Can Stay Under the Bed
description: Bob and Lois Anderson want to help all those people whose closets look like Fibber McGee's, or in the case of New Yorkers, whose entire apartments seem to be the size of a closet. Mr. Anderson has invented the Bedroom Organizer, a bed frame that can hold an ironing board, skis, a broom or even a ladder, depending on the size of the bed.

title: Selig Goes In for Vincent at First
description: Peace broke out among baseball owners today, at least in the major leagues' executive council.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about management changes at Saks Fifth Avenue described Investcorp S.A. incorrectly. It owns a minority stake in Saks and represents Persian Gulf investors who collectively have a controlling interest. It is not a subsidiary of the Arabian Investment Banking Corporation.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Health Care Policy; Administration Accuses Democrats of Blocking Bush's Health Plan
description: The Bush Administration complained today that House Democrats had blocked action on President Bush's proposal to guarantee health insurance coverage for virtually all Americans, even as Administration officials accused Gov. Bill Clinton of equivocating on health-care policy.

title: Events: Plant Auction, Children's Harvest Fairs
description: Fair, Tours, Open House Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; (718) 622-4433.

title: Four Singular Views: Shops That Sell the Different Drums; Juxtaposing Old and New
description: THE small building that sits squarely on the green in the center of Bedford, N.Y., looks as if it was built in 1840, in the style John Montague Massengale calls "Provincial Greek Revival."

title: Many Questions Remain on Trump's Shortened West Side Story
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Congress; BUDGET JOUSTING HAS POLITICAL RING
description: Those Congressional big spenders President Bush has been attacking, sometimes by name, were a bit puzzled to be asked down to the White House on Tuesday for a drink and some amiable chitchat.

title: Lloyd's of London Names a New Chief
description: Lloyd's of London, the troubled insurance market whose sizable losses have raised questions about its management structure, today named Peter Middleton as its chief executive, succeeding Alan Lord, who is retiring at age 63.

title: Fox to Preview New PBS Children's Series
description: In a unusual cross-promotion that recalls the premiere of "Sesame Street" 24 years ago, a new public television series called "Ghostwriter" will be broadcast as a sneak preview on the Fox network one day before it begins on PBS stations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: President Bush has nominated STEVEN J. McAULIFFE to be a Federal judge; he is the husband of Christa McAuliffe, the schoolteacher who died in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger. .

title: Striking Midnight, All Day and All Night
description: IT is always midnight at John Badum's apartment. Except for the master bedroom, where it is almost too bright to sleep.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo; G.O.P. Looks at Clinton Draft Record and Spies Willie Horton
description: Have the Republicans found their furlough issue for 1992?

title: A New Stove With the Sign of the Wolf
description: FOR 60 years, the Wolf Range Company of Compton, Calif., has produced commercial ranges, signing each oven with a bright red wolf's face on the door.

title: Review/Jazz; Javon Jackson, in Good Company
description: Javon Jackson, a 27-year-old tenor saxophonist who grew up in Denver and was a member of Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers, has superb company for his first Village Vanguard date as a leader. His quartet on Tuesday night included Kenny Barron on piano and the agile rhythm section of Ron Carter on bass and Lewis Nash on drums, with the trombonist Curtis Fuller scheduled to make it a quintet tomorrow through Sunday at the Vanguard (178 Seventh Avenue South, at Perry Street, Greenwich Village). But in Tuesday's second set, Mr. Jackson was not in the same league as his associates.

title: A Good Time Was Had
description: To The Home Section:

title: Hallowell Davis, 96, an Explorer Who Charted the Inner Ear, Dies
description: Dr. Hallowell Davis, a pioneer in the physiology of hearing and a former director of research at the Central Institute for the Deaf in St. Louis, died on Aug. 22 at the Bethesda Dalworth Home in St. Louis. He was 96 years old and until recently had lived in University City, Mo.

title: William Barrett, 78, a Professor And Interpreter of Existentialism
description: William Barrett, one of the foremost American interpreters of the philosophy of existentialism and a leading chronicler of the post-World War II generation of New York intellectuals, died on Tuesday at the Tarrytown Hall Nursing Home in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

title: Pacific Bell Sells 40-Year Bonds
description: Pacific Bell, a unit of Pacific Telesis Group, offered $300 million of 40-year bonds yesterday through Merrill Lynch & Company, which was awarded the issue in competitive bidding yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS: New Owens-Corning Logotype; This Change Is Purely Symbolic
description: Some 25 years after settling on an "interim" logo, the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation has gotten around to choosing a replacement.

title: Florida Freezes Insurer's Rates in Warning
description: Florida's insurance commissioner took the unusual action yesterday of freezing the rates and premiums charged by one of the nation's largest insurance companies, the American International Group.

title: Washington Chief Joins A Trend of Frustration
description: Three years after taking command of the police force in the most heavily policed and most murder-prone city in the United States, Isaac Fulwood Jr. joins the fast-growing number of big-city police chiefs who have left their jobs in the past year.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column and a picture caption yesterday, about alternatives to regular blood transfusions, misidentified a blood bank. It was the New York Blood Center, not the New York Blood Bank.

title: Waterford Journal; The Future of Irish Crystal Is Anything but Clear
description: In the year 853, Danish Vikings sailed up the river here and, after some battling with with the local Celts, established a port. Some 1,100 years later, after World War II, an Irish entrepreneur imported a band of German, Czech and Italian craftsmen to revive the local glassmaking business, which became Waterford Crystal and quickly spread its glistering elegance to millions of homes, mostly in America, and bringing prosperity.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: A FEW crayons from a kindergarten classroom find their way into your daughter's lunch box. A friend's toy mysteriously migrates to your son's collection. Your teen-ager takes a "five-finger discount" on some makeup or clothing from a store.

title: Term Limits Can Only Make Congress Worse; Keeping in Touch
description: To the Editor:

title: Prints of Published Photographs
