description: HE'S not an obvious pin-up. But a black-and-white image of Albert Einstein is a hot seller at FPG International, a photography archive in Manhattan.

title: Chavez Has Pounded His Way to the Top
description: His older brothers were fighters of ordinary talent. When they would lose, little Julio Cesar Chavez of Culiacan, Mexico, would tell them that some day he would do better and become a world champion.

title: Whatever His Title, Selig's in the Hot Seat
description: Several days ago, Jerry Reinsdorf, the most powerful and influential owner in major league baseball, declared Bud Selig to be the most powerful and influential owner in major league baseball.

title: Home Video
description: Television movies are often disregarded by video dealers, but occasionally one comes along that can sit alongside the better feature films. A recent example is "The Green Man," based on a novel by Kingsley Amis and starring Albert Finney as a boozy, womanizing innkeeper whose establishment near Cambridge, England, is overrun by ghosts.

title: IRAN SAID TO SEND ARMS TO BOSNIANS
description: In the first documented evidence of military support by an Islamic country to the Muslim-dominated Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatian officials have intercepted a planeload of Iranian arms and personnel, Western officials said today.

title: Review/Music; From Mal Waldron, Jazz Without Pity
description: Mal Waldron plunged into the depths for his first set on Tuesday night at Sweet Basil. In an intense and single-minded group of pieces, each extending more than 20 minutes, Mr. Waldron prowled the low register of the piano, spending long stretches below middle C and keeping his two tenor saxophonists, Chico Freeman and Ricky Ford, in their most sepulchral register for ensembles. The music glowered, rumbled, ruminated, alluding to the darkest blues, turning torchy ardor into a self-mockery. One piece was a blues turned into a chromatic maze, another was a Chopinesque ballad, the finale the modal vamp of "The Git Go." The tempos were slower than a dreamer's heartbeat, the motion as inexorable as the tides. It was jazz without doubt or pity, desolation turned sensual.

title: Clinton: Getting People Off Welfare
description: The Clinton campaign yesterday began broadcasting its second commercial since the Republican National Convention. The campaign said it purchased $1 million of broadcast time in 10 states for the 30-second advertisement, but it refused to name the states. It said about a third of the money would be spent in the South. ON THE SCREEN Opens with these words against plain background: "The Clinton Plan. Welfare to Work." Switches to image of Gov. Bill Clinton in a jacket and tie leaning on his office desk. As Mr. Clinton discusses welfare, the camera zooms in for a close-up, and these lines appear on the screen: "End welfare as we know it," "Provide education, training and child care," and "Those who are able must go to work."

title: Eleanor Raynolds, Business Consultant And an Author, 55
description: Eleanor H. Raynolds, an executive search consultant who was honored by the Queen of England for her work for the British-American Chamber of Commerce, died on Tuesday at Stamford Hospital in Connecticut. She was 55 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: Democracy vs. Dictator in Apartheid 'Homeland'
description: The make-believe country of Ciskei has a shiny "international" airport capable of landing a Boeing 747, in case one ever attempts to visit this curious figment of apartheid.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 2 about changes in medical school curriculums referred incorrectly to an associate dean of the medical school at Emory University in Atlanta. He is Dr. Jonas A. Shulman.

title: When Pain Is an Intruder at the Table
description: FOR elderly, arthritic or handicapped people, some objects can make eating and drinking easier.

title: 8 Jurors Start Weighing Evidence in N.F.L. Case
description: The eight-woman jury deciding the National Football League's battle over free agency with its players began deliberations at 9 A.M. today and worked for nearly eight hours without reaching a decision before adjourning for the night. The jurors will resume at 9 A.M. on Thursday.

title: Graf Is Left Baffled; Young Maleeva Falls
description: Nerves were the headliners in both of the women's quarterfinal matches yesterday at the United States Open, and in the case of a publicly miserable Steffi Graf, the nerves won and cost her a chance to become No. 1.

title: Executive Changes
description: ADVACARE INC., Horsham, Pa., which provides accounts-receivable management services to physicians and hospitals, named William Joe Davis 3d president and chief executive. COCENSYS INC., Irvine, Calif., a biopharmaceutical company, appointed David A. H. Lee, M.D., executive vice president of research and development.

title: Nobody's Collecting a Social Security Bonanza
description: To the Editor:

title: Polls Continue To Vary
description: Five recent nationwide polls show a continuation of the variability seen in surveys taken since the Republican National Convention was held in mid-August.

title: Trade Pact Is Criticized By Gephardt
description: Dealing a blow to Congressional prospects for the North American Free Trade Agreement, the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, said today that the labor and environmental provisions were so badly flawed that the pact should be renegotiated.

title: Willing Suspension
description: NAOMI KOBRIN, a 27-year-old interior designer, always liked the soothing, rhythmic feeling of dozing off in a swaying hammock. Two years ago, she moved into a 2,400-square-foot loft in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, where machinery to produce corrugated paper had once been made.

title: Mentally Ill Jailed on No Charges, Survey Says
description: A survey of American jails has found that more than half regularly hold people with serious mental disorders on trivial charges or no charges at all.

title: Angry U.N. General Says Bosnia Attacked Convoy
description: The commander of the United Nations peace force in Sarajevo charged today that Muslim militiamen had deliberately attacked a United Nations supply convoy on the city's western fringe Tuesday night, killing two French officers and wounding five.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SALMAN RUSHDIE, the British author who has lived in hiding since 1989, said yesterday at the University of Colorado in Boulder that he intends to be increasingly visible, in the hopes that public pressure on the Iranian Government will lead it to lift the death threat under which he lives. The Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called for his assassination after Mr. Rushdie's book "The Satanic Verses" was deemed to be blasphemous according to Islam.

title: Jackson Shifts Focus to a Good Cause
description: For Mark Jackson, last night's Wheelchair Classic at Madison Square Garden was another precious evening on the town, with the taxi meter running.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY A DECISION IN FATAL SHOOTING

title: C.I.A. Chief to Visit Moscow; Cooperation May Be a Topic
description: Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, will visit Moscow this fall to discuss, among other issues, potential cooperation with Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service, senior Administration officials said today.

title: State Acquires Landmark Theater To Salvage While It Still Can
description: The New Amsterdam Theater, the badly tarnished crown jewel in a string of historic playhouses along 42d Street, has been taken over from the Nederlander Organization by New York State, in the hope of salvaging the building while there is still so much left to salvage.

title: Letters Lift House Bank Cloud From Some Lawmakers
description: Federal agents swept across Capitol Hill today hand-delivering the first of hundreds of letters clearing lawmakers who wrote overdrafts at the House bank, but leaving others not knowing when or whether the cloud over their careers would be lifted.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about fighting around the Bosnian city of Gorazde included scrambled passages. Readers wishing a corrected version of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Head of SUNY at Purchase to Retire in June
description: Dr. Sheldon N. Grebstein, who has headed the State University campus here during a decade of budget cuts, announced today that he would retire as president in July.

title: Bridge
description: The clubs that provide duplicate bridge in New York City fall into four categories. Some are major operations, providing for all comers throughout the week. Others are also open clubs, but operate once or twice a week. A few are private clubs with permanent premises and a variety of services. And one, perhaps only one, is a private club offering a weekly game.

title: Embargoed Haiti's Suffering Increases
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: "I went along with one Democratic tax increase and I'm not going to do it again. Ever. Ever." PRESIDENT BUSH. [ A1:5. ]

title: Jets' Plan of Action: To Reinstate the Run
description: The Jets' rushing attack was sidetracked last week when the Atlanta Falcons went up by 17-0 in the first quarter.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EVELYN LAUDER has received compliments on the photographs that have embellished her Christmas cards for the last 10 years or so. "Sometimes people even notice that they are my photographs," said Mrs. Lauder, who is senior corporate vice president of the Estee Lauder cosmetics company, as she prepared to show her photographs on a grander scale.

title: Four Singular Views: Shops That Sell the Different Drums; Creating Modern Heirlooms
description: "THE normal route is not for me," said June Goldfinger, whose Katonah General Store is certainly not run-of-the-mill.The recently opened store in upper Westchester is a mini-emporium of high design, all in understated hues of beige and white.

title: A Boy Back From the Brink: When Love and Care Prevail
description: When the 5-year-old foster child first walked into Debra Bondy's psychotherapy office, she noticed that his front teeth were missing (knocked out by his mother, it turned out). The beautiful, dark-eyed boy did not know how to play. He sat very still, clutching a toy ambulance and making a wailing, siren noise: "Lee-loo, lee-loo, lee-loo."

title: In This Lodge, Collector Meets Minimalist
description: WHEN Mary Mhoon, a landscape photographer, saw an ad in the local paper here that read, "Hunting lodge for sale in midtown," she knew right away that she wanted the place. Although she lived in the same area of town, she had never seen Redwood Lodge before. Built in 1917, it was part of a famous local estate, whose marble mansion half a mile away is now the Pink Palace Museum and Planetarium. In the meantime, a residential neighborhood of comfortable houses and tree-lined streets had grown up around the lodge, concealing its rustic origins.

title: As Promised, Florio Vetoes a Bill Permitting Assault Weapons
description: After stumping the state for more than a month to build public support for his position, Gov. Jim Florio today made good on his promise to veto a bill that would effectively repeal the state's two-year-old ban on the sale and possession of semiautomatic assault firearms.

title: Courier Refuses to Crack, Banishing Agassi to Defeat
description: It was well past midnight when the resident strongman, who later fell prey to a case of post-match cramps, finally fended off this Grand Slam's unofficial Zen master, who remained glib in defeat.

title: A Wasted Opportunity
description: To The Home Section:

title: Storm Blows a New Hero Into Town
description: With a high-pitched voice and eyes that blink too often, a degree in mathematics and a keen interest in isobars, Bryan Norcross hardly seems a candidate for public adulation.

title: Amex Is Investigating Link Between Officer and Investor
description: Once seen as an idea that would signal the revival of the American Stock Exchange, the five-month-old Emerging Company Marketplace has instead led to new questions about the actions taken at the senior levels of the exchange.

title: Banking Dept. Proposes Changes in Rating Rules
description: In a fresh effort to pressure lenders to provide more loans and services in poor areas, the New York State Banking Department yesterday proposed new rules that it said would strengthen a controversial law that ranks lenders on the basis of their social responsibility.

title: History of Commissioners Mimics Itself
description: The appointment of Bud Selig of the Milwaukee Brewers as a temporary holder of the commissioner's functions, is a new procedure for major league baseball. But it echoes earlier situations.

title: Officials Form Elaborate Plan To Keep Peace
description: Ted Finkelstein and Fritz Sanchez, officials with New York City's Commission on Human Rights, tooled through Washington Heights yesterday afternoon looking for trouble but finding none. They were worried that reports of a grand jury not indicting the police officer who killed a Dominican immigrant during a struggle last July would touch off anger and violence.

title: When Storm Got Tough, the Women Got Tougher
description: Surrounded by sugar cane fields that seem to isolate them like green oceans, the people of this poor overwhelmingly black hamlet have been surviving without electricity, insurance adjustors, the National Guard or Federal aid since Hurricane Andrew struck Louisiana. Yet the women who live here have already started rebuilding.

title: Court Nominee Is Confirmed After Angry Senate Debate
description: After two days of angry debate in which election-year politics were never far from the surface, the Senate today confirmed Edward E. Carnes, an Alabama prosecutor, to an important Federal appeals judgeship.

title: China Threatens U.S. With Trade Reprisals
description: In yet another jolt to strained Chinese-American relations, the Government-controlled press agency said today that China was prepared to retaliate with punitive tariffs if the United States carried out a threat to restrict the import of Chinese-made goods.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column in some editions of Business Day on Saturday about the acquisition of Sunrise Bancorp by PNC Financial described one company incorrectly and misstated the other's location. PNC Financial is a bank holding company, and Sunrise is based in Fort Mitchell, Ky.

title: Judge Says Minister Can't Block Censorship Film
description: A coalition of film makers and civil rights advocates has won the right to distribute a British documentary about censorship in the arts in the United States over the objections of an anti-pornography crusader who was interviewed in the film.

title: Market Place; Growth Is Harder For Safety-Kleen
description: WHEN the Safety-Kleen Corporation disclosed on Aug. 5 that it was guilty of large-scale permit violations in its storage of liquid hazardous wastes in Puerto Rico, investors hammered its stock. Shares ended the day down $3, to $27.625, on the Big Board as Wall Street worried about the potential for fines and cleanup costs.

title: CAR DEALER ADMITS FRAUD OF BILLIONS
description: John McNamara, the Long Island car dealer and philanthropist, admitted yesterday that he had bilked General Motors in a $6 billion loan scheme and that he had used some of the money to bribe officials at all levels in the town of Brookhaven to win approvals for his vast real-estate developments.

title: Text of Letter to Representatives
description: Following is the letter sent today to some members of the House of Representatives by Malcolm R. Wilkey, the special Justice Department prosecutor investigating the House bank scandal. It was released by the Justice Department.

title: Four Singular Views: Shops That Sell the Different Drums; . . . And Whimsy Next Door
description: ACCORDING to Stella Flame, for years her husband, Michael Somers, a New York bond trader, "ran to yard sales like a nut." Now Mr. Somers has a place to trade it all off: Wild Ivy, a small shop located in a nicely ramshackle maroon barn just off Route 27 in Bridgehampton, L.I. Mr. Somers is the owner. His wife is the manager and buyer.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Big Shifts Are Announced By Saatchi and Euro RSCG
description: THE global advertising industry continues to reshape itself.

title: G.M.'s Bold Move Into Credit Cards
description: The credit card introduced yesterday by the General Motors Corporation brandishes a long list of features that make it, some industry analysts say, the most important new national card since A.T.& T. introduced its Universal card in March 1990.

title: In Senate Race, Debate Comes at a Crucial Time
description: Just five days before the New York Democratic primary for the Senate, the strategies of all the candidates revolve around Geraldine A. Ferraro. For her rivals, the question is how to beat her. For Ms. Ferraro, the trick is to hold onto every ounce of support that has made her the leader in the polls so far.

title: Comedy Troupe Makes It Up As It Goes
description: Campaign '92 is shaping up nicely for Chicago City Limits, the improvisational comedy group that has been based in New York City for the last decade.

title: School Tainted With Lead Dust Is Expected to Reopen Monday
description: An elementary school in Greenwich Village that was closed yesterday after lead was found in dust on the floors will remain closed the rest of the week while a cleanup crew scours every surface in the building -- every wall, ledge, radiator and book, officials said.

title: All the Prints in Newsstands That Fit
description: GREEN newsstands, the plain flat-roofed kind that dot the New York landscape, may someday become obsolete.

title: Kohl, His Support Sagging, Admits Unification Errors
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl acknowledged today that he had mishandled some aspects of German unification.

title: For Assembly: Manhattan, Queens
description: Because of redistricting, New York voters will face an unusually large number of Democratic primary contests for the State Assembly on Tuesday. Here are our recommendations for Manhattan and Queens races in which the primary winner is all but guaranteed election in November. MANHATTAN.

title: On First Day For Schools, Many Lessons
description: New York City's schools opened their doors yesterday in a spirit of giddiness and dread, with six brand-new schools and 2,000 eager new teachers confronting a stagnant budget, labor turmoil and an enrollment that has swollen ominously to almost one million.

title: Four Singular Views: Shops That Sell the Different Drums; A Most Elegant Barn . . .
description: THE back of a barn is not exactly where one would expect to find antique Spode platters ($1,800 each), a series of Greek icons painted in 1933 ($1,400 each) as well as a silver chandelier (sold). But the incongruous setting is part of the charm of Amy Perlin Antiques.

title: Absolut Steps Up Efforts in Europe
description: Absolut vodka and its agency, TBWA Advertising in New York, have announced plans to introduce their first coordinated advertising and marketing efforts in Europe, to begin by the end of the month.

title: Warning From France On U.S. Wheat Subsidy
description: France, which has long defended the European Community's system of generous farm subsidies, warned today that President Bush's recent decision to increase subsidies for American wheat exports posed a new threat to stalled international trade talks.

title: Topics of The Times; Justice Beclouded
description: When Judge Lee Sarokin of U.S. District Court in New Jersey issued a key ruling against tobacco manufacturers in February, he began with a thorough denunciation of the industry. He declared that "despite some rising pretenders, the tobacco industry may be the king of concealment and disinformation."

title: R. T. Wellington Jr.; Wine Expert Was 39
description: Raymond Thomas Wellington Jr., an authority on wines who played a major role in food and wine education in New York City and beyond, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 39 years old.

title: C.I.A. Is Planning to Unlock Many Long-Secret Nazi Files
description: In a change of policy that could provide new information about American recruitment of Nazi war criminals after World War II, the Central Intelligence Agency says it has begun to systematically search its records with the aim of opening long-secret files to historians' scrutiny.

title: Rabin Implies He'd Return Some of Golan to Syria
description: Responding to legislators' criticism of his conduct of Middle East peace negotiations, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin strongly suggested today that Israel is willing to return at least part of the Golan Heights to Syria for peace with that country.

title: Books of The Times; Name-Dropping and Star-Gazing Among the Best
description: Dangerous Friends At Large With Huston and Hemingway in the 50's By Peter Viertel 406 pages. Doubleday. $24.50.

title: Four Singular Points Of View
description: AT least in principle, shopping outside New York City implies a more leisurely pace. But the intensity of purpose and single-mindedness of four new shops on Long Island and in Westchester County are anything but laid-back. It is the enthusiasm of their owners that makes them particularly appealing, even to the most jaded furniture and accessories buyer. Salesmanship is often mixed with philosophy, and after 10 minutes, these shopkeepers may feel like old friends.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF WITH: Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme; After 35 Years, Their Act Is Here to Stay
description: BY 11:30 P.M., Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme are stepping quickly into their dressing room at the Desert Inn, exhausted and exhilarated. The 85-minute show in the tiered, chandeliered Crystal Room has earned a standing ovation from the packed crowd, and a woman has rushed forward to hand Eydie a rose.

title: One More Point of Light
description: O Christmas Bush,O Christmas Bush, How glorious is your gifting!How rapidly it dissipatesThe doubts of disaffected states,That have of late been drifting.A million here,A billion there Has been a cinch to wheedle.It sets your whole campaign to rightsAnd drapes your green-backed boughs with lights, While Clinton gets the needle.

title: Fujitsu Says Its Computer Will Be the World's Fastest
description: Fujitsu Ltd. provided details today of its first parallel supercomputer and said it would be the world's fastest computer when shipments began in September 1993.

title: Yeltsin Cancels a Visit to Japan As Dispute Over Islands Simmers
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin abruptly put off a visit to Japan today, only four days before he was scheduled to leave, after negotiations throughout the summer failed to resolve a bitter territorial dispute that has haunted Moscow-Tokyo relations since World War II.

title: NEW YORK OFFICER SAID TO BE CLEARED IN FATAL SHOOTING
description: A Manhattan grand jury has cleared a New York City police officer in the fatal shooting of a drug suspect whose death in July touched off several days of violent demonstrations in Washington Heights, a top official in the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Handley Pulls Reverse and Stays With Simms
description: And you thought the Giants quarterback controversy was over? You knew Phil Simms started last Sunday because Jeff Hostetler was hurt, but you also knew Hostetler would regain the starting job this Sunday against the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Washington State Refinances Debt
description: A $203.4 million refunding by the State of Washington was tentatively priced yesterday for sale to the public.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 YELTSIN POSTPONES JAPAN VISIT

title: N.F.L. to Name Namath as Pitchman
description: NFL Properties in New York, the licensing, marketing and publishing unit of the National Football League, is expected to announce today that Joe Namath has signed a 10-year contract to become the league's first corporate spokesman ever.

title: CHEVRON TO RESUME ANTITRUST SUIT AGAINST PENNZOIL
description: The Chevron Corporation said it would proceed with its antitrust lawsuit against the Pennzoil Company, after an appellate court reinstated its claim. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, overturned a lower court and said Chevron could proceed with its suit. The lawsuit charges that Pennzoil is seeking a controlling interest in Chevron by buying almost 10 percent of its stock.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Jewish Voters; Clinton Swipes at Bush For Lack of Jewish Aides
description: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, seeking the support of Jewish voters, today painted the Bush Administration and the Republican Party as institutions that were virtually devoid of Jews and dominated by fringe religious and right-wing elements hostile to Jewish concerns.

title: 28 Graves Giving Up Secrets of the 1700's
description: Because of a twist of archeological fate and a minor mistake on an old map, H. David Geer's sand-and-gravel crew stumbled onto a bit of 1700's rural America two years ago. A tiny and long forgotten farm family cemetery -- 28 bodies representing generations of a family called the Waltons -- suddenly re-emerged into the 20th century.

title: Ugandan Aide Among 5 Indicted From a Sting on Illegal Arms Deal
description: After an elaborate 10-month sting operation, a senior aide to the Ugandan President and four other people were indicted today on charges that they had illegally tried to export antitank missiles and launchers to Uganda. Two of the men were also accused of illegally trying to sell helicopter parts to Libya.

title: Sayedah Khadijah Faisal Is Dead; Co-Founder of Mosque Was 93
description: Sayedah Khadijah Faisal, a founder of Brooklyn's first mosque who was known to hundreds of Muslims as Mother Khadijah, died Saturday at her home at the mosque in Brooklyn Heights. She was 93 years old.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON PACT WITH OLYMPUS OPTICAL OF JAPAN
description: Johnson & Johnson said its Ethicon Endo-Surgery division had formed an alliance with the Olympus Optical Company of Tokyo. The companies will focus on the development of new products and procedures, as well as training surgeons, Ethicon president's, Robert Croce, said. Mr. Croce said the companies would work with surgeons to identify procedures that could use endoscopic surgery and then develop suitable products. Endoscopic surgery requires smaller incisions than traditional surgery, and allows for quicker recovery, less pain and shorter hospital stays. The procedure is used in gall-bladder removal, hernia repair, appendectomies and hysterectomies.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats; Clinton Presses Welfare Overhaul, Stressing Job Training and Work
description: Gov. Bill Clinton today called for an "end to welfare as we know it" and proposed a major program of job training and education for recipients of public aid.

title: N.H.L. in Court on TV
description: The National Hockey League and SportsChannel America faced off acrimoniously in court yesterday as the N.H.L. defended its right to sell cable television rights for the next five years to ESPN despite SCA's claim that it was cut out of bidding.

title: Baseball Owners Lean Toward Lockout
description: With the battle over Fay Vincent as commissioner apparently ancient history, major league baseball's club owners focused their attention on economic issues today and showed early signs that they were gearing themselves for a self-inflicted shutdown next spring.

title: Top Businesses Join in Plan To Provide Dependent Care
description: Eleven of the nation's leading corporations, joining with more than 100 smaller businesses and private organizations, announced yesterday that they would collaborate on a $25.4 million project to help their employees provide care for their children and aging relatives.

title: William Leisher, 51, Paintings Conservator
description: William R. Leisher, a paintings conservator and the executive director of the department of conservation at the Art Institute of Chicago, died on Wednesday at his home in Evanston, Ill. He was 51 years old.

title: COURT CLEARS T.W.A.'S AGREEMENT WITH UNION EMPLOYEES
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge in Wilmington, Del., approved an agreement between Trans World Airlines Inc. and its union employees that the airline expects will produce savings of $177 million a year. Judge Helen Balick approved the agreement to cut wages and benefits of 23,700 employees 15 percent, or $153 million, in exchange for 45 percent of the stock in a reorganized company. T.W.A. officials said the carrier would save an additional $24 million from cutting wages and benefits for its 5,800 management and nonunion employees.

title: Yield on 30-Year Bond Remains 7.24%
description: The prices of bond and notes bounced around yesterday but did not change that much on the day. Trading was moderate, and many investors were waiting to see what President Bush would say in an important economic speech in Detroit and in a five-minute paid television broadcast last night.

title: Midlantic Hires Lintas Marketing
description: The Midlantic Corporation of Edison, N.J., has named Lintas Marketing Communications in New York to handle its corporate and retail banking accounts, with billings of $2 million to $3 million. The account was previously divided between Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor Inc. in New York and Elkman Advertising in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.

title: AEL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-After a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 2,540,000, or 64 cents a share.c-Net incomed-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 111,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 262,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Clinton Criticizes Provisions in Trade Pact
description: Following in the footsteps of the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, Gov. Bill Clinton said today that the North American Free Trade Agreement appears to be lacking substantive provisions on job retraining for American workers and environmental cleanup in Mexico.

title: In Their Own Words
description: PRESIDENT BUSH

title: TV Ruling Favors N.H.L.
description: SportsChannel America was denied a preliminary injunction yesterday that would have required the National Hockey League to let SCA bid on the same deal that the league struck last week with ESPN.

title: Review/Cabaret; Susannah McCorkle Sings About the Vagaries of Love
description: Susannah McCorkle has determined, she says early in her new cabaret act, that in a romantic relationship things are great only 17.5 percent of the time. Appropriately, just 3 of the 17 songs in the singer's new show, "I'll Take Romance: Love Songs for People Who Love Songs," celebrate those perfect moments. And that happens to be just about 17.6 percent of the show.

title: MOUNTAIN TROOPS HELPING IN FLORIDA
description: Until Hurricane Andrew came along, the soldiers of the United States Army's 10th Mountain Division had planned to spend September in training exercises at their home base, Fort Drum, N.Y. Instead, members of the unit have for the last week been sorting canned goods and other donated items in the ruins of a tomato processing plant here.

title: Cracker Barrel Old Country Store Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said all share earnings reflected the 3-for-2 stock split effective March 1992.

title: Little Isles, A Big Fight
description: After voluntarily pulling out of Afghanistan and Eastern Europe and watching their huge empire crumble, the Russians suddenly drew the line at four obscure islands off Japan -- alienating, in the process, a major potential donor.

title: Tokyo Journal; Students Get a Saturday Off: Can They Handle It?
description: One of the biggest changes in Japan's education system since it was established 120 years ago will take place on Saturday. Schools will be closed.

title: September Surprise in Bronx
description: September can be a cruel month for losing baseball teams. The losses mount, the games stretch longer and the road trips never seem to end. Sometimes, the team captain even announces there is nothing left to play for.

title: What's This Happening In 'Joy to the World'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Jets Quarterbacks Are Making Quite a Team
description: Browning Nagle is all of 24 years old, with a grand total of one National Football League start, although that was an impressive near-record performance.

title: AIDS Benefit Concert
description: The Theater of the Heart is to perform a benefit concert for the People With AIDS Coalition entitled "Embrace the Human Race," at 8 tonight and tomorrow night at St. Clement's Church, 423 West 46th Street, in Clinton. The composer and pianist Richard Shulman is to perform the premieres of two new works scored for chamber orchestra and choir. Selections from his album "Open Spaces," as choreographed by Jeff Quinlivan, is to be performed by 10 dancers. Dawn Buckholz, a composer and cellist, is to perform her chamber ensemble work "Embrace," and Maureen Snyder, a composer and French hornist, is to present the premiere of a jazz work for horn, trombone, piano, cello and voice. Tickets are $15, $30 and $45. Information: (212) 265-6507.

title: The Big Guns Take Sides in Trade-Policy Debate
description: Chances are that if Warren Steibel, the producer of "Firing Line," were entrusted with organizing the Presidential debates, they would turn out to be a lot more enlightening and entertaining than they promise to be this year. Tonight's two-hour debate on a subject that is not often honored in prime time manages to make the pros and cons of free trade, believe it or not, positively lively.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY WASHINGTON HEIGHTS: BEHIND THE DECISION

title: Why They Died in Ciskei
description: South African politicians spend a remarkable amount of time vowing not to speak to one another, and Monday's massacre in the Ciskei black homeland has prompted yet another round of dark threats from both sides about the future of constitutional negotiations.

title: 'High Powered' President for Tektronix
description: Delbert W. Yocam, a former chief operating officer at Apple Computer Inc., agreed yesterday to join Tektronix Inc. as its president and chief operating officer.

title: Review/Film; The Romance of the Sea And the Lure of the Cup
description: Carroll Ballard's "Wind" is an irresistible end-of-summer dividend that extends the season indefinitely. It's a bracing fable about those grand 12-meter yachts and their crews that compete for the America's Cup, the oldest and most prestigious of international sailing trophies. Though called the Hundred Guinea Cup when it was originally offered in England in 1851, it was renamed that year for the boat that won the first race. Since then, except for one brief period in the 1980's when Australian sailors took the prize, the cup has remained in American hands.

title: Toro Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net incomeThe latest fourth quarter's results included charges of 56 cents a share covering three facility closings.Latest year's results included $ 1.41 a share in restructuring charges.

title: Even G.O.P. Supported Children's Legal Rights; Nothing Radical in It
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokyo Stocks
description: Japanese stocks closed sharply lower today. The Nikkei average of 225 issues was off 800.78 points, or 4.24 percent, to 18.107. Brokers attributed today's drop to index-related selling. On Thursday, the Nikkei rose 32.92 points.

title: Genetic Therapy Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represented total revenue.

title: Restaurants
description: Century Cafe

title: Diversified Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 465,000 from a writeoff of deferred industrial bond issuance costs due to early retirement.c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 63,000 for the quarter and $ 1,524,000 for the 9 months.

title: At Chapel Hill, Athletes Suddenly Become Activists
description: At the University of North Carolina, athletes and their accomplishments are taken seriously. The school is about to begin celebrating its bicentennial and, along with its reputation as one of the nation's most illustrious public universities, it has a proud history of exploits by such stars as Michael Jordan and Lawrence Taylor.

title: Auto Dealer Plea Deal Is Called Good for U.S.
description: The plea bargain in which a Long Island car dealer admitted bilking General Motors of $6 billion and promised to help prosecute public officials he said he bribed was cited by criminal lawyers and other legal experts yesterday as an apparently good deal for Federal prosecutors. The experts said the Government gave away only a conditional pledge to recommend leniency and may have opened a wedge against corruption in Suffolk County and perhaps in the auto industry as well.

title: INSIDE
description: Talks Likely in South Africa

title: The Spoken Word
description: TELEVISION DISCUSSION, Podell Auditorium, Beth Israel Hospital, First Avenue and 16th Street, Manhattan. A comparison of the new and the original "Star Trek" television series, sponsored by the Science Fiction Association of Metropolitan New York. Sunday at 1:30 P.M. Admission: $2. Information: (212) 262-3911.

title: Alistair Butler Is Dead; Ex-Ailey Dancer, 42
description: Alistair Butler, a former member of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and a performer with other modern-dance troupes, died on Monday at Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center. He was 42 years old and lived in New York City.

title: EE Bond Sales Rise
description: Sales of Series EE Savings Bonds more than doubled in August, to $1.469 billion, from $692 million in August 1991, the Treasury Department said today. The bonds, backed by the Government, provide a guaranteed minimum interest rate of 6 percent if held for five years or longer.

title: Brazil's Besieged Leader Is Deserted by a Top Aide
description: With impeachment pressure mounting, President Fernando Collor de Mello today accepted the resignation of his top political coordinator and canceled a trip to the United States.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Ballet Theater and Joffrey Decide Against Merging
description: American Ballet Theater and the Joffrey Ballet have agreed not to pursue a merger plan that the financially hard-pressed companies had been exploring since June. The decision was reached in separate board meetings on Wednesday and announced yesterday.

title: At the Bar
description: Last July, Craig Bradley of the Indiana University Law School received a tempting invitation, at least for a law professor accustomed to the mealy-mouthed mores of academic scholarship. It came from Reconstruction Magazine, and it was to write a no-holds-barred attack on Justice Clarence Thomas.

title: Ferraro Releases Tax Returns for 2 Missing Years to Offset Attacks by Rivals
description: Conceding that her refusal to release two years of tax returns had given her rivals an issue that was helping to erode her lead for the Democratic nomination for the Senate, Geraldine A. Ferraro reversed herself yesterday and said she was adding her 1984 and 1985 personal and family business tax filings to the dozen years of financial records she had previously released.

title: The Art Market
description: Hammer Museum Pact

title:
Single-Family Homes;
Smaller Lot Size, but More Open Space
description: An ordinance that allows residential units to be clustered to preserve open space is helping a developer attract buyers to a project here called the Highlands. Sixteen of the 94 detached three- and four-bedroom houses have been sold since sales began in November.

title: No Headline
description: "I can't imagine telling my children as a bedtime story that mommy and daddy got married because of a lawsuit." -- MARIA DILLON. [ B8:3. ]

title: CHRONICLE
description: About a year and a half ago, it struck ALEXANDER S. FRIEDMAN, a mountain climber who is a senior at Princeton University, that his sport was an apt metaphor for the battle against AIDS. Out of that notion came plans for an expedition that will benefit the American Foundation for AIDS Research. Mr. Friedman says he hopes it will also increase public awareness of the disease.

title: Plan Giving Public Hospitals More Autonomy Is Approved
description: The board of New York City's public hospital system voted without opposition yesterday to overhaul its relationship with City Hall, approving a plan intended to give the hospitals more control over their own budgets and more incentive to save money and to improve care.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In retrospect, DAVID BAKALAR says that there was something presumptuous about telling GEORGE SEGAL how to create a sculpture. But it was a request that in a way transformed Mr. Bakalar, a former electronics executive, into a sculptor himself.

title: Little Links: Maximizing Minimal Golf
description: ANY miniature golf course is a blend of three things: sport, art and nature. The more of each, the better, and an excess of all three is ideal. This isn't just a matter of big golf writ small. At its most successful, miniature golf should be bigger than life.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans; Plan Promoted In 5-Minute Ad
description: The Bush-Quayle campaign purchased five minutes of air time on four television networks last night to broadcast a new advertisement in which the President promotes the package of economic proposals that he announced earlier in the day.

title: On My Mind; Movies, Drugs, Elections
description: The movie stuck in my throat. It was not just that I and everybody else in the movie theater were being treated as political morons -- captive to left-wing paranoia about America and putting out $7.50 a head for the privilege.

title: Interstate Bakeries Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 22
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $ 10,176,000 related to Interstate Bakeries's public offering in July 1991.

title: 2 Researchers Accidentally Exposed to Monkeys' AIDS-Like Virus
description: Two researchers studying an AIDS-like virus in monkeys were accidentally exposed to the virus in different laboratories, and Federal health officials said yesterday that they were conducting tests to determine whether they had become infected with the virus. It is known as S.I.V., for simian immunodeficiency virus.

title: Air Force PC Contract For Zenith
description: Zenith Data Systems, a division of Groupe Bull of France, has been awarded an Air Force contract estimated to be worth at least $740 million, one of the largest Government contracts for desktop computers.

title: N.F.L.'s Judicial Record Remains 0 for Antitrust
description: The National Football League has never won an antitrust case on the basis of law, although it has escaped paying damages some of the time.

title: Five Charged With Looting Pension Fund
description: Three top officials of a construction union and two reputed members of the Genovese crime family were charged yesterday with turning the union "into a racketeering enterprise" through kickbacks and a fraudulent real-estate deal that looted nearly $20 million from the union's pension fund.

title: Stifel Financial reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax-loss carryforward of $ 648,000, or 19 cents a share.c-Net loss

title: Kit Manufacturing Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Special Prosecutor Sought On Justice Dept. Software
description: The 21 Democratic members of the House Judiciary Committee asked the Justice Department today to seek appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate accusations that senior department officials stole a computer company's program in the mid-1980's to benefit their friends and associates.

title: Senate Panel Rejects Plan to Repair Florida Base
description: Dealing a serious blow to President Bush's $7.6 billion plan to rebuild South Florida in the aftermath of the hurricane, the Senate Appropriations Committee today rejected his proposal to restore Homestead Air Force Base.

title: Value Merchants Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Photography; Obsessive Investigation of Personality
description: With its pristine surfaces and mechanically precise rendering of space, photography would seem to be a particularly unpromising medium for Lucas Samaras to work in. Mr. Samaras has long specialized in psychologically charged paintings and objects that feature ornate, obsessively worked surfaces made up of hundreds of pins or nails or bits of brightly colored yarn. But the exhibition of Mr. Samaras's photographic works from the last two decades, at the Museum of Modern Art through Dec. 1, demonstrates how well he has managed to turn this apparently recalcitrant medium to his own ends.

title: Bridgford Foods Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 3.

title: Federal Grand Jury Indicts Ex-Chairman of Silverado
description: A Federal grand jury in Denver today indicted Michael R. Wise, former chairman and chief executive of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, on charges of intent to defraud the bank and misapplication of its funds, Justice Department officials announced.

title: Pall Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-Included a charge of 3 cents a share from a settlement of promissory notes received by Pall Corp. in connection with the sale of its air dryer business in a leveraged buyout, which was reported in fiscal 1988. A pretax gain of $ 10.2 million, or 8 cents a share, was realized at that time; the period was also after income of $ 2,475,000, or 3 cents a share, representing the effect of adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 109, Accounting for Income Taxes, as of the beginning of fiscal 1992.

title: Currencies Teaching Europe That Unity Can Be Painful
description: Europe's plans for further unification may be up in the air, but people from Helsinki to Rome have been learning an often painful lesson in recent weeks about how entwined their economies have already become.

title: Family-Leave Bill Sent to President
description: After a debate marked by emotion, sarcasm and political one-upmanship, the House passed and sent to President Bush today legislation that would require employers to give workers 12 weeks of unpaid leave for family and personal medical emergencies.

title: Meadowbrook Rehabilitation Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from Tuesday, Sept. 8, editions.

title: A Utility's Strategy for Life in a Nonnuclear Age
description: When the voters here decided in 1989 to close the nuclear plant operated by their public utility, many wondered what would replace it. Rancho Seco ran only fitfully, but its generating capacity was half of the total for the Sacramento Municipal Utility District and could meet the needs of all 457,000 customers in Sacramento County if the weather was not too hot.

title: A Better Bargaining Hand for N.F.L. Players
description: The verdict in favor of the players in the McNeil v. National Football League trial vastly ups the ante for baseball-like free agency in football, but much will depend on how United States District Court Judge David Doty frames his injunction against the league and the league's certain appeal.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans; VOWING A REVIVAL, PRESIDENT SETS OUT HIS ECONOMIC PLAN
description: Seeking to convince the electorate that he has a coherent plan to lead the country to prosperity, President Bush today packaged his economic proposals of the last four years into what he called "a single program, a unified strategy" to revive the nation's economy.

title: DVI Health Services Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dance World Bestows The Bessies
description: Modern dancers and performance artists are often considered among the rugged individualists of the cultural world. Yet there are times when they gather in a spirit of community. Such an occasion took place on Thursday night, when Dance Theater Workshop presented the ninth annual Dance and Performance Awards at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

title: David Hyatt, Head Of Interfaith Group In 1970's, Dies at 76
description: David Hyatt, a former president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, died on Tuesday at Mount Zion Hospital in San Francisco, his hometown. He was 76 years old.

title: Sage Laboratories Inc.  reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Revenue represented net sales and contract revenues.

title: For Children
description: La Marqueta 116th Street and Park Avenue East Harlem Manhattan Recommended ages: 4 and up Daily except Sundays

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Jack Ossofsky, retired chief executive of the National Council on the Aging, omitted the names of some survivors. Besides his wife, Eula, Mr. Ossofsky is survived by two sons, Robert, of the Bronx, and Stephen Walden of Churchville, Va.; three daughters, Mindy Homer of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., Patricia Harrison of Boothbay Harbor, Me., and Paula Thompson of Yarmouth, Me.; and eight grandchildren.

title: TV Weekend; Corruption, Love and Murder, All From Real Life
description: The based-on-fact movie brigades are out in force this season. Two representative examples of the form are on tap this weekend: "Teamster Boss: The Jackie Presser Story," making its debut on HBO tomorrow at 8 P.M., and "A Murderous Affair: The Carolyn Warmus Story," on ABC Sunday at 9 P.M. Presser was the unscrupulous leader of a notoriously corrupt union; Ms. Warmus is now serving time for killing her lover's wife. In short, just about par for the this-is-a-true-story course.

title: Genesee Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $ 311,000 from the sale of real estate.Sales represented gross sales.Genesee reported net sales, after excise taxes and allowances, of $ 37,921,000 in the latest quarter and $ 41,082,000 in year-ago period.

title: New York's Senate Race; FERRARO AND FOES CLASH OVER ETHICS
description: The contenders for the Democratic Senate nomination from New York clashed sharply over ethics last night, as Geraldine A. Ferraro's main rivals repeatedly questioned her integrity, and she responded by vigorously challenging their own.

title: Reviews/Theater; Getting to the Heart of Joyce With His Own Words
description: Whether jigging a jiggily jig down the Liffey or juggling a jangly jingle jiffily, there's joyance and jollity in "Joyicity." Ah, that Jimmy Joyce, he knew a bit of the lingo, by jingo.

title: How to Deal with a Wounded Russia
description: Boris Yeltsin deserves sympathetic understanding for his decision not to visit Japan when no face-saving compromise could be worked out for return of four small islands. And he deserves special praise for his agreement to speed withdrawal of former Soviet troops from Lithuania.

title: Article 494492 -- No Title
description: Lucio Medina, a jewelry designer in New York, used to long for the chicken of his native Peru. "We have chicken stands the way you have hamburger stands," he said. "I wanted to taste that kind of chicken."

title: U.N. Will Add NATO Troops To Bosnia Force
description: The United Nations moved today to greatly expand the size of its peacekeeping force in Bosnia and Herzegovina through the addition of at least 5,000 NATO troops to protect convoys of food and medicine being sent to needy people throughout the wartorn country.

title: Jones Spacelink Ltd. reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 812,000, or 1 cent a share, which included a gain of $ 1,380,000 from a tax loss carryforward and a loss of $ 568,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.c-Net loss and after an extraordinary gain on early extinguishment of debt of $ 2,789,000, or 3 cents a share.Year-ago figures included results from Jones Intercable Inc. in which the company owned a 23 percent stake at May 31, 1992, compared with a 24 percent stake last year.

title: Ever a Litigious Lot
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L.'s Free-Agency System Is Found Unfair by U.S. Jury
description: The National Football League's system of free agency, under which teams retain the rights to their best players, was rendered illegal today by a Federal jury in an antitrust lawsuit brought by eight players.

title: Inmac Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
description: b-After a reserve of $ 1.3 million to provide for severance and costs in connection with the closing of the company's Italian operations.c-Included a 20 cent a share increase in earnings resulting from tax loss carryforwards from start-up countries.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo; Facing Draft Questions, Clinton Avoids the Press
description: Stung by recurring questions about his credibility, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas took refuge today behind the unblinking eye of a camera and the long-distance questions of television anchors in Detroit to try to control the coverage of his campaign.

title: Verdict Leaves Players Happy and Wanting More
description: Yes, Jim Quinn was happy last night, and why wouldn't he be. As the lead lawyer for eight National Football League players he had just won what he called "a total and huge victory" in Federal court in Minneapolis.

title: A New Stance for Doubleday
description: As the first baseball club owners meeting in the post-Fay Vincent era ended, one owner of a New York team came away with his qualms about remaining in baseball eliminated while another was still in limbo.

title: Knicks Lose McDaniel to The Celtics
description: Placed on hold by the Knicks all summer, Xavier McDaniel abruptly cut the line between himself and New York yesterday by signing a three-year contract with the Boston Celtics, rivals of the Knicks in the Atlantic Division.

description: b-Net loss

title: Andretti's World Might Include Indy
description: MICHAEL ANDRETTI will join the international Formula One circuit next year, but he still might be able to race in the Indianapolis 500.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS AMCOR LTD.,Melbourne, Australia, said its paper-making division, Australian Paper Manufacturers, would build its first American mill in Prewitt, N.M., to make corrugated fiber box materials from wastepaper. INTELSAT, Washington, an international cooperative of 124 member nations that owns the global communications satellite system, said its board had approved the purchase of Intelsat 8 satellites from GE Astro Space.
description: WYLE LABORATORIES INC., El Segundo, Calif., said its Scientific Services and Systems Group had received a contract of more than $75 million from the NASA-Langley Research Center.

title: Balloonists Will Try Again to Circle Globe
description: Larry Newman, captain of a team of aeronauts who hope to make the first nonstop balloon flight around the world, announced this week that their Earthwinds balloon would be ready to launch from Reno Stead Airport in Nevada on Nov. 15.

title: Countrywide Credit Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective July 2, 1992.

title: Tales of Corruption Widen L.I. Dealer Inquiry
description: The investigation of municipal corruption in Brookhaven has already expanded far beyond the allegations of bribery raised by John McNamara, the Long Island car dealer and real estate developer who pleaded guilty to fraud and bribery on Wednesday, Federal prosecutors said today.

title: MCI WILL FORM NETWORK WITH CANADA'S PHONE COMPANIES
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said it would create the first fully integrated international network with Canada's major telephone companies. The pact calls for MCI to license its intelligent network platform for $150 million to Stentor, an alliance of nine phone companies. The platform is the basis for advanced telecommunication services including MCI Vnet, MCI Vision and MCI Friends & Family. Stentor will be able to offer these services to Canadian customers once the platform has been installed. Doug Maine, MCI's chief financial officer, said the timing of Stentor's payment of the one-time amount had not been set.

title: Newark Police Shootings Revive Calls for a Civilian Review Board
description: In the first organized citizen response to recent police shootings of young car-theft suspects, a new coalition of community groups led by Amiri Baraka, the poet, pressed today for a civilian police complaint review board.

title: Sony Introduces Recordable Disk System
description: The Sony Corporation today introduced the product lineup and pricing for the recordable music disk system that it hopes will become the heir to its wildly successful Walkman line of portable cassette players.

title: Even G.O.P. Supported Children's Legal Rights; A Douglas Opinion
description: To the Editor:

description: Results for the year-ago periods ended July 27.Sales represented net sales.

title: An Upset: Opponents Are Gracious
description: As DON KING, the promoter, rambled on from the dais, HECTOR CAMACHO shadowboxed, mugged and postured, and kissed his infant son, MACHO.

title: Young & Rubicam Gets Mixed News
description: As Young & Rubicam New York watched one account go into review, it was reported that another client was likely to award the agency additional business.

title: Autotote Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 2.6 million, or 51 cents a share, related to an insurance claim.c-Net lossThe company said the decline in revenues for the latest third quarter and 9 months reflected the divestiture of the United Tote Co. totalizator and racetrack operations.

title: Naylor Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
Workers, Wives and Mothers
description: Have you ever wondered why most politicians speak in safe cliches? I've recently learned the answer. The great hazard in stating one's views publicly, in one's own words, is that they will be misunderstood or, for political reasons, deliberately misconstrued.

title: Haitian Women With H.I.V. To Be Admitted to the U.S.
description: Opening the door further to Haitians stranded at the United States Navy base at Guantanamo, Cuba, because they or their relatives tested positive for the virus that causes AIDS, the Administration will allow all pregnant women at the camp infected with H.I.V. to come to American hospitals, Assistant Attorney General Stuart M. Gerson said today.

title: Stemming the Upsurge in Measles
description: Three years ago measles, which had been reduced to very low levels in the United States, started making a comeback. It has since infected tens of thousands of young victims, many of them in New York. The epidemic has been caused by an unconscionable failure to vaccinate the most vulnerable children. But starting today, health authorities should be able to turn the tide.

title: O'Connor Discusses Possibility of a Strike
description: With teachers in the 298 schools of the Archdiocese of New York working without a contract, John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday that he would respect the right of the teachers to strike but added that such an action would do little good.

title: The Rhetoric Aside, She's No Churchill
description: To the Editor:

title: Mandela Group Agrees to Meeting With de Klerk
description: Sobered by the massacre of its followers in the black homeland of Ciskei, the African National Congress agreed in principle tonight to a summit meeting with President F. W. de Klerk aimed at curbing violence and resuming the transition to a nonracial democracy.

title: Books of The Times; Artist, Pawn and Avenging Angel
description: Trick of the Eye By Jane Stanton Hitchcock 275 pages. E. P. Dutton. $19.

title: Concern in the Season of Jocklock
description: Beats me. People who only last week called Fay Vincent an arrogant, conniving back-stabber now proclaim him the Man of La Mancha. What a comeback. It may be solace for Vincent, but it leaves me confused.

title: Ampal-American Israel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net lossYear-ago revenues for the quarter and 6 months are restated to reflect the change of status of a subsidiary to an investee company and an investee to a subsidiary.The company said the improvement in the second quarter results is highlighted by a substantial gain on issuance of shares and a gain on sale of shares related to a public offering in the United States by an investee company.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks Fans: Anybody But The Celtics
description: THEY could have rationalized Xavier McDaniel's going anywhere but the grubby old barn on Causeway. Knicks fans know the Boston Celtics have a history of picking up older players like Don Nelson and Bailey Howell, and now the Celtics have done it with McDaniel.

title: September Rubies Ripe for Harvest
description: THERE was a time, in the mists of the middle-aged memory of at least some former children, when summer's end was an eagerly awaited seasonal moment of hidden treasure. Those were the days before air-conditioning imprisoned people indoors, before movies and records needed warning labels and before earnest mothers and fathers confined a prescribed period of parenting into something called "quality time."

title: Market Place; Small Investors Stepping Aside?
description: SIGNS of a retreat by small investors led to much wringing of hands yesterday on Wall Street, where some brokerage stocks took a nasty hit. The selling was prompted by an announcement by Charles Schwab & Company, the discount broker, that said late Wednesday that business had fallen to an average of 18,000 trades a day recently, down from boom levels of 32,300 in January.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12 ISRAEL AND SYRIA TALK OF PEACE

title: No Place for the Drug-Addicted Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Carrington Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
The Green Card at the End of the Irish Rainbow; Latest Wave of Immigrants Finds That, Even With Legal Status, Jobs Are Still Tight
description: Last fall, Carol Philbin gave up. Without working papers and out of a job for more than a month, she returned home to Galway for good after three years of struggle in the shadow world of New York City's undocumented Irish.

title: Review/Art; Magritte And His Defiance Of Life
description: "IF the spectator finds that my paintings are a kind of defiance of 'common sense,' he realizes something obvious," said Rene Magritte, who is the subject of a stimulating retrospective that opens tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. "I want nevertheless to add that for me the world is a defiance of common sense."

title: At Last, a Bush Package
description: President Bush: Welcome to the debate. Yesterday, almost four years after taking office, he issued an "Agenda for American Renewal" that comprises a coherent statement of economic objectives and policies. It calls for making the U.S. a strong exporter, educating disadvantaged children, sharpening competitiveness, cutting government waste, helping the poor and protecting workers.

title: Judge's Ruling May Mean Clifford Will Never Face Trial
description: A Federal judge today postponed a trial on bank fraud charges for Clark M. Clifford and his junior law partner, allowing a trial on similar charges in New York to proceed first. But the ruling also set in motion events that may result in Mr. Clifford never going to trial anywhere because of concerns about his health.

title: 'Doktor Faust' Premiere
description: The New York stage premiere of Busoni's opera "Doktor Faust" is to be presented by the New York City Opera at 8 tonight at the New York State Theater. "Doktor Faust" was unfinished when Busoni died in 1924, and was completed by his student and colleague Philip Jarnach. Using Busoni's libretto based on a puppet-play version of "Faust," the work was first performed in Dresden in 1925, and in a concert version at Carnegie Hall in 1964. Tonight's performance is to feature William Stone in the title role; Eva Zseller as Herzogin, and Michael Rees Davis as Mephistopheles, with John Calvin West, Peter Blanchet and Robert Brubaker in supporting roles. Tickets are $10 to $68. Information: (212) 870-5633.

title: Exxon and Mobil in Russia Venture
description: The nation's two biggest oil companies, the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation, said today that they would join forces to bid on oil-and-gas exploration and production projects in one of Russia's biggest oilfields, the West Siberian basin.

title: Fischer Just Manages a Draw in Game 6 of Match
description: After more than seven hours of hard-fought play, Bobby Fischer barely managed to survive with a draw yesterday in Game 6 of his exhibition chess match with Boris Spassky in Sveti Stevan, Yugoslavia.

title: Gunmen in Italy Kill Cousins Of an Informer Against Mob
description: Five days after he police arrested a suspected Mafia boss, gunmen in Sicily today shot dead two brothers related to an informer who had earlier helped the authorities identify other mobsters, the police said.

title: Chang Stops Ferreira In Five Sets
description: Michael Chang, careful to a fault, let himself be pushed to the limit last night by 12th-seeded Wayne Ferreira of South Africa, an incorrigible risk-taker, in their lengthy United States Open quarterfinal last night on the Grandstand Court.

title: Labatt (John) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 2,000,000.Some of the year-ago figures have been restated to conform with the latest period's presentation.Results are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Patricio on Staten Island

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Sweet Soul

title: Messinger Hurt in Crash
description: The Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, was slightly injured yesterday when her chauffeur-driven car swerved onto a sidewalk along Third Avenue to avoid hitting a truck and crashed into a pole, the police said. Ms. Messinger complained of neck and back pain after the accident, the police said. She was admitted for observation to St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center, where she was listed in stable condition yesterday afternoon. Her driver, Clarice Brown, was treated and released at St. Vincent's. The driver of the truck, John Grillo, was not injured.

title: NEW YORK'S SENATE RACE: The Ad Campaign; Holtzman: On the Attack
description: THE TELEVISION SCRIPT: NARRATOR: "The New York Times on Ferraro's ethics: 'Fair-minded voters are left to wonder.' Now, more revelations. Ferraro voted for school prayer. For tax breaks to schools that discriminate against blacks and Latinos. Even voted to make homosexuality a crime. Liz Holtzman: In Congress, the guts to take on a President. To stand up for choice and fight discrimination. On ethics, squeaky clean. Want to beat the sleaze and elect a woman? Liz Holtzman." PRODUCER: Squier, Eskew, Knapp, Ochs of Washington.

title: Paramount Communications Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 35.4 million, the majority of which was related to a provision for writedowns of certain motion picture and television development commitments and entertainment reorganization costs.

title: 4 Senate Challengers: Excerpts From the Democrats' Debate
description: Following are excerpts from last night's Democratic Senate debate, as transcribed by The New York Times: Taxes and the Middle Class

title: Review/Art; Photomontages of 20's Still Resonate in the 90's
description: It may be early to start designating the season's best shows, but one of them is bound to be the quietly dazzling display of the photomontages of the German artist Hannah Hoch (1889-1978) at Goethe House.

title: PENNEY WILL REVAMP DATA PROCESSING AND PARE 300 JOBS
description: The J. C. Penney Company said it would overhaul its data processing, eliminating 300 jobs. Consolidating its four major data centers into a single center in Dallas will save $11 million a year, or 10 cents a share, starting in the year ending in January 1995. The four centers are in Columbus, Ohio; Reno; Dallas, and Lenexa, Kan. Penney has not calculated severance and related costs of the move, a spokesman said.

title: A Proposal On Housing Is Approved By Council
description: The New York City Council gave final approval to a plan to replace the historic Brighton Beach Baths in Brooklyn with a large housing development yesterday, ending a bitter, six-year-old dispute.

title: Youth Denies He Killed Man In Crown Hts.
description: The youth accused of killing a visiting rabbinical student during disturbances in Crown Heights last year testified in a pretrial hearing yesterday that he neither stabbed nor participated in the assault on the student.

title: Recriminations Fly in Japan On Collapse of Yeltsin Visit
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin's sudden cancellation of his trip to Japan unleashed an unusual round of recriminations as the Japanese Government was accused of pressing an embattled Russian leader so hard on its territorial claims that it lost its best chance in decades to improve relations with Moscow.

title: Bush's Double Bind
description: When it comes to dealing with the economy as a campaign issue, President Bush is caught in a trap.

title: New York City Firefighters Given 4.5% Raise in 30-Month Accord
description: In a settlement that Dinkins administration officials said they hoped would set a pattern for coming labor negotiations, City Hall and the firefighters union agreed on a tentative contract yesterday that calls for a 4.5 percent raise.

title: Imex Medical Systems reports earnings for Year to June 30
Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Critic's Notebook; For Adult Pop Music, A Quiet Sonic Boom
description: "WHAT have you heard that's good?"

title: Empire Co. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ailing, Sure, but Fit for a Championship
description: The four women's semifinalists are on a myriad of missions, but the one who says she is the sickest after five rounds of United States Open duty is probably the least fragile of the lot.

title: Raymond Hickok, 74, Executive Who Helped Develop Seat Belts
description: Raymond P. Hickok, who headed a family business that made men's belts and jewelry and helped develop automobile seat belts, died on Wednesday at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 74 years old and lived in nearby Pittsford.

title: In Washington Heights, Dinkins Defends Actions After Shooting
description: Frustrated over charges that he had taken sides against the police in the shooting of Jose (Kiko) Garcia, Mayor David N. Dinkins angrily defended his actions in the Washington Heights case late yesterday afternoon when he was challenged by a police officer.

title: Ex-House Post Office Manager Indicted
description: A House post office manager was indicted today for conspiring with legislative officials to use the mailing service for "personal and campaign services," including cashing checks for House employees.

title: Lawyer, Hereafter Broken Heart, Sues to Mend It
description: In a year when lawyers are fodder for just about everyone else, Maria Dillon has another beef with the profession. Because her former fiance is so much the lawyer, she contends, her broken courtship has ended up in court.

title: Review/Film; A Crime Of the 20's In the Garb Of Today
description: "Swoon" was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 27 . The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza, Broadway at 63d Street, Upper West Side.

title: Getty Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Nicaragua Leader Seeks to Counter U.S. Criticism
description: Despite charges from her leftist opposition that she was caving in to the United States, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has taken steps to clear up some of Nicaragua's bitter disputes over private property.

title: G.O.P. Lawmakers Meet to Regroup and Rethink Issues
description: Faced with a politically explosive $1.7 billion budget shortfall next year and possible defections on major issues, New Jersey's Republican legislative majority held a retreat today to regroup.

title: Zuckerman Gains in Bid To Purchase Daily News
description: Seven of the Daily News's nine unions said last night that they had reached an agreement in principle with Mortimer B. Zuckerman, propelling the real estate developer into front-runner status for acquiring the newspaper.

title: Many Women in Army Favor Ending Combat Ban
description: A large majority of female Army officers and enlisted personnel favor repealing the military's regulations that exclude women from combat roles, but less than 15 percent say they would volunteer for combat jobs if allowed, according to a new survey.

title: Bergdorf Turns to Humor to Soften Image of Men's Store
description: EXECUTIVES at one of the most problematic recent retail ventures are hoping that humor can help sell high-priced haberdashery.

title: Geraghty & Miller Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that the year-ago quarter and 6 months included non-recurring tax benefits of approximately $ 100,000, or 2 cents a share, and $ 200,000, or 3 cents a share, respectively.Revenue represented gross revenue.Corrected from Wednesday, Sept. 9, editions.

title: Bachanalia Festival
description: The fourth annual Bachanalia Festival is to begin this weekend with two free concerts at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, in Morningside Heights. Tomorrow night at 7:30, the Festival Orchestra is to present the New York premiere of the actor and jazz musician Michael Moriarty's Symphony for Strings, conducted by the composer, as well as three concertos by Bach, conducted by the festival's director, Nina Beilina, who will also be a violin soloist. On Sunday at 3:30 P.M. there is to be a chamber-music concert featuring a Concerto for Clarinet and Piano Trio by Boris Tischenko and works by Shostakovich and Bach, with Ms. Beilina, Mr. Tischenko, the clarinetist Julius Milkis, the pianist Nina Kogan, the cellist Boris Rayskin and the violinist Basia Danilow. The festival will end with two concerts next Friday and Sept. 19. Admission is free. Information: (212) 316-7563.

title: ISRAELIS DISCLOSE TALKS WITH SYRIA ON STEPS TO PEACE
description: Israel and Syria are negotiating the terms of a joint document setting forth the principles for working out a peaceful settlement between the two countries, Israeli officials say.

title: I.M.F. Urges U.S. to Lift Taxes and Slash Deficit
description: The International Monetary Fund's executive board criticized the United States today for doing too little to cut its budget deficit and said that tax increases would be needed.

title: NEW YORK'S SENATE RACE: Ferraro's About-Face; As Opponents' Charges Begin to Hurt, She Abandons Front-Runner's Stance
description: For weeks, former United States Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro insisted that opponents' charges about her family's finances were "sour grapes," desperate gambits of rivals far behind her in the polls. But yesterday, she acknowledged something quite different: the charges were working.

title: Traffic Alert
description: TOMORROW

title: Intertrans Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Sidney Forman, 77, U.S. Army Historian
description: Prof. Sidney Forman, an authority on the history of the United States Army, died on Monday at the home of his son in Spring Valley, N.Y. He was 77 and lived in Fort Montgomery, N.Y.

title: 7 Charged in Death of Student Who Objected to Racial Slur
description: Seven young men have been charged by Broward County prosecutors in the beating death last month of a 19-year-old pre-medical student after he objected to a racial slur.

title: BORLAND'S QUATTRO FOR WINDOWS ON SALE THIS MONTH
description: Borland International Inc. said yesterday that its long-delayed version of its Quattro Pro for Windows spreadsheet will be available this month. In an attempt to win market share, Borland will sell the program to users of competing programs for $99. People using Borland's older Quattro Pro, for DOS-based computers, can buy the new program for $79. The list price for everyone else will be $495.

title: Trade Pact Job Losses Put as High as 150,000
description: Labor Secretary Lynn Martin conceded that the North American Free Trade Agreement could put up to 150,000 Americans out of work, while Democrats asserted that the President's plan to help them was inadequate.

title: Review/Film; Under the Freeway, A Family of Runaways
description: The southern California teen-agers seen in Marc Rocco's "Where the Day Takes You" have no thoughts of fun in the sun. These runaways, ragged and homeless, could be living in Times Square were it not for certain particulars of the film's Hollywood setting. The dive where they gather for fast food doesn't have plates, but it does have movie posters on its walls. One character recalls having been so high on drugs that he tried to scrape the stars off Hollywood Boulevard. And a glamorous likeness of James Cagney looks down from a mural, as if to emphasize that tough guys of the past had no notion of how tough things can be today.

title: General Host reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 9
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $ 13,500,000, or 43 cents a share, from sale of the company's 80 percent interest in Calloway's Nursery Inc. in July 1991.Year-ago 6 months' results included the results of Calloway's Nursery. The figures included sales from Calloway's of $ 4,400,000 in the second quarter and $ 18,900,000 in the 6 months.The company said after eliminating the effect of Calloway's, second quarter earnings were $ 200,000, or 1 cent a share, compared with a year-earlier net loss of $ 3,600,000. For the 6 months, net was $ 6,800,000, or 38 cents a share, up from year-earlier net of $ 1,500,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: T. E. Robinson, Ex-College President, 87, Is Dead
description: Dr. Thomas E. Robinson, the former president of Glassboro State College and unsuspecting host of an unsuspected East-West summit meeting in rural southern New Jersey in 1967, died on Wednesday at St. Mary's Hospital in Langhorne, Pa. He was 87 years old and lived in Holland, Pa.

title: GILLETTE TO PAY $561 MILLION FOR PARKER PEN
description: The Gillette Company, which in addition to shaving products makes Paper Mate, Flair and Waterman pens, agreed today to pay $:285 million ($561 million) for Parker Pen Holdings Ltd. of Britain.
