Ludgin Philip L. Steele 2d District Glenn Carberry Ed Munster + Died yesterday, but his name remains on the ballot.

title: German Cut Not Seen as Quick Cure
description: The Bundesbank's decision to cut German interest rates was hailed in dozens of world capitals as a move that will spur growth in Europe and beyond. But the cuts are not so sizable that economists expect them to fuel a quick or strong turnaround.

title: Paris Says Vote for Unity Treaty Will Allow It to Cut Interest Rates
description: Moving quickly to capitalize on a reduction in German interest rates, the French Government today offered wavering French voters a deal: it too hopes to lower domestic interest rates -- if they ratify a treaty on European union in a referendum on Sunday.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Leonid Hambro Pianist Merkin Concert Hall

title: Kenneth Kendrick, 43, Magazine Art Director
description: Kenneth L. Kendrick, a former art director of The New York Times Magazine, died on Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 43 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bridge
description: The Summer National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League always attract a sprinkling of players from other continents. In Toronto in July there were contestants from England, Scotland, Iceland, Sweden, Poland, Saudi Arabia, India, Brazil and Uruguay.

title: Persian Gulf Journal; At 140degrees Below Decks, You Might Say War Is Hell
description: American aviators and sailors in the Persian Gulf, daily sending warplanes into the skies over southern Iraq, have discovered that the most debilitating force they confront is one that Saddam Hussein does not control: the sun.

title: U.S. Backs a Vitamin To Foil Birth Defects
description: THE United States Public Health Service recommended yesterday that all women of childbearing age should take extra folic acid, a B vitamin, to prevent neural tube defects that affect 1 to 2 of every 1,000 babies born each year. The effects of these birth defects include paralysis and death.

title: William R. Reid, 74, Former Chief Executive
description: William R. Reid Jr., a former chief executive of the Torrington Company, a Connecticut manufacturer, died on Sunday at his home in Litchfield, Conn. He was 74 years old.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Gerald Ranck Harpsichordist The New York Society for Ethical Culture

title: The 1992 Campaign; Seven Priests and a Nun Back Hispanic Rivals Over Solarz
description: In an unusual Election Eve appeal made without the approval of the Brooklyn Diocese, seven Roman Catholic priests and a nun called on voters in the new 12th Congressional district to select any of the five Hispanic candidates for office over Representative Stephen J. Solarz.

title: Germany's Pollution Offers A Shield
description: ALTHOUGH they occupy similar latitudes in opposite hemispheres, New Zealand is exposed to nearly twice as much harmful ultraviolet radiation from the Sun as Germany, scientists have found.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Debates; Bush Camp Gives Ultimatum on Debates
description: President Bush's campaign today spelled out its conditions for debates with Gov. Bill Clinton and threatened to refuse to debate at all if the Arkansas Democrat does not give ground on the format.

title: It's Time to Normalize Relations With Vietnam; Clinton and Draft
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Leap by 70.52, Biggest Jump of Year
description: Stock prices in the United States took their biggest leap of the year yesterday, following sharp rallies in Europe, after Bonn loosened its interest-rate tourniquet.

title: Trenton G.O.P. Chief Runs for Congress
description: Assemblyman Robert D. Franks, chairman of the Republican State Committee, announced his candidacy today for the Seventh District Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Matthew J. Rinaldo.

title: AMDAHL FORECASTS A LOSS FOR THE SECOND QUARTER
description: The Amdahl Corporation said yesterday that an unexpected decline in demand recently for its new mainframe computers was likely to result in a loss for the third quarter. Amdahl, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., cited the sluggish worldwide economy and its adverse effect on capital spending as the primary factors that are limiting demand for its mainframes, tape and disk drives.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Vilas Upended in Bordeaux Opener Guillermo Vilas was beaten, 6-4, 3-6, 6-0, by German Lopez of Spain in the first round of the $330,000 Bordeaux Passing Shot tournament in France yesterday. Seventh-seeded Andrei Cherkasov of Russia, the only seeded player in action, advanced by defeating Laurent Prades of France, 6-2, 7-6 (9-7). In other first-round action, Alex Corretta of Spain beat Thierry Fontang of France, 6-4, 6-1; Francisco Roig of Spain beat countryman Jordi Burillo, 6-7 (4-7,) 6-1, 6-0; Claudio Pistolesi of Italy beat Arnaud Boetsch of France, 7-5, 6-7 (3-7), 6-3; and Guillermo Perez-Roldan won a battle of Argentines, 6-3, 6-7 (3-7), 6-3, against Juan Garat. (AP)

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats; Clinton Readies Answer to Bush On Draft Issue
description: Choosing to confront an issue he had declared himself finished with three weeks ago, Bill Clinton abruptly altered his campaign schedule and flew from here today to defend himself against an anticipated attack by President Bush on the subject of Mr. Clinton and the draft during the Vietnam War.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: 'Rigoletto' Amato Opera 319 Bowery (at Second Street) East Village Through Oct. 11

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail; The Eyes of the Clinton Strategists Are on Texas
description: Two weeks ago, Gov. Bill Clinton and Senator Al Gore took their bus tour deep into the heart of Texas, spending three dusty days on the trail, from San Antonio to Tyler. Then they sent in a poll taker to determine how their political act had played.

title: Shining Path: Cut Off at the Top
description: Saturday's arrest of Abimael Guzman Reynoso, founder, leader and animating force of Peru's murderous Shining Path rebels, could prove a life-saver of staggering dimensions.

title: Satellite Woes Undercut U.S. Hurricane Forecasts
description: The United States is facing heightened danger from hurricanes because delays in modernizing its weather satellites are forcing the use of spacecraft so antiquated and poorly positioned that they are raising the risk of forecasting errors, Federal scientists say.

title: Lageman's Loss Sends Jets Into Tailspin
description: After losing in a humiliating way to Pittsburgh, 27-10, and falling to 0-2, the Jets were trying to dig their way out from underneath a pile of shattered expectations here today.

title: Untangling The Tangle Of a Home Network
description: LAST June I wrote about adding a new computer to my home-office arsenal and setting up a tiny network: two machines, along with a printer and modem. This is a progress, or rather lack of progress, report.

title: Mud and Dark On First Day Of New Term
description: The tent city here was still knee deep in darkness as the children walked sleepily through the mud to catch the buses that would take them to school for the first time since Aug. 24, when Hurricane Andrew struck South Florida.

title: Remember the Massacre
description: The dying 102d Congress has only three weeks to renew the expiring 1978 independent counsel law. Failure to do so will give added weight to the movement to impose term limits on Congress. After all, what good is it for members to stick around a long time if they won't act on their memory of Watergate, the Saturday Night Massacre and a President who claimed the right to fire prosecutors on his trail?

title: Murder Charge in Crash
description: A 64-year-old Queens man was killed yesterday when the livery cab in which he was riding was struck by a stolen car at the intersection of Skillman Avenue and 39th Street in Queens , the police said. The driver of the stolen Pontiac, identified as Patrick Marrin, 22 years old, of 63-37 Fresh Pond Road, was arrested and charged with second-degree murder, said a police spokeswoman, Sgt. Tina Mohrmann.

title: First Chicago Selling Off Bad Property Loans
description: The First Chicago Corporation announced an ambitious plan yesterday to put the problems of bad real estate loans behind it by selling them and covering some of the resulting losses with previously unreported profits from various investments.

title: Case Is Settled by Salomon
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. will pay the Government $27.8 million to settle charges that it violated Federal antitrust law in a Treasury bond auction scandal last year, the Justice Department said today.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week; Movement on Debates Reflects Shifting Needs
description: The sudden proposal by the Bush campaign to open direct negotiations with Gov. Bill Clinton's staff on the subject of Presidential debates means more than just a realization by Republicans that their strategy of holding out was hurting them politically.

title: When an Audience Becomes the Show
description: "If you stumble across this collection of loonies, it looks like a National Front rally," said John Drummond. "It's rather worrying. But it's not planned like that, and it's really a rather good-humored occasion, without any edge of aggression."

title: Miscellany
description: * Gov. Bill Clinton's advertising campaign to date was rated more effective than President Bush's, according to a national poll conducted by Market Facts, Arlington Heights, Ill. Out of 1,015 adults surveyed, Mr. Clinton's ads were preferred 40 percent to 29 percent. Eight percent of respondents said they had not seen any ads and 23 percent refused to specify which they believed to be more effective.

title: GERMAN RATES CUT, SETTING OFF SURGE IN WORLD MARKETS
description: Germany's powerful central bank cut its high interest rates slightly today -- less than many political leaders and economists had hoped -- but even the small cut was enough to provoke a strong worldwide rally in stocks.

title: Eastern College Report
description: Syracuse

title: Left-Hand Trouble A Given For Mets
description: The endless summer for the Mets has once more extended the club's search for a dependable left-hander in the bullpen.

title: Garret G. Ackerson, 88, Envoy In East Europe During Cold War
description: Garret G. Ackerson Jr., a retired career Foreign Service officer who headed United States legations and embassies in Eastern Europe during some of the most difficult periods of the cold war, died Monday at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 88 years old.

title: Alexander Marble, 90, Physician And Leader at a Diabetes Center
description: Dr. Alexander Marble, an expert on diabetes and president emeritus of the Joslin Diabetes Center in Boston, died Sunday at Carlton Willard Village, a retirement community in Bedford, Mass. A former resident of Brookline, Mass., he was 90 years old.

title: Sports of The Times The Garden Glitters At Midday
description: A GOOD OMEN in that otherwise dismal railroad station under Madison Square Garden. A young man, a young black man who looked like a college student, was wearing a crisp, cream-colored Dodgers shirt with the reddest No. 42 emblazoned on the front.

title: 2 KOREAS RESUME TALKS ON NEW TIES
description: The Prime Ministers of North and South Korea opened a new round of talks tonight, amid concern that the effort to reconcile the two countries is stalling.

title: Police Panel: Shadow of 60's Hangs Over Council
description: A debate that two decades ago divided New York City will be resurrected today as the City Council prepares to wrestle with a proposal from Mayor David N. Dinkins to create an independent, civilian-controlled agency to investigate police misconduct.

title: It's Matisse vs. Music As the Fall Season Gets Under Way
description: Perhaps when you're installing 400 works by Matisse, it's easy to get distracted, so distracted that you don't hear the New York Philharmonic tuning up across town. And the Philharmonic can hardly be blamed for assuming that no one would dare give a party to compete with its 150th-birthday celebration.

title: Serving Up Gardens by the Glass, Juice Bars Flow Into the Mainstream
description: IT'S 12:40 on a Friday afternoon, and Mizan Biswas and Mike Flores are loading carrots and beets and celery stalks into whirring silver machines like ammunition into cannons in the heat of battle. The line is lengthening at Healthy Chelsea, a market, cafe and juice bar just off Eighth Avenue at 248 West 23d Street in Manhattan, and the two men speed up the dance behind the counter, sending shocking green spurts of wheatgrass juice into tiny one-ounce cups and weighty pink Jumbo Combos into the hands of thirsty customers.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Senate; ABRAMS, IN TIGHT SENATE VOTE, APPEARS TO EDGE OUT FERRARO
description: State Attorney General Robert Abrams apparently edged out former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro in a bitterly close race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senate from New York last night, setting the stage for a tough fight with the Republican incumbent, Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Don't Gut Credit Reform
description: Norwich, Vt., remains unsurpassed as a reason for reforming the laws that govern the credit reporting industry. TRW Inc., one of three companies that dominate the business, once threatened the credit rating of every taxpayer in Norwich -- the result of erroneous information entered into credit histories.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail; Clinton's Invited Guests Hope to Bash Arkansas
description: "Washington, come on down!"

title: Hawaii All-Star Lineup Ready to Roll
description: The 16-driver lineup is almost set for the first running of the Hawaiian Super Gran Prix, a 100-mile race with a $1 million first prize that is scheduled for Jan. 24 in Honolulu.

title: Dense-Pac Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net lossThe company is listed on the Nasdaq Small Cap.

title: Bowl America reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Fernandez to Let Students Transfer to Any District
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez will let parents send their children to any school outside their district throughout New York City's five boroughs next year, giving the city one of the largest school-choice arrangements in the nation.

title: Emilia-Romagna: What Italians Say To Mean 'The Best'
description: THE Emilia-Romagna region is Italy's culinary heartland, a broad chunk of terrain that almost spans the peninsula north of Tuscany and south of the Alps. But despite its fame among Italians, the region is almost unknown elsewhere and is seldom visited by tourists who speed across the great fertile plain of the Po valley en route from Florence to Venice or Milan, unaware of the gastronomic treasures they are passing by.

title: The Agonies of Waiting for the Thrill of Victory
description: First it looked as though Robert Abrams was winning, and then it seemed equally clear that Geraldine A. Ferraro was ahead, and then it all swung back again. With every turn in a truly topsy-turvy evening, the spirit at the headquarters of both front-runners soared and plunged in dizzying succession.

title: Alimentation Couche-Tard reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Behavior Therapy Can Change How the Brain Functions, Researchers Say
description: Like drug therapy, behavior modification therapy produces metabolic and functional changes in the brains of people with obsessive compulsive disorder, scientists are reporting today.

title: Light Sentences Against Germans Who Killed Foreigner Stir Debate
description: Light sentences handed down this week to five youths found guilty in the beating death of an African immigrant have touched off a political debate in Germany.

title: Cooper Companies reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included losses on sale of discontinued operations of $ 934,000 and $ 2,300,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the quarter also included an extraordinary charge of $ 318,000.c-Included extraordinary credits which reflected the purchase of certain of the company's 105/8 percent debentures of $ 1,553,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 5,428,000, or 21 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: A Cheaper Way of Linking Offices
description: Anticipating adoption of the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Mexican telephone company is about to initiate a sophisticated network service that should make it easier for multinational corporations to do business with, and within, Mexico.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RICHARD DREYFUSS, the Academy-Award-winning actor, has filed for divorce from his wife of nine years, JERAMIE RAIN DREYFUSS. Richard Grant, a spokesman for the star, said yesterday that "the agreement to part was mutual and amicable."

title: Round Two: D'Amato Takes Aim At Opponent
description: Even before he found out that Robert Abrams would most likely be his Democratic opponent, Republican Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato was spewing venom in Mr. Abrams's direction.

title: Advanced Photonix Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Advanced Photonix said that about $ 250,000 of its losses in the latest first quarter were associated with the assimilation the Advanced Optoelectronics product line, acquired March 8, and other non-recurring charges.

title: Light Trucks Pace Rise in Vehicle Sales
description: Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks rose 10.1 percent in early September, though car sales remained stuck at a fairly low level.

title: REP. SOLARZ LOSES IN A NEW DISTRICT
description: United States Representative Stephen J. Solarz, the nine-term incumbent from Brooklyn, was defeated for re-election last night by Nydia M. Velazquez, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico's former representative in New York, in a Democratic primary. Ms. Velazquez was thus virtually assured of becoming the first Hispanic woman elected to represent New York City in Congress.

title: The Athletics Hammer In the Last Nail
description: The Oakland Athletics may have approached their series with the Minnesota Twins with cautious optimism, but it was obvious tonight that there was no need for restraint.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Overview; Bush Subtly Avoids Direct Attack Against Clinton on the Draft Issue
description: In a day marked by some of the most subtle political jousting of the campaign, President Bush today took note of the controversy over Gov. Bill Clinton's draft record but said he did not want to attack his opponent over it. Instead, he invited an audience of National Guard officers to compare the candidates' credentials to be Commander in Chief.

title: CHINA-JAPAN LINK ON MISSILES SEEN
description: The Toshiba Machine Company, which was penalized by the United States for selling equipment that helped the Soviet Union silence its submarines in the 1980's, also sold a machine that may now be helping China build better missiles, a Japanese magazine reports.

title: French Vote Puts Eurocrats on Trial
description: It was not long ago that Margaret Thatcher, when she was British Prime Minister, was being dismissed by her European partners as an eccentric nationalist for her fierce attacks on the unelected bureaucrats who run the European Community's executive commission here.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Comerica Inc. is offering $150 million of senior bank notes with a 5.95 percent coupon at 99.963 to yield 5.959 percent, through Kidder, Peabody & Co. The noncallable notes are rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.& P. * Conagra Inc. is offering $300 million of 7.40 percent 12-year subordinated-debt securities at 99.676 to yield 7.441 percent, through First Boston Corp. The noncallable securities are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB- by S.& P.

title: Rangers' Kovalev Is Fast Becoming Americanized
description: Aleksei Kovalev left behind his family, his girlfriend, his skates. By midseason, he hopes, he will still be in New York, reunited with all but his skates.

title: Islanders' Pay Mirrors Performance
description: In the 22-team National Hockey League last season, the Islanders finished 14th in the overall standing and dead last in home attendance.

title: Holtzman and Ferraro Fought Double Standards as Well as Each Other
description: In this year in which so much attention has been paid to the role and prospects of women in politics, New York's Democratic Senate primary, pitting Geraldine A. Ferraro against Elizabeth Holtzman, was always a centerpiece of discussion and a source of awkward pride. Feminists and voters who said that women might be the ones to bring about significant political change saw it, from the start, as proof of changing times.

title: Theater in Review
description: The Adding Machine Joseph Papp Public Theater 425 Lafayette Street Greenwich Village Today Written by Elmer Rice; directed by Michael Schwabe; original music composition by Evan Chen; technical direction and stage management by James Rossow; design and construction by Mr. Basgall, Kevin Byrne, Pam Clouse, Richard Goodman, John Gegenhuber, Pat O'Hara, Cynthia Orthal, Timm Reinhard, Mr. Rossow, Mr. Schwabe and Jayson Stahl. A Jim Henson Foundation presentation of Puppetry at the Public: The International Festival of Puppet Theater, executive producer, Cheryl Henson; producing director, Leslee Asch; associate producers, Bill Yates and Anne Dennin. WITH: Tracey Gilbert, Dave Herzog, Mr. Basgall and Mr. Schwabe.

title: How to Make Presidency and Congress Work; Parliamentary Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Harry F. Gaugh Dies; Art Professor Was 53
description: Harry F. Gaugh, a professor of art at Skidmore College and a specialist in the Abstract Expressionist period, died on Saturday at Glens Falls Hospital in Glens Falls, N.Y. He was 53 years old and lived in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: Datapoint Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: There were no share earnings in the latest year after preferred dividends.

title: Lincoln Center Nominates Programming Director
description: Lincoln Center's 14-month search for a new director of programming has apparently come to an end. Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center, said yesterday that he would nominate Jane S. Moss for the post at a Lincoln Center board of directors meeting on Monday. He said that he expected the board to vote immediately on the nomination, and that if the board approved her, she would take over the institution's programming before the end of the year.

title: Birtcher Medical Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included pre-tax charges of $ 2,000,000 and $ 6,600,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.c-Net incomeThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Wine Talk
description: SEPTEMBER is the beginning of the wine-shopping season. More money will be spent on wine -- and spirits, too -- from now until Christmas than in all the other months combined.

title: Anthony Perkins's Wife Tells of 2 Years of Secrecy
description: For two years Anthony Perkins and his wife, Berry Berenson, kept silent that the actor was dying of AIDS. "He simply never wanted anyone to know," Ms. Berenson said in an interview at their home today. "He figured if anyone knew they'd never give him work again."

title: Foreigners Didn't Cause German Violence; No Immigration Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Bashing, the Quayle Way
description: Hatred of gay Americans was written into the Republican Party platform and trumpeted from the speakers' podium in Houston. Vice President Quayle didn't initiate these ugly sentiments but he exploited them in his convention speech and afterward, right along with the arch-practitioners Pat Robertson and Patrick Buchanan.

title: Senate Votes to Rebuild Base Destroyed by Storm
description: The Senate voted today to rebuild a vastly scaled-down Homestead Air Force Base into a mostly civilian complex, which would provide some relief toSouth Florida and head off a political quarrel.

title: Food Notes
description: Restaurant Sauce at Home

title: Baseball's Charade
description: If you read the weepy testimonials in the sporting press, you probably think that the sacking of Commissioner Fay Vincent by the owners of the major league teams has severely weakened the once powerful office of the commissioner to the extreme detriment of baseball fans, who were supposedly protected by the commissioner's benevolent rule "in the best interests of baseball."

title: Insurer to Buy Olympia Office Tower
description: Four days after New York City signed a bill granting tax breaks to property owners who modernize aging office buildings, Mutual of America said it had reached an agreement to buy and improve a vacant office tower on 320 Park Avenue from Olympia & York Developments Ltd..

title: Brown Promoted 8 in Last Days
description: Days before leaving his post as Police Commissioner, Lee P. Brown promoted eight members of the security detail that guarded him, six of them without the usual practice of giving notice in the New York City Police Department's interoffice memorandums.

title: Ogilvy Adams Loses 2 Executives
description: The Ogilvy Adams & Rinehart public relations firm suffered a blow as two top executives at its New York office left to form their own public relations shop.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Harold Louis Humes, a novelist, misidentified one of his children. Devin Loman is one of Mr. Humes's two sons; Mr. Humes also had three daughters.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Holtzman Defends Her Losing Strategy
description: Elizabeth Holtzman, the New York City Comptroller, tried last night to put the best face on her last-place finish in the Democratic Senate primary, even though voters dealt her a stunning blow by giving her less support than the Rev. Al Sharpton, who ran third.

title: Dr. Julius W. Bell, 91, Specialist and Teacher
description: Dr. Julius W. Bell, an ear, nose and throat specialist who practiced and taught in Manhattan for 56 years, died on Sept. 8 at Memorial Hospital in Hollywood, Fla. He was 91 years old and had moved to Hollywood from Manhattan when he retired eight years ago.

title: Federal Reserve Goes Astray on Recession
description: To the Editor:

title: Struggling With Those Who Seek the Virgin Mary; Reported Vision Has Brought Grumbling and Expenses to Officials in Marlboro Township
description: Until Joseph Januszkiewicz started reporting visions of the Virgin Mary near the blue spruce trees in his yard, local government was free to devote its energies to earthly matters like repaving roads or recruiting volunteer firefighters.

title: A Hidden Disaster Grows In Sudan, Aid Officials Say
description: As relief agencies and diplomats struggle to deal with the famine in Somalia, they say a huge disaster, largely hidden from the world, has developed across the southern Sudan.

title: Biaggi Fails in His Bid to Return to Congress
description: Having tested the limits of political redemption, Mario Biaggi wearily conceded last night that voters' unwillingness to forgive and forget his felonies contributed to his overwhelming defeat in the Democratic primary in the 17th District to the incumbent, Eliot L. Engel.

title: Dinkins Tries To Heal Rift With Police On Shooting
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins used the Police Department's annual medal day ceremony yesterday to reach out to police officers in an attempt to heal a rift caused by his visit to the family of a drug suspect who was fatally shot by a police officer in Washington Heights.

title: Public & Private; Great Expectations
description: When liberal Democrats talk about the Presidential election these days, they seem a bit like the bride determined that the groom not see her before the ceremony. They fear a jinx -- the jinx of optimism in this, their best-chance year in many years.

title: Personal Health
description: ONE of the most serious and costly epidemics in America today arouses almost no public concern and is all but ignored by health officials. Unlike AIDS or polio, it is not caused by infection and it can be cured. But few have put their minds to bringing it under control.

title: The Pop Life
description: Rhythmic Additives

title: Koala Technologies reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 54,300.c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 55,400.

title: Red Object Sighted Beyond Pluto May Be Part of Minor Planet Belt
description: Astronomers have detected a small, faint object beyond Neptune and Pluto that could be the first direct evidence for the existence of a broad belt of icy minor planets that is presumably the source of many comets streaking in from the fringes of the solar system.

title: Weiss Wins, Biaggi Loses In House Bids
description: Voters in New York's Congressional primaries last night rejected Mario Biaggi, a convicted felon aiming for a political comeback in the Bronx, and handed victory to Ted Weiss, a dead man whose selection will allow Democratic Party leaders to designate someone else to run in his place in November.

title: 150 Miles Away, the Doctor Is Examining Your Tonsils
description: On the television screen in the small room at the Medical College of Georgia here an image jumped and jerked as, 150 miles away, a doctor brought an instrument into position in the ear of a patient.

title: Cassell Expects to Stay on Job
description: OLLAN CASSELL, executive director of The Athletics Congress, the governing body for track and field in the United States, will very likely remain in his position at least two more years after a committee of officials voted to retain him during meetings over the weekend in Denver. All that remains for Cassell, the only person to serve in his capacity since the late 1970's, to continue serving is formal approval by the board of directors of the congress at its annual convention in December. Approval is expected.

title: AT THE DOOR WITH: Drew Nieporent; The Restaurateur As Diplomat And Rising Star
description: "HI, how are you?"

title: Trenton Legislator to Offer Bill To Lift Some Speed Limits to 65
description: Fresh from an overwhelming victory in banning photo radar from New Jersey's highways, Assemblyman Steven Mikulak now says he will introduce a bill that would raise the speed limit on 400 miles of state highways to 65 miles an hour.

title: American Film Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net lossThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Acklands Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a loss on the sale of fixed assets of $ 139,000 for the quarter and $ 252,000 for the 6 months.c-Included a loss on the sale of fixed assets of $ 72,000 and $ 154,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CRAY RESEARCH AND MOTOROLA INC. FORM A CHIP VENTURE
description: Cray Research Inc. and Motorola Inc. said yesterday that they had formed a partnership to develop application-specific integrated circuits, a chip designed to perform certain tasks. The agreement stems from a long-term customer-supplier relationship between the two companies, in which Motorola has produced high-performance chips for many of Cray's supercomputers. Cray will apply Motorola's manufacturing knowledge to construct and operate a new chip-production operation in Chippewa Falls, Wis.

title: Simi Valley Journal; Spotlight of Trial Fades, Leaving Sense of Peace
description: Beneath multi-colored tents dotting the parking lot of a drive-in theater here, there was more brewing than the pots of chili competing for first place in the annual Simi Valley Days Festival.

title: Trade Pact vs. Environment: A Clash at a House Hearing
description: House Democrats and the Bush Administration clashed today over the environmental impact of the North American Free Trade Agreement, with lawmakers asserting that safeguards are inadequate and the Administration acknowledging that the treaty would prevent the United States from directly enforcing tough conservation rules in Mexico.

title: Mills Accepts $10 Million Piston Offer
description: Terry Mills took a giant, if indirect, step toward landing a lucrative contract with the Nets yesterday by accepting a five-year, $10 million offer from the Detroit Pistons.

title: New Environmental Debate Expected as U.N. Convenes
description: A new round of disputes over environmental issues, pitting the United States and Western Europe against developing countries, is expected to be a major theme of the 47th United Nations General Assembly, which opened today.

title: At Work, High Above the Fast Track
description: IVOR HANSON, a 28-year-old admiral's son, Vassar graduate and musician, makes his living by washing windows and so knows a lot about the fear of falling.

title: As Tensions Rise, Lebanese Resume Exodus
description: Lebanese are again leaving the country by the thousands because of recurring political tension, a worsening economic crisis and soaring unemployment.

title: U.S. Regulators Scale Back Rise In Banking Fees
description: Bowing to political pressure, Federal regulators today cut in half a proposed increase in the insurance premiums that banks pay to the deposit insurance fund -- and exempted three-quarters of the industry from any increase at all.

title: Cable TV Regulation Battle Heats Up Before Showdown
description: As opposing sides intensified their lobbying on a bill to regulate cable television prices and accused each other of deception, a leading House Democrat charged today that it would cost consumers heavily and vowed to fight it.

title: Accounts
description: * J. P. Morgan & Co., New York, to Goldsmith/Jeffrey Inc., New York, to handle its United States private banking advertising account, previously in-house. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Aura Systems Inc. reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
description: Aura Systems said that its results for the latest fiscal year reflected increases in pre-production tooling and related labor costs, indirect costs from the growth of its business, and about $ 1 million of year-end adjustments associated with discontinued activities.The company also said that the loss reflected the restatement of income to exclude $ 996,000 previously reported by the company in the third quarter related to the sale of part of its investment in Aura Medical Systems.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: A Crack! But It Wasn't From Bonilla's Bat
description: The afternoon sky was as black as night. Wind swirled through Wrigley Field and lightning zigzagged crazily against the Chicago skyline.

title: Executive Changes
description: BIDERMANN INDUSTRIES, New York, a unit of Bidermann International that manufactures men's and women's apparel, named Edward Gilgallon executive vice president for merchandising. GOODY PRODUCTS INC., Kearny, N.J., a maker of hair accessories, named John A. Creel senior vice president for marketing in the United States.

title: Killearn Properties reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Right Out of the 60's, With Plenty of Hair, But Actually Dressed (Mostly in Versace)
description: IT was, as they used to say, a happening. Monday night's "Rock n' Rule," Gianni Versace's combination benefit fashion show and rock concert (with a bit of rap and rave thrown in), was both a throwback to the 1960's and a this-minute way to present his outrageous designs.

title: Owners Play a Game In Which the Rules Are Forever Changing
description: Consistency has never been one of the strengths of the club owners. They demand it of the players whom they pay millions of dollars; they demand it of their managers and general managers, and if they don't get it, they fire them. But if scouts were rating the owners on consistency, like they rate players on power, speed and defense, the numbers next to their names would be low. They would be labeled "no prospect."

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ohio Voters; Smattering of Fire but Mostly Unease in a District That Bush Carried in '88
description: A few weeks ago, Jane Shade got so scared at what she saw on the nightly news that she did something she had never done before: she registered to vote.

title: Senate Contest Isn't Over Till Absentee Votes Are In
description: Local election boards will count hundreds of absentee ballots next week to determine the final tally in the election for the Democratic nomination for the Senate.

title: Eagle-Picher Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss and the 9 months included provision of $ 12.5 million for Mat division closing.

title: William L. Dill; Lawyer, 89
description: William L. Dill, a lawyer and a former mayor of Montclair, N.J., died on Monday at his home in Upper Montclair, N.J. He was 89 years old.

title: Review/Music; The Tully Behind The Hall Turns 90
description: Nelson A. Rockefeller once introduced her as Miss Alice Tully Hall. She piloted planes for the Civil Air Patrol during the Second World War. She had a 14-year career as a dramatic soprano in Europe and the United States. She is a second cousin of Katharine Hepburn, the niece of an Ambassador to the Court of St. James's and a granddaughter of the founder of Corning Glass.

title: Highland Superstores reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included restructuring charge of $ 58,056,000 for the quarter and $ 68,556,000 for the 6 months.

description: b-Net loss

description: b-Net incomeThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Jaco Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net lossThe company listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Book Notes
description: Full Circle

title: Sales Drop, But Inflation Stays Low
description: American consumers remain extraordinarily reluctant to spend, and that reluctance is helping to hold inflation down to the levels of the 1960's.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: WHEN I was the chef at Le Pavillon restaurant in Manhattan, we offered a selection of egg dishes at lunch every day. It might have been eggs en cocotte with fresh herbs, eggs en gelee (aspic) with various seasonings, cold omelets with savory fillings and more. They were among the most popular items we served. You rarely see these dishes on menus today, partly because of health concerns, partly because eggs have simply fallen out of fashion.

title: Hideo Gosha; Film Director, 63
description: Hideo Gosha, a film director known for his samurai movies, died on Aug. 30 at a hospital in Kyoto, Japan. He was 63 years old.

title: Internet Communications reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A.T.&T. Sees Profit for Unit
description: The chief executives of A.T.&T. and NCR said yesterday that the two companies' $7.5 billion merger a year ago and that A.T.&T.'s computer operations, troubled for much of the 1980's, would be profitable in 1992.

title: Market Place; Tracing the Trail Of Perfume Money
description: EVEN with its dull-sounding name, a Schedule 13-D is greeted on Wall Street with the kind of breathless excitement that usually reserved for a royal scandal. The filing, required of investors who acquire more than 5 percent of a company, is the calling card of takeover bids, often touching off sharp run-ups in a company's stock.

title: No Headline
description: "There is just no feasible way that is environmentally safe and sound to get rid of all this stuff." -- DAVID P. MAZUR, on the trash problem in Homestead, Fla. [ A16:4. ]

title: Stocks, Off 48.90, Give Back Much of Gains
description: Wall Street's euphoria over Germany's interest rate cuts evaporated yesterday as it had in Europe. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 48.90 points, or 1.4 percent, to 3,327.32, consuming more than two-thirds of Monday's 70.52-point gain, the year's largest.

title: Edward J. Grenier; Lawyer, 87
description: Edward J. Grenier, a lawyer who practiced in New York City for more than 50 years, died on Sept. 11 at his home. He was 87 years old.

title: Review/Television; Seinfeld's Quirky Road to Reality
description: Tonight at 9 on NBC, "Seinfeld" returns with a special one-hour episode to open its new season and to demonstrate once again that if you're looking for quirkiness, the hot prime-time commodity of the moment, you don't necessarily have to send a nice Jewish boy to Alaska. You can keep him in a nondescript New York City apartment and just let him shmooze with a gaggle of somewhat odd but entirely recognizable friends. What's more, "Seinfeld" has to be a lot cheaper to produce than "Northern Exposure."

title: After Death, Victory for Weiss and His Party
description: Even though he died on Monday, Representative Ted Weiss won the Democratic primary in the Eighth District yesterday, after a day in which residents of his base on the Upper West Side struggled to suppress the feeling that voting for him this time was macabre, ridiculous or even somehow illegal.

title: How to Make Presidency and Congress Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Umm el Fahm Journal; Winds of Islam Sweep Israel, Changing Landscape
description: The golden dome of an imposing new mosque soars above the narrow streets and crowded buildings of this Arab town, boldly proclaiming its return to Islam.

title: HESS STORES, TRYING TO EASE LOSSES, WILL SELL 11 STORES
description: Hess Department Stores Inc. agreed yesterday to sell three stores to Dillard Department Stores and eight to Proffitt's Inc. in an effort to stem losses. Hess, a unit of the closely held Crown American Corporation in Johnstown, Pa., is selling nine stores in eastern Tennessee, one in Bristol, Va., and one in Asheville, N.C. Dillard said it expects to close its deal in November, while Proffitt's, a family-owned chain, expects to complete its transaction within 60 days. After the sales, Hess will have 62 stores concentrated in the Northeast. A spokesman said the Allentown, Pa., company has no plans to sell any more stores right now.

title: Cott Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Foreigners Didn't Cause German Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Hi-Tech Pharmacal Co. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
POPULATION POLICY IN ASIA IS FAULTED
description: Serious flaws in family-planning programs in China and India make it unlikely that the world's two most populous nations will be able to stabilize growth until well into the next century, by which time they may have added more than 1.5 billion people to the world's population, according to findings published this week by the independent Population Crisis Committee.

title: Stocks Fall as Markets Rethink German Role
description: One day after Germany's central bank grudgingly nudged its interest rates down, financial markets across Europe and in the United States fell today as investors concluded that the Bundesbank by itself could not foster economic recovery or ease currency strains.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Big Plans Are Swept Away by Hurricane Andrew
description: The financial losses from Hurricane Andrew can be reckoned in two ways: in the brain-numbing aggregate of billions of dollars or in the suddenly changed life circumstances and plans of people like Jose Garcia.

title: Chief at Troubled J. I. Case Stepping Down
description: Tenneco Inc. said yesterday that the chairman and chief executive of J. I. Case, its troubled agricultural and construction equipment manufacturer, was stepping down.

title: Pentagon Says a Rescue Helicopter Was Fired On in Bosnia
description: A Marine Corps helicopter that was dispatched to the crash site of an Italian relief plane in Bosnia earlier this month was struck by small-arms fire, the Pentagon said today.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Iraqi Bank-Fraud Scheme Described
description: The case of an Atlanta banker involved in a huge fraud has shed light on the remarkably sophisticated system set up by Iraq to illegally obtain billions of dollars in loans in the United States, some of which was vital to Saddam Hussein's arms buildup.

title: U.S. Clears Use of Gene Therapy Against a Form of Lung Cancer
description: The first gene therapy treatment for lung cancer received the unanimous approval of an important Federal panel yesterday, bringing the once-rarefied and experimental science of manipulating human genes to bear on the most common cause of cancer death in America.

title: F.B.I. Forms Unit to Battle 'Carjacking'
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that the armed theft of cars from drivers was becoming such a serious problem nationwide that his agency was adding it to the list of violent crimes being handled by a special force of agents.

title: Brook Johnson Captures Republican Senate Race
description: Brook Johnson, a millionaire business executive from Greenwich who was completely unknown in Connecticut politics until he announced his candidacy last May, scored a decisive victory yesterday in the Republican primary for the United States Senate.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: BALLY's GRAND INC., a unit of the Bally Manufacturing Corp., Chicago, the casino, hotel and fitness center operator, said a Federal Bankruptcy Court in New Jersey had approved its reorganization plan. COMCAST CORP. , a cellular and cable television company, bought 3.57 million shares of Fleet Call Inc. at $14 each.

title: Owners Convince Bankers They Are Not Risky Borrowers
description: Bankers who have extended major league baseball clubs a $260 million line of credit received assurances yesterday that everything is running smoothly despite the departure of Commissioner Fay Vincent.

title: ITT Names Chief Financial Officer
description: The ITT Corporation named Robert A. Bowman chief financial officer yesterday, a year and a half after he joined the $21 billion conglomerate from his previous job as treasurer for the state of Michigan.

title: With New Design Chief, G.M. Quiets Speculation
description: The General Motors Corporation named Wayne K. Cherry its new vice president of design staff today, filling a key position that oversees how all G.M. cars and trucks look, as well as their comfort and styling characteristics.

title: Letter: On Trade; Just a Push to End Arab Boycott of Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: For Sheet Music, Just Pick a Key And Print It Out
description: Music may soothe the savage breast, but generating the soothing sounds can be savagely difficult, particularly when transposing sheet music to a different key. For all but expert musicians, the job can take several hours.

title: Bond Prices Stage a Broad Retreat
description: The bond market, many traders are saying, has had too much of a good thing: bad news on the economy and positive news on inflation. And now, after a vibrant rally, slow economic growth and declining inflation is just not enough to keep the climb going.

title: Campus Journal; Twin Goals: $250,000 for AIDS and a Lofty Peak
description: Thinking about his passion for mountain climbing and his desire to raise money for AIDS research, Alex Friedman did what undergraduates like himself are often taught to do in college: he reached for the interconnectedness of things.

title: Yields Fall At Banks
description: Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates were down for the week ended today, The Bank Rate Monitor said in its most recent survey.

title: School-Choice Plan On Ballot in Colorado Puts State in Spotlight
description: In the newest battleground over "school choice," a ballot initiative in Colorado would give parents up to $2,500 in public money each year to cover the expense of private or parochial schools and even of educating a child at home.

title: Motorman Goes to Trial in Subway Deaths
description: In a case that led to random drug and alcohol testing of bus and subway operators, opening arguments in the murder trial of the motorman charged with killing five passengers in a subway derailment at the Union Square Station are to be presented tomorrow in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 THE SUFFERING OF SUDAN

title: McCormick & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After income from unconsolidated operations of $ 2,368,000 in the quarter and $ 7,439,000 in the 9 months; the 9 months also included gain on sale of industrial cleaning supply business of $ 1.9 million, or 2 cents a share.c-After income from unconsolidated operations of $ 2,292,000 in the quarter and $ 6,955,000 in the 9 months.Shares outstanding were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in January 1992.Sales represented net sales.

title: Balkan Tribalism, as Uganda Sees It
description: The Speke Hotel is one of the few spots in Kampala that recall its colonial past. A couple of trophies from safari days are still displayed in the dusty lobby with its well-worn armchairs. People drink beer at rickety tables on the terrace. The beer is cheap and good. Perhaps that's the reason it's a place where you run into local intellectuals, who scrape by working at absurdly low salaries and moonlighting -- a bureaucrat from the Ministry of Information, a professor of literature who studied in Glasgow and Berlin, a dramatist who has taken refuge in state-run television and a lawyer who would prefer to be a historian.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Two Spaniards Are Upset in Bordeaux

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Poll; Clinton Retains a Wide Lead in Latest Survey
description: Despite President Bush's efforts to rebuild his political base, Gov. Bill Clinton is holding on to both a significant lead in this race and the support of important elements of the Reagan-Bush coalition, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Eating Well
description: FROM juicy 10-ounce strip steaks and prime rib to meatloaf and quarter-pound charbroiled hamburgers, meat is a major contributor of saturated fat and cholesterol to American diets.

title: PDG Environmental Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net lossYear-ago periods' results were after an extraordinary credit of 4 cents a share.Share earnings for the latest quarter and year-ago period are after preferred dividend requirements of $ 225,000.The latest 6 months and year-ago period's results are after preferred dividend requirements of $ 450,000.The latest revenues' results were benefited by the acquisition of Enviro-Tech, which was effective April 1, 1992.

title: Alpine Group reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from extinguishment of debt of $ 422,000, or 6 cents a share.Latest figures included the results of Dataproducts New England, acquired in February.

title: Giants Coach Does A Quick About-Face
description: No matter what he tries, it hasn't been coming out right for Coach Ray Handley -- with his players or with the public.

title: Bracknell Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a tax loss carry-forward of $ 724,000 in the quarter and $ 2,633,000 in the 9 months.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ambulatory Medical Care reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Brown Seeks Endowments for 65 Junior Professors
description: In what is believed to be the first attempt of its kind, Brown University will try to create 65 endowed chairs for assistant professors, the university's president announced last night. Such chairs are usually reserved for full professors of senior stature.

title: 2 KURDISH PARTIES AGREE TO MERGER
description: In a major step toward further centralizing power in Kurdish-controlled northern Iraq, the Kurds' two main political parties agreed today to merge their guerrilla units into a single force under Kurdish Government command, officials said.

title: Emergency Response Kept a Company Going
description: To the Editor:

title: Symbols That Win, or Lose, Consumers' Seal of Approval
description: WHAT'S in a name? Never mind, it's what's in a logo that matters.

title: Input/Output Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Official of Christian Party Is Kidnapped in East Beirut
description: A senior official of Lebanon's largest Christian party was kidnapped today.

title: A Broccoli Sauce a la Pesto, With Far Less Fat
description: BROCCOLI fans will think that this recipe for pasta sauce is the greatest thing since President Bush trashed the vegetable and gave it a high profile.

title: Ex-Albanian Chief Seeks Help
description: Albania's former Communist President, Ramiz Alia, has appealed to international organizations for protection after being placed under house arrest, Tirana radio said today. It said Mr. Alia had sent letters to international organizations and to some individual foreigners to protest against confinement in his Tirana villa.

title: Voicing Confidence, Italian Leader Bets on French 'Yes' to Europe
description: Six days before a French referendum on the treaty on European union, the Italian Prime Minister, Giuliano Amato, said today that he believed that the chances of a "yes" vote were strengthening and that his own country would ratify the pact whatever the outcome in France.

title: Jets Wait for Thomas to Turn Handoff Into Liftoff
description: Stop the run on defense. Run the ball on offense.

title: Economists View Election
description: A poll published on Monday by the National Association of Business Economists found two-thirds of the membership expecting that the Democratic nominee, Bill Clinton, would be elected in November and that economic growth under him would probably be higher than during a second Bush term.

title: Oracle Picks Ex-General As Chairman
description: The Oracle Corporation, the world's largest supplier of data base software, today named James Abrahamson chairman of the board. He succeeds Lawrence J. Ellison, Oracle's co-founder, who continues as president and chief executive.

title: Serbian Snipers Content to Let Sarajevo Just Bleed
description: From the Serbian sniper position known as No. 8, a bombed-out nightclub that has been converted into a heavily protected bunker, there is a magnificent view of this besieged city along the banks of the Miljacka River.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A dance-company poster might seem an unlikely item for an astronaut to carry into space, but Dr. MAE C. JEMISON, now on the shuttle Endeavor, was determined to bring along some memento of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

title: Bridge
description: The most prolific author of bridge books in North America is Mike Lawrence of Kensington Calif., a former world team champion. Two of his recent efforts provide the serious enthusiast with a wealth of practical advice on bidding, covering areas that are neglected elsewhere in the literature of the game. They are "Contested Auctions" and "Bidding Quizzes: The Uncontested Auction." They are available for $17.20 and $16.05 respectively, including mailing, from The Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025.

title: Helen A. Wilson, 79, Leader in Refugee Aid
description: Helen A. Wilson, a retired executive for international refugee and development agencies, died Friday at her house in Washington. She was 79 years old.

title: Cytel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represented total revenues.

title: Homestead's Bonfire Consumes Hurricane Debris
description: From where Ed Hawtree sits, high up on his bulldozer, ramming the mangled remains of somebody's house -- a carpet, a record player, a red striped Hula Hoop -- straight into a 15-foot-high wall of fire, it is like barging right into hell.

title: Detroit & Canada Tunnel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HEWLETT-PACKARD CARRIES OUT A COST-CUT PLAN
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, Palo Alto, Calif., a manufacturer of computers and test and measurement products, will attempt to reverse its disappointing third-quarter performance with a new four-point cost-cutting program. The plan, approved by top executives last month and disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, instructs divisional managers to cut costs by these steps: closing plants at Christmas for about a week, using fewer temporary workers, requiring workers to take a day off without pay every two weeks, or moving workers from slow-growing to fast-growing businesses.

title: Vehicle Ban On S.I. Ferry Is Planned
description: New York City has decided to ban vehicles permanently from the Staten Island Ferry to discourage motorists from driving to Manhattan and to allow for a $112 million renovation of the ferry's downtown terminal.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A FRIEND writes:

title: Brady (W.H.) Co. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included non-recurring charges of $ 5,431,000 and $ 6,562,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included an accounting charge of $ 3,334,000 related to post-retirement benefits and income taxes.c-Net incomeThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Have Archives, Will Travel
description: There is nothing dashing about William Asadorian, the brainy archivist tucked back in the main Queens Public Library. At 44, his hair is crawling farther from his forehead each year, and he still cannot seem to knot his tie flat; its muted colors tumble over a paunch that mocks all bypassed lunches.

title: Foodarama Supermarkets reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Laser Recording Systems reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Gotti Is Still Crime Boss, U.S. Asserts
description: John Gotti is continuing to run the Gambino crime family from his maximum-security prison cell, using relatives to relay orders to Gambino members, Federal prosecutors say.

title: With X Gone, T. C. Looks to Garden Stage
description: So the X-Man's gone. Don't nobody fret. T. C.'s here to be the new Top Cat. Tony Campbell didn't put it exactly that way yesterday, but the newest Knick came close.

title: Real Estate; Philadelphia Arts Area Gets Boost
description: AN insurance company's gift of a building to a theater company in Philadelphia has provided a small boost to the city's longstanding efforts to strengthen downtown theater attractions.

title: Bill Clinton's Vietnam Test, Cont'd.
description: President Bush had the grace to say in his speech to the National Guard Association yesterday that never to have seen "the awful horror of battle" did not mean "you can never be Commander in Chief." By forgoing a more frontal attack on Bill Clinton's record of draft avoidance, Mr. Bush conveyed an impression of moral magnanimity.

title: Vote for Incinerator Let All New Yorkers Down
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Simple End to Summer, It's Fish the Light Basque Way
description: IN this simple, light menu still suggestive of summer, whiting is featured in a main dish inspired by the cooking of the Basques, the people of northern Spain and southwest France. Whiting, or merluza, as the Basques call it, is plentiful and inexpensive in that region and in most parts of the United States. If you can't find it, substitute another economical species -- perhaps porgy or bluefish, providing it is fresh.

title: Leader Gone, Maoists Still Stalk Lima Slums
description: They came early this morning, a band of about five or six Shining Path rebels. The people of this shantytown some 12 miles west of Lima awoke to find their walls daubed with dozens of revolutionary slogans and praises of the rebel leader, Abimael Guzman Reynoso.

title: INSIDE
description: Stock Rally Is Reversed; Limits Seen to German Role

title: Reso Kidnapper Admits State Charges
description: A week after confessing his crimes in Federal Court, Arthur D. Seale pleaded guilty today to state kidnapping charges in the abduction and death of the Exxon executive Sidney J. Reso.

title: Militello's Masterpiece Ruined by Monteleone
description: Dead arm? Who were the Yankees trying to fool when they rested rookie Sam Militello for the last 10 days and said his right arm was dead? The only thing dead about last night was the procession of White Sox hitters who were fooled by Militello's crafty pitching.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JUDD HIRSCH, the actor, has had his share of cancellations, but he's feeling good about the one that he will experience today. To honor Mr. Hirsch's Tony-Award-winning role in "Conversations With My Father," the United States Postal Service is producing a special commemorative stamp cancellation for Citizenship Day, which is tomorrow. This afternoon, from noon to 4 P.M., a postal truck will be parked in front of the Royale Theater, at 242 West 45th Street, where the public can have their mail marked with the one-time-only cancellation showing Mr. Hirsch in the play, about an immigrant from Russia who raises two sons on the Lower East Side.

title: Mutual Fund Sues Westinghouse Credit
description: A Boston-based mutual fund has sued the Westinghouse Credit Corporation to recover about $61.2 million it paid for stock in the closely held bankrupt discount drugstore chain Phar-Mor Inc.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Admar Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: METRO DIGEST
description: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN ABRAMS APPEARS TO WIN PRIMARY

title: Two Weeks Late, but DuBose Has a Clash Schedule
description: On a bright, warm late-summer afternoon last Saturday, the kind that seemed perfect for opening the gates at Notre Dame Stadium, Demetrius DuBose found himself in the wrong place at the wrong time.

title: Fastcomm Communications reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DISPUTED OFFICIAL SEATED IN MEXICO
description: A Governor from the ruling party took office here today in the most important bastion of the Mexican left, ending at least a chapter in the conflict over a crucial state election and raising questions about the opposition's political future.

title: In a State Known for Landsides, There Have Been Tight Races
description: In New York politics, landslides are more common than races as close as yesterday's Democratic primary for the United States Senate. But the nerve-rackingly narrow margin that separated Robert Abrams and Geraldine A. Ferraro is by no means unique.

title: John Lahr Is Appointed New Yorker Drama Critic
description: John Lahr, a critic, biographer and author of books about the theater, has been named drama critic of The New Yorker, Tina Brown announced yesterday. He replaces Mimi Kramer, who will go back to writing features at her own request, said Ms. Brown, who becomes the magazine's editor at the end of this month.

title: Harvey Group reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $ 81,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 160,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Books of The Times; The Great Arts Debate In the Debaters' Words
description: Culture Wars Documents From the Recent Controversies in the Arts Edited by Richard Bolton Illustrated. 363 pages. New Press. Paperback, $19.95.

title: Too Young for Day Care
description: President Bush is expected to quickly veto the family leave bill, which passed the House last week, 241 to 161. The bill mandates that companies with 50 or more employees offer an unpaid, 12 week leave to workers with new or newly adopted children. It is unlikely that the veto will be overridden. Before this scenario unfolds, the President and his Congressional supporters should consider the results of the first large-scale national study of the effects of day care -- evidence that full-time day care, as against having a parent home, may harm children under the age of 1.

title: Managed Care Is More of What We Have Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Millicent Fenwick, 82, Dies; Gave Character to Congress
description: Millicent H. Fenwick, a retired Republican Congresswoman renowned for her political independence and championing of liberal causes, died yesterday at her home in Bernardsville, N.J. She was 82 years old.

title: Somalis Would Benefit From a Breakup
description: To the Editor:

title: Sonics May Be Eyeing Olajuwon Deal
description: The Seattle SuperSonics may be trying to make a trade for the disgruntled Houston Rockets center HAKEEM OLAJUWON. Olajuwon, a six-time All-Star who feuded with Houston management last season, has said he doesn't want to play for the Rockets this year.

title: Fed Action On Europe Not Expected
description: The turmoil in European's financial markets is primarily a European affair and the United States will not get involved in trying to help steady Europe's jitters, officials of the Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve said today.

title: A $4.5 Million Bid by Seville for Maradona
description: The Seville soccer team has offered Naples of the Italian league $4.5 million for the rights to the Argentine star DIEGO MARADONA, a Seville official said yesterday.

title: Amman Journal; In a Foreign Field, Iraqi Art Is Allowed to Flower
description: Each night one of the most eclectic crowds in Amman files into a theater to watch a play written by an Iraqi playwright and featuring a Jordanian actress.

title: Executive Changes
description: ALTEON INC., Northvale, N.J., a pharmaceutical company, appointed Dr. Jere E. Goyan senior vice president of research and development. GENPHARM U.S., Mountain View, Calif., a unit of Genpharm International Inc., appointed Dr. David L. Winter president and chief operating officer.

title: Page Takes Step Toward Judicial Post
description: The Hall of Famer ALAN PAGE made history on the football field. Now he is one step away from making history in Minnesota politics.

title: Bettors Can Now 'Screen' More of Their Picks
description: If you go to the Meadowlands this afternoon for a day at the races, you won't see any live horses on the track until 7:30 in the evening. But you can spend the afternoon sitting in front of television monitors and betting your money on 21 races beamed in from Pimlico in Maryland and Freehold in New Jersey.

title: U.S.-China Rift at Trade Talks Is Still Wide
description: American and Chinese negotiators concluded a third day of talks today on a number of contentious trade issues, but the two sides remained far apart on what could prove a landmark trade agreement.

title: Aggressive Spitters In Animation
description: Spike and Mike's Festival of Animation, the stylish potpourri of short animated films at the Cinema Village Third Avenue, bills itself as a survey of the latest achievements in animated film making. In fact, its centerpiece, "Dimensions in Dialogue," a disturbing 12-minute film by the noted Czechoslovak Surrealist Jan Svankmajer, was completed a decade ago.

title: G.M. and Other Companies Quit Tokyo Stock Market
description: In a blow to Tokyo's standing as a world financial center, the General Motors Corporation and four other large foreign companies announced separately today that they would stop selling their shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

title: Mitterrand Has Cancer; No Danger Is Seen
description: President Francois Mitterrand has prostate cancer, his doctors said today, but they said the illness was not life-threatening.

title: Review/Television; Cheating On Welfare, Cheerfully
description: The soft spot that television news usually shows for people on welfare is not evident in tonight's edition of "Prime Time Live." The subject of Diane Sawyer's tough-minded report is the cheaters whose number, she says, far exceeds the official figure of 2 percent. One investigator puts the figure at closer to 50 percent, and tonight's exposure of the ease with which the system can be bilked makes that seem plausible.

title: Matisse's 'Drawings With Scissors'
description: HENRI MATISSE'S art book "Jazz" is like his paintings: it cuts "to the quick in color," as Matisse wrote. The close-to-autobiographical book, first published in France in 1947 by Edition Teriade, was reissued this month in an oblong hardback format by George Braziller. The publication coincides with the Matisse retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, which opens on Sept. 24 and runs through Jan. 12.

title: U.S. Aides Propose $500,000 Fine for State Power Authority
description: Federal authorities yesterday proposed fining the New York State Power Authority $500,000, saying it had suffered "a significant breakdown in management and administrative control" at one of its nuclear reactors, the James A. Fitzpatrick plant in Scriba.

title: Halt the Verbal Abuse Of 'Special Interests'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Martin, Canadian Diplomat And Cabinet Stalwart, Dies at 89
description: Paul Martin, an enduring Liberal Party politician who for decades served in Canadian Cabinets and represented Ottawa at international gatherings, died on Monday at the Hotel Dieu Hospital in Windsor, Ontario. He was 89 years old.

title: Most House Primaries Defy Anti-Incumbent Mood
description: Though anti-incumbent attitudes are running higher than a decade ago, only two Representatives lost bids for renomination in primaries on Tuesday.

title: Nazi Hunter Says C.I.A. Has Files On Man Accused of War Crimes
description: A former lawyer with the Justice Department's Nazi-hunting unit has told the Central Intelligence Agency where he says it can find its own documents on a Ukrainian fascist leader whom it reportedly recruited and taken to the United States after World War II.

title: Events: Latin America, Architecture, Pottery
description: Latin Culture Museum of American Folk Art, Feld Gallery at 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at West 65th Street; (212) 977-7298.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Musica Maestro Dance Theater Workshop 219 West 19th Street Chelsea

title: Managed Care Is More of What We Have Now; Rochester's Example
description: To the Editor:

title: EUROPEANS' CURRENCY SYSTEM SHAKEN AS BRITAIN CUTS FREE
description: After a futile day of trying to defend the value of the pound, Britain dropped out of the European Monetary System on Wednesday, at least temporarily. Its departure from the monetary system, a cornerstone of greater European unity, left the program of economic coordination in tatters.

title: WORKERS APPROVE CONTRACT AT AMERITECH UNITS
description: Members of the Communication Workers of America approved by a 78 percent margin a three-year contract covering operating units of the Ameritech Corporation, which is based in Chicago and owns five Bell telephone companies in the Midwest.

title: Farr's Advice to Yankees: Get Cone and a Backup for Tartabull
description: Steve Farr sits in one corner of the Yankee clubhouse and is usually quiet and inconspicuous. The only time the reliable reliever finds himself in the forefront is when the Yankees need him to save a game in the ninth inning.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Chemical Bank, a unit of Chemical Banking Corp., New York, is offering $300 million of 7 1/4 percent 10-year subordinated notes at 99.298 to yield 7.35 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The noncallable notes are rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A- by Standard & Poor's Corp. * Clark Oil and Refining Corp., a unit of Horsham Corp., Toronto, is offering $175 million of 9.5 percent senior notes due in 2004 at par to yield 9.5 percent through Goldman, Sachs. The notes are rated Ba-2 by Moody's and BB+ by S.& P.

title: 1.1% Growth in World Economy Seen
description: After experiencing no growth last year, the world economy will expand only 1.1 percent this year and accelerate to a merely respectable 3 percent next year, the International Monetary Fund predicted today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Turmoil in Europe

title: Burden for the Jets Is Likely to Fall On O'Brien Now
description: With the Jets still staggering from two successive losses, Coach Bruce Coslet made a bold prediction today about Sunday's home opener against the 49ers: "We're going to go out and win."

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Cherkasov Is Upset Andrei Medvedev of Ukraine upset seventh-seeded Andrei Cherkasov of Russia, 5-7, 6-2, 7-5, yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of a clay-court tournament in Bordeaux, France. Medvedev, an 18-year-old who has risen from junior champion at the French Open last year to No. 33 in the world, beat Bjorn Borg in the opening round. In other second-round matches, second-seeded Carlos Costa of Spain beat a countryman, Francisco Roig, 6-3, 6-1, and third-seeded Guy Forget of France downed Claudio Pistolesi of Italy, 6-4, 6-4. Halard Leads the Way: Top-seeded Julie Halard of France led a quartet of seeded players into the quarterfinals of the Paris women's tournament. Halard topped Silke Frankl of Germany, 6-1, 6-1, in the second round. The only seeded player to lose was fifth-seeded Barbara Paulus of Austria, who was beaten by Silke Meier of Germany, 6-3, 6-2. (AP) 6-3, 6-2. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Ecuadorean Wins Walk Jefferson Perez of Ecuador won the 10,000-meter walk yesterday, the only event decided on the opening day of the world junior championships in Seoul, South Korea. Perez won by eight seconds with a time of 40 minutes 42.66 seconds. Jacek and Grzegorz Muller, Polish twins, finished second and third with times of 40:50.82 and 41:12.28. The five-day event has attracted 1,002 athletes from 99 countries. The competitors are aged 16 to 19. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Abimael Guzman Reynoso, leader of the Peruvian rebel group Shining Path, omitted a crucial word in quoting Francisco Eguiguren, assistant director of the Andean Commission of Jurists, a human rights group. He said of Mr. Guzman: "To have him in prison shows failure, disaster. It would not be better if he were killed."

title: Iran-Contra Prosecutor Sees No More Indictments
description: The Iran-contra independent prosecutor said in an interview today that his six-year inquiry into the scandal was unlikely to produce further indictments. The prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh, told The Washington Post, "We are nearly complete."

title: Unser Is Considering Formula One
description: AL UNSER Jr. is looking into a couple of Formula One rides next year, but he will continue with Galles-Kraco Racing if he decides to stay in Indy-Car competition, a Galles-Kraco official said yesterday.

title: Cosby Benefit Is Postponed
description: Bill Cosby's benefit show for Carnegie Hall on Nov. 11 has been postponed to March 29 because of scheduling difficulties, the hall has announced. Tickets, which will go on sale in early 1993, are $15 to $75 for the show and $1,000 for a pre-show reception with Mr. Cosby, first-class seats for the show and a supper afterward. Tickets at $500 include the show and supper. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: The Presidential Debates, Diminished
description: Presidential debates have one basic goal -- enlightening voters about the candidates. Time after time this noble purpose has been frustrated by a stodgy, stylized format: A pompous panel of interrogators asks random questions that are rarely followed up. As the questions zig and zag, so do the candidates. There's little continuity, and almost no robust interplay of ideas.

title: Electrician Indicted in Insider Deal
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday accused an electrician of trading illegally on insider information he got while installing a security system at the office of a company planning a takeover.

title: Rocking Chairs to Complement the Atomic Fireplace Perfectly
description: ONE day about three years ago, when Bernice Steinbaum was at her psychiatrist's, she happened to look down at her feet. She noticed that they were in motion. "I was moving back and forth," said Ms. Steinbaum, an art dealer who has had a gallery in SoHo for 10 years.

title: Car Dealer's Projects Face Challenges
description: A group of environmental lawyers and a state legislator, frustrated by the Brookhaven Town Board's approval of projects proposed by John McNamara during the last decade, plans to challenge those approvals in light of Mr. McNamara's admission last week that he bribed town officials for their support.

title: Mets Begin Trims for Minors
description: The Mets, citing fiscal concerns as well as standard evaluations of job performance, have begun a significant overhaul of their minor league personnel, a project that includes cutbacks, dismissals and reassignments.

title: U.S. Opens Inquiries on Spending for Los Angeles Rail System
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the General Accounting Office have opened inquiries into the Los Angeles agency that is building that city's vast new subway and rail system, the largest public works project under way in the country, Government sources said today.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA ADVANCE AT TALKS
description: Syrian and Israeli negotiators said today that they had reached agreement on several points in what they hope will be a joint document laying out the principles for an Israeli-Syrian peace settlement.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: 8th District; Maneuvering At Funeral For Weiss
description: Representative Ted Weiss, who died on Monday and was renominated for his House seat by a record margin the next day, was eulogized as the "conscience of Congress" yesterday at a funeral drawing Washington dignitaries, ordinary constituents and a gaggle of fellow politicians -- some of whom mixed mourning with maneuvering to succeed him.

title: TLC in Florida in the Form of a Shelter
description: IMPROMPTU shelter, be it an Army tent or a sofa bed in a relative's living room, is one disorienting consequence of a hurricane.

title: Norman Newton, 94, Architect Of Statue of Liberty Landscaping
description: Norman Newton, a landscape architect who redesigned the setting for the Statue of Liberty in 1937, died on Saturday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 94 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Multimedia Unit by Sony Is Portable
description: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that it would introduce next month a $999 portable multimedia player, a two-pound device that marries some of the capabilities of compact disk players, video players and computers.

title: Expos Stay Very Much Alive on Grissom's Heroics
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates saw enough of Marquis Grissom tonight to last until next season. But, to their displeasure, they have to see him three more times in the next eight days. They just hope they don't see him in the National League playoffs.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Connecticut; Johnson Begins Uphill Struggle vs. Dodd
description: Brook Johnson, a Greenwich millionaire, opened his general-election drive for the United States Senate today after a victorious Republican primary campaign built around generous financing and calculated spending on television commercials.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media; Secrecy Over TV Ads, or, the Peculiar Logic of Political Combat
