description: Barbara Bush is still vastly more popular and better known in the polls, but Hillary Clinton seems to be riding a heady backlash from the Republican convention these days. Her crowds are big, her portrait on the cover of Time magazine this month was downright beatific, and months of careful maneuvering to recast her image may be finally paying off.

title: Why Worry About the Brain Machine?
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Gas-Price Rally Continues To End of October Contract
description: Natural gas prices extended their remarkable post-hurricane ascent yesterday, with the contract for October delivery rising 9.7 cents, to $2.743 per 1,000 cubic feet, in the contract's final day of trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: If Nets Do Keep Mills, He Won't Come Cheap
description: More than a week after the Detroit Pistons offered Terry Mills a five-year contract worth almost $10 million, the Nets haven't decided whether to match the offer to their backup power forward, and no wonder.

title: Who Split Czechoslovakia?
description: Most Czechs and Slovaks are deeply sad as they watch the breakup of their federation into independent republics, which is to be completed by Jan. 1. Both nations, proud of Czechoslovakia, had made it Eastern Europe's most exemplary democracy.

title: Murder Trial Begins in Crown Heights Stabbing
description: The black teen-ager charged with the death of Yankel Rosenbaum killed the Hasidic scholar "in the frenzy of the moment" after getting swept up in a mob that was screaming "Kill the Jew" and seeking revenge for the death of a black Crown Heights child last summer, prosecutors said yesterday in their opening arguments.

title: Celebrating 30 Years of Valentino's Couture
description: PLACIDO DOMINGO's tenor dominated as he, Bette Midler and Aretha Franklin sang "Happy Anniversary to You." Lypsinka popped out of an anniversary cake, and Kid Creole and the Coconuts drew the elegantly dressed guests in black and white gowns to rhythmic wriggling on the dance floor. Sophia Loren brought the house down when she swept onstage to receive an award for her work for abused children.

title: Architecture as an Antidote
description: At the Guggenheim Pavilion, Mount Sinai Medical Center's new $200 million hospital building on upper Fifth Avenue, I. M. Pei continues his quest for a clean, well-lighted place. This time, the search has turned up a couple of beauties: a pair of lofty atriums, luminous with natural light. Rising 6 and 11 stories, respectively, these radiant, three-sided rooms offer Mount Sinai's patients one of the world's oldest holistic therapies: architecture.

title: Social Security's Ungrateful Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Findings Add to the Mystery of Alzheimer's Disease
description: In a surprise twist in research on Alzheimer's disease, scientists have found that a protein widely believed to play a role in causing the disease in the brain is also found in cells throughout the body.

title: Economic Scene; Long Creek, Short Paddle
description: "U.S. interest rates are too low," Carlos Solchaga told the multitudes assembled in Washington to watch unnerved government bankers play Point the Finger. What Spain's minister of finance meant was that American interest rates are too low to suit Europeans, whose internal system of fixed exchange rates deconstructed last week under the strain of trans-Atlantic warfare over monetary policy.

title: Congress Pressures U.S. on Waste Disposal
description: Congress passed and sent to President Bush today legislation requiring Federal installations, like nuclear plants, to comply with state and Federal laws on the disposal of hazardous waste.

title: Morgan's Foods Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 18
Ringer Names New President
description: The Ringer Corporation named a new president today and said it expected to take a restructuring charge of $900,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: And Goodwill To Someone
description: The site of the 1988 Goodwill Games will be announced Oct. 16 in the city, or regional area, selected. Final presentations will be made to the selection committee in Atlanta the day before by the four finalists: New Yorki, Dallas-Fort Worth, South Florida and St. Louis.

title: Larson-Davis Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
What's a Poor Man's Pennant Race? This Is
description: Welcome to the only race in town. No, make that the only race in baseball. As Sparky Anderson said upon arriving at Yankee Stadium the other day, "It's the one to watch."

title: Opponent of Military Dominance Named Thailand's Prime Minister
description: A politician who has opposed military interference in politics was named Thailand's 20th Prime Minister today after cobbling together a coalition Government that includes one of the nation's pro-military parties.

title: R2 Medical Systems Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: Peter Cook, 77, Dies; Was a Portrait Painter
description: Peter G. Cook, a portrait and landscape painter, died on Tuesday at his home in Kingston, N.J. He was 77 years old.

title: Firefighters Are Exposed To Asbestos
description: A smoky fire broke out last night in the basement of a high-rise apartment building on Central Park West undergoing asbestos removal. Although no one was injured in the blaze, 30 firefighters were exposed to the asbestos, which had been collected in more than 40 bags in the basement, the authorities said.

title: Tarkanian Subpoenaed by Committee
description: Former Nevada-Las Vegas Coach JERRY TARKANIAN and the university president, ROBERT MAXSON, have been subpoenaed to testify next month before a Nevada legislative committee investigating problems at the school. The Las Vegas Sun reported yesterday that Maxson's subpoena ordered him to bring all documents related to Tarkanian's employment and resignation. He was also ordered to bring records relating to his use of discretionary funds at the school, and the U.N.L.V. Foundation, a separate fund-raising organization. (AP)

title: Russian Tells of Americans' Fate
description: The Russian official responsible for the search for missing American prisoners of war in the former Soviet Union said today that two Americans had died in the 1940's after long prison terms and that one of them had probably been executed.

title: Perfumania Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-After a reserve for potential inventory losses of $ 3,700,000 relating to previously announced charges that Perfumania purchased frangrance products from a foreign supplier that were not genuine.The company also said that it established a reversal of about $ 2,800,000 in sales of the product. Included in the reserve for possible inventory losses are about $ 200,000 of related investigative and legal costs.Perfumania added that it did not recognize a full tax benefit in this year's second quarter because it did not have sufficient income in prior perids to offset such losses. The company said that it has about $ 3,500,000 of net operating loss carryovers to offset income taxes on future income.c-Net income and the quarter included an extraordinary credit of $ 226,431, or 10 cents a share.

title: William P. Mott Jr. Is Dead at 82; Directed the National Park Service
description: William P. Mott Jr., director of the National Park Service from 1985 to 1989, died on Monday in Orinda, Calif., where he lived. He was 82 years old.

title: KODAK INTRODUCES A COMPACT-DISK PUBLISHING SYSTEM
description: The Eastman Kodak Company is introducing a so-called writable compact-disk publishing system that offers companies a way to write, store and retrieve information. The new Kodak PCD Writer 200 system consists of a writer and compact disk, which can store 550 to 650 megabytes, plus software to operate the writer from a customer's computer. The software is available for DOS, Windows, Macintosh and Unix operating systems. Kodak also said it sold its Videk business to Performance Technologies Inc., a maker of hardware and software for communications and computer systems. Videk makes optical scanners for medical, industrial and scientific applications. Kodak and Performance Technologies are based in Rochester.

title: Topics of The Times; Vitamin Voodoo
description: A mischievous amendment quietly inserted in the giant Labor, Health and Education appropriations bill would prevent the Food and Drug Administration from taking action against false and misleading health claims for vitamins and dietary supplements.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID HAMPTON, the man whose escapades as an imposter and con artist became the subject of JOHN GUARE'S hit play "Six Degrees of Separation," denied in court yesterday that he had ever threatened the playwright in an attempt to get money from him.

title: Harold's Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 PROPPING UP THE FRANC

title: 'Safety Net' for Anchorage Homeless Is Seen as Both a Lifesaver and a Trap
description: This city is a showcase to social progress of a sort, though it is measured in the slumped forms of the homeless men and women who sleep on a cavernous shelter floor.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg Business News in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about an investor group's stake in Taj Mahal Holding referred incorrectly in some editions to the securities sold by the group. They were bonds with a face value of $30 million, and 30,000 class B shares.

title: Review/Opera; Love's Labors Exercised in a Series in Omaha
description: Love took its lumps over the weekend at Opera Omaha. The three wildly divergent works in the company's fall festival at the Joslyn Art Museum, which ended today, shared one thing: an obsession with fruitless romance. At every turn, love met with frustration or even outright mayhem and disaster. The whole experience might have led even an incurable romantic to consider becoming a hermit.

title: Market Place; Seeking Bargains In Military Stocks
description: DESPITE a generally gloomy outlook for American military contractors, which are suffering from deep cuts in Pentagon spending, a growing number of Wall Street analysts maintain that there are still bargains to be found among aerospace and military stocks.

title: Review/Opera; A Story of Intrigue In Sweden, Set Mostly In the Mind of the Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera has found a curious solution to the perennial problem of "Un Ballo in Maschera" -- the problem of where the work should take place. Verdi's libretto by Antonio Somma was based on the assassination of a Swedish king at a masked ball in the Stockholm opera house in 1792. But the censors in Naples in 1857 objected to setting it too close to home in either space or time. So Somma thought of moving it to Pomerania ("an independent duchy in the 12th century"). Verdi finally settled on Boston, renaming the characters (although in Paris, an early production moved the setting to Italy). So the opera ended up with villains named Samuel and Tom, along with alternative names for the king (Gustav III or Riccardo) and the king's best friend (Captain Anckarstrom or Renato).

title: Navy Is Said to Punish 3 Admirals For Lax Inquiry on Fliers' Conduct
description: The Navy has decided to oust one admiral and discipline two others after a long-awaited Pentagon investigation concluded that they had failed to aggressively carry out an investigation into a naval aviators' convention in Las Vegas, Nev., where at least 26 women were sexually assaulted, Pentagon officials said tonight.

title: Shopko Stores Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
description: Year-ago periods' share earnings and shares outstanding are pro-forma, reflecting the number of shares outstanding after the October 1991 initial offering.

title: Sports of The Times; Riley's New Knick Doodlings
description: EVERYONE involved in a trade is usually filled with dreams. It's like a transplant. The hope, if the surgeon is to be believed, is that things will be better than ever.

title: High School Melee Draws Heavy Fina
description: The Camden school district will pay a $10,000 fine assessed against its boys basketball team for a chair-throwing melee that erupted after a 1990 championship game, officials announced Tuesday.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: This week's column answers questions from readers about common -- and not-so-common -- home-improvement and repair problems. In Place of Slate

title: Advance Circuits reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Stein Supports Proposal For Police Review Board
description: City Council President Andrew J. Stein took a side yesterday in the battle over investigating police misconduct, saying he would support Mayor David N. Dinkins's proposal to establish an all-civilian agency, with some minor alterations.

title: Mujahedeen Strive for Democracy in Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Rescuing Street Drunks And Trading War Stories
description: Saving the lives of street alcoholics is an unassailable goal, but it is also ugly work. And no one knows it better than Kirk Roberts, a medical technician who spends his days dragging them from bushes, sidewalks and alleys.

title: Shaver Maker Announces Refinancing
description: For two years, the Remington Products factory that fronts Long Island Sound here has been in trouble. Workers were laid off, raises were foregone, and the possibility of a foreign buyout, one that would move every last Remington job out of Bridgeport, hovered persistently.

title: Espey Manufacturing & Electronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: California; For Bush, California Seems a Lost Cause
description: Republicans have all but given up on winning California for President Bush, essentially writing off the largest electoral prize of all to Gov. Bill Clinton.

title: The Ad Campaign
description: TELEVISION SCRIPT -- Announcer: "To pay for his increased spending in Arkansas, Bill Clinton raised state taxes. And not just on the rich. He increased the sales tax by 33 percent. Imposed a mobile home tax. Increased the beer tax. He assessed a tourism tax. Created a cable TV tax. Supported a tax on groceries.

title: Technology Solutions Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Nu-West Industries reports earnings for Year June 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: RSI Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $ 17,000 in the quarter and $ 1,330,000, or 17 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 59,000 in the quarter and $ 129,000 in the 9 months.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ross Perot; Perot, Pondering Re-entry Into Race, Spends Millions to Press Ballot Drive
description: In the month after he renounced his intention to seek the Presidency, Ross Perot spent nearly $4 million -- nearly all of it his own money -- to continue the effort to place his name on the ballot.

title: Among Many Lists, Tales of Missing Americans
description: On May 18, 1965, when the American war in Indochina was still in its early stages, Capt. David L. Hrdlicka, an Air Force pilot, was shot down in an F-105D over Laos. He walked away from the crash, and into oblivion.

title: Foreign Affairs; Mr. Bush, Statesman . . .
description: George Bush was not at a political rally in Pittsburgh or San Diego Monday when he recalled his military career, backhandedly rebuking Bill Clinton for failing to serve, and then proposed revamping U.S. foreign aid to create 40,000 new U.S. jobs. No, he was plugging his own campaign in New York -- in a solemn speech before the U.N. General Assembly, of all places.

title: Giants Situation Angers Florida Senator
description: Senator CONNIE MACK, a Republican of Florida, accused baseball officials with trying to block the move of the San Francisco Giants to Tampa Bay, Fla., and said he would do everything he could to revoke the sport's antitrust exemption. Mack is a member of a Senate subcommittee that will hold hearings next week on baseball's exemption from antitrust laws. Mack said he thought baseball officials made "a 180-degree turn" by letting San Francisco make a counteroffer after the Giants' owner, BOB LURIE, was told he was free to explore other offers. (AP)

title: Daily News Creditors Endorse Zuckerman's Plan
description: The creditors committee of The Daily News yesterday endorsed Mortimer B. Zuckerman's plan to buy the bankrupt paper, and he could close the deal as early as Thanksgiving.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about the author William A. Swanberg misidentified the subjects of his last book, "Whitney Father, Whitney Heiress." They were William Collins Whitney, Secretary of the Navy in the first Cleveland Administration, and his daughter, Dorothy, not the publisher John Hay Whitney and his daughter, Dorothy.

title: Germans Find Mass Graves at an Ex-Soviet Camp
description: Investigators digging at the site of a Soviet-run prison camp in the former East Germany have uncovered mass graves containing the bodies of 12,500 people, the Brandenburg state government said today.

title: Top Russian Official Says Debts Are Preventing New Borrowings
description: A top Russian official asserted today that his country was unable to tap Western loans because it could not meet overdue payments on previous debts. Other Western loans are not being used because the weak ruble make imports too expensive, even with the loans, he said.

title: A Video Telephone From MCI
description: The MCI Communications Corporation opened a new front in its long rivalry with A.T.& T. yesterday by announcing plans to introduce a video telephone for $750. That is half the price of A.T.& T.'s picture phone, which went on sale earlier this summer amid what the company says is intense consumer interest.

title: Is It Art or Scrap Wood? The Answer Is: It's Both
description: The southern tip of Roosevelt Island is haunted ground, a wasteland of crumbling Gothic ruins where the city once deposited its sick and insane. It has a new, peculiar feature. Yesterday, the final nail was driven into a temporary sculpture called "Kawamata: Project on Roosevelt Island," bringing to an end five years of negotiation, bureaucratic wire-pulling and furious hammering.

title: Curfews on Top of Curfews
description: Without a single dissenting vote, both houses of New Jersey's Legislature have passed a bill authorizing towns to impose a 10 P.M. to 6 A.M. curfew on youngsters under 18. But the law they so heartily endorse is neither necessary nor useful, except to show just how four-square New Jersey lawmakers stand against lawlessness.

title: An Israeli Opening to Palestinians Delayed
description: To discourage moves to involve the Palestine Liberation Organization in Mideast peace diplomacy, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin has delayed proposed changes in a law banning contacts with the group, officials said today.

title: Baseball Goes Cool to Lure Young Audience With Rap
description: IN the 1950's musical "Damn Yankees," the Devil turns a middle-aged baseball fan into a young player. Now, Major League Baseball is trying to turn young people into baseball fans.

title: U.N. Expulsion of Yugoslavia Breeds Defiance and Finger-Pointing
description: Serbs reacted with defiance and despair today to Yugoslavia's ouster from the United Nations, and the nationalists who hold power tried to pin the blame on the Serbian-American millionaire they drafted to become Prime Minister 10 weeks ago.

title: Giants Learn a Lesson On How World Turns
description: Call them the sweetness-and-light Giants.

title: Hunts Want Suit Dismissed
description: Members of the Hunt family of Dallas will return to Federal bankruptcy court on Thursday to request dismissal of a racketeering suit that seeks to recover $100 million from relatives and affiliates of Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt.

title: Bush's Nonsense on Jobs and the Environment
description: Claiming that Americans must choose between their jobs and the environment is getting to be a habit for President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle.

title: Abroad at Home; The Bush Constitution
description: President Bush's veto of the family leave bill, announced at night to avoid public notice, actually deserves close attention. For it gives us an insight into Mr. Bush's view of what government should do in our society -- his view of politics and the Constitution.

title: Digging In Against the Serbs' Svengali
description: The Serbian-born business executive from California who was handpicked in July by hard-liners in Belgrade to be Prime Minister of Yugoslavia speaks with a voice that often seems at odds with those who named him to the post.

title: Key Job Shifts At Anheuser
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies announced several management changes yesterday in the wake of the departure this week of a top marketing executive, John N. MacDonough, to be the new president of Miller, a unit of Philip Morris.

title: Emons Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after income from discontinued operations from the sale of its railcar management and brokerage business of $ 2,871,036, or 43 cents a share, which included $ 108,171 in earnings from the operations, for the quarter and $ 3,547,300, or 51 cents a share, which included $ 784,435 in earnings from the operations, for the year.

title: EX-OFFICIAL CITES DOUBT ON P.O.W.'S
description: Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Defense when American troops were withdrawn from Vietnam in 1973, said today that the Pentagon believed that some prisoners of war might have remained in neighboring Laos, contrary to a statement by President Nixon that all the prisoners were on their way home.

title: PLEA DEAL IS SEEN IN TOKYO SCANDAL
description: Shin Kanemaru, Japan's most influential politician, was reported tonight to be readying an admission that he received $4 million in illegal political contributions from a company linked to mobsters in a widening scandal that is threatening to engulf the Cabinet of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa.

title: UNITED SEEKS REVIEW OF BRITISH AIR STAKE IN USAIR
description: United Airlines has asked the Department of Transportation to conduct a public review of British Airways plan to buy a $750 million stake in USAir. Delta Air Lines made a similar request last week and was rebuffed within 24 hours. British Airways wants to buy 44 percent of USAir's overall equity and 21 percent of its voting stock. United States law now restricts foreign ownership of domestic carriers to a 49 percent equity stake and a 25 percent voting position. United, Delta and American Airlines, representing 53 percent of the domestic industry's traffic, oppose the British move. They say it would give British Airways expanded entry in the United States without giving United States airlines reciprocal access to British airports.

title: Newly Empowered Owners Rescind Order to Realign
description: Seventeen days after Commissioner Fay Vincent resigned under fire, the owners who replaced him as baseball's ruling body yesterday rescinded his order to realign the National League.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Escovedo at Tramps

title: Reviews/Film; A Melodious Variation On Feminist Awareness
description: Maria Novaro's "Danzon," an unusual work of Mexican feminism opening today at the Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, is the gentle and earnest story of one woman's voyage of self- discovery. It concerns Julia (Maria Rojo), a telephone operator in Mexico City whose principal joy is the form of ballroom dancing for which the film is named. Julia and her dance partner, Carmelo (Daniel Rergis), have been meeting weekly for six years, which is the full extent of their relationship when Carmelo mysteriously disappears. Julia sets out to find him and manages, in the process, to find herself.

title: Natural Gas Prices Plunge In Wake of Selling Wave
description: Natural gas prices fell sharply yesterday as producers exploited the steep price advance of September to sell huge volumes of gas, analysts said. The contract price for November delivery dropped 12.9 cents to settle at $2.474 per 1,000 cubic feet.

title: American Safety Closure reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net lossShares outstanding reflected a 1-10 reverse stock split effective Sept. 1, 1992.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK PLEDGES $750 MILLION TO LOAN PLAN
description: The Bank of New York, seeking to secure regulatory approval of an expansion plan, said yesterday that it intended to make $750 million in housing loans to low- and moderate-income areas over the next decade. Bank of New York said the program would take effect once Federal banking regulators approve the bank's application to acquire 64 New York-area branches of Barclays Bank.

title: Righteous Anger Spilled Over at Police Rally
description: To the Editor:

title: On Matters of Health, Women's Magazines Give Solid Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Innovo Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: George Bush's Stall on Debates
description: President Bush continues to duck the Presidential debates, and voters have a right to be angry. This week in Greenville, Miss., demonstrators dressed in chicken suits chided Mr. Bush with placards that said "Chicken George" and "Read My Beak." The demonstrators may well have been Clinton operatives; even so, plenty of ordinary voters want to see the candidates face to face, displaying views and personalities that can help form judgments for Nov. 3.

title: The Art Market
description: There and Back Again

title: Gtech Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
description: Share earnings are pro forma, reflecting the company's initial public offering on July 22.

title: Congressional Delegation Will Undergo Some Shifts
description: About the only question left concerning the Congressional elections in New Jersey six weeks from now is whether Republicans will outnumber Democrats in the delegation for the first time since 1964.

title: Tobacco Measure Fails in Senate
description: The Senate today killed by an overwhelming margin a measure that would have reduced the tax deductibility of advertising and promotion for tobacco products.

title: Breakthrough Eludes Mideast Talks
description: Israeli and Arab delegates ended their sixth round of negotiations today, having inched a bit closer to one another but with no substantive breakthroughs.

title: Festival Films Look Back in Affection
description: MOVIES have never been more self-conscious about their history. If one had to choose a defining phrase for the mood of world cinema today, "esthetic self-awareness" might be the most pertinent. And this sense of an art refreshing itself by rummaging through its past runs through many of the 26 programs in the New York Film Festival, which opens tonight at Lincoln Center with Agnieszka Holland's psychological drama "Olivier, Olivier."

title: From Musica Sacra
description: Musica Sacra opens its season with a concert entitled "Songs and Psalms of the Divine," at 3 P.M. tomorrow at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights. Richard Westenburg is to conduct the choral ensemble in a program including "Spem in Alium," Thomas Tallis's 40-voice motet; Richard Strauss's "Deutsche Motette"; Schoenberg's "Friede auf Erden"; a new work by Gerre Hancock commissioned by Musica Sacra, and music of Gabrieli, Schutz, Bruckner and Randall Thompson. The 60-voice Musica Sacra Chorus will be accompanied by organ and brass. Tickets are $25. Information: (212) 874-3104.

title: On Matters of Health, Women's Magazines Give Solid Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Rangers Get First Preseason Victory

title: Resourcecan Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a $ 54,000 gain on the redemption of preferred shares.c-Included a $ 191,000 writedown of investments.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Dean Foods Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
Review/Art; A Mulatto-Chinese Cuban With a Gift for Fusion
description: This is a big year for Wifredo Lam (1902-1982). Two major exhibitions are scheduled for Europe, another will be mounted at the Studio Museum in Harlem in January and at present "Wifredo Lam: A Retrospective of Works on Paper" is on view at the Americas Society. The attention is well deserved -- Lam is an exceptionally interesting, if uneven, artist -- but why is it coming now? The fact that his career has been seriously under-examined has something to do with it; but so does the fact that he is an amazing paradigm of cross-cultural interaction.

title: Mozart's 'Magic Flute'
description: The New York City Opera will begin performances of Mozart's "Magic Flute" at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow at the New York State Theater. Amy Burton will be making her debut as Pamina and Rachel Rosales is the Queen of the Night; Richard Drews sings Tamino; Jeff Mattsey is Papageno; John Calvin West is Sarastro, and Philip Cokorinos is the Speaker. All the principals, other than Ms. Rosales, are singing their roles for the first time at City Opera. "The Magic Flute" is to be conducted by Scott Bergeson and sung in an English translation by Andrew Porter. Tickets are $10 to $68. Information: (212) 870-5570.

title: Self-Help Guides on Law Grow Into Big Business
description: When it comes to lawyer bashing and changing the legal system, President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle have nothing on Ralph Warner. Mr. Warner is the co-founder and publisher of Nolo Press, a longtime producer of legal self-help guides.

title: Paris-Bonn Effort Aids The Franc
description: The turmoil in the European currency markets abated somewhat today as a joint effort between France and Germany succeeded in stabilizing the value of the franc.

title: Opportunities Are Not Equal in Athletic Departments
description: A survey of the nation's Division I athletic programs by the General Accounting Office, due to be released today, offers the first firm evidence that women and members of minority groups have been excluded, minimized and underpaid by college athletic departments.

title: Short Sales Outstanding Rise Again on Nasdaq
description: By borrowing the stocks of those companies and selling them at high prices, the investors are betting they will be able to buy the shares back on the cheap and keep the difference.

title: Hartco Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Alcide Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Sports of The Times; N.F.L. Brass: The Future's In the Bronx
description: IF there is not some clause in their contract forbidding their attendance at a baseball game, the top officials of the National Football League just might want to head over to Yankee Stadium tonight to watch their own future in action. His name is David Cone.

title: Briton Repeats His Commitment to Europe, but Warily
description: Prime Minister John Major told a clamorous session of the House of Commons today that Britain was committed to closer European union, but he said the details of future monetary and political cooperation still needed further deliberation.

title: Santo Domingo Journal; For Columbus Lighthouse, a Fete That Fizzled
description: For years, President Joaquin Balaguer has faithfully traveled somewhere in his country each week to inaugurate a new road, apartment building or aqueduct, all pieces of a vast body of public works that his associates say is his fondest legacy of his many years in power.

title: TV Weekend; 3 of the Golden Girls in a New Home
description: Spiraling health-care costs, age discrimination: the elderly may not have much to laugh about these days but, at least as far as television entertainment is concerned, oldsters remain a hoot. Absent Bea Arthur, NBC's "Golden Girls" has been resurrected on CBS as "The Golden Palace" (Fridays at 8 P.M.), and the old girls are, well, as irrepressible as ever. And then "Frannie's Turn," also on CBS (Saturdays at 8 P.M.), offers a wacky domestic menagerie that includes a dotty mother-in-law who watches a television shopping network to order items like a "Star Trek" ankle bracelet. Oh, you kids!

title: FDP Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net lossThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: RESUMPTION OF PREFERRED DIVIDEND LIFTS UNISYS STOCK
description: The Unisys Corporation's shares rose nearly 8 percent in active trading yesterday after the company restored its dividend on certain preferred shares. The computer maker's shares closed up 62.5 cents, at $9.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. More than 2.2 million shares were traded, compared with a three-month average daily volume of 836,800 shares. It was among the most active issues on the Big Board. Unisys declared a dividend of $1.40625 on its series A cumulative convertible preferred shares, payable Oct. 15 to stockholders of record Oct. 6. The last dividend payment on this preferred stock was made in January 1991, a Unisys spokesman said.

title: Review/Film Festival; 'Olivier, Olivier,' a French Provincial Family Mystery
description: Agnieszka Holland, who wrote and directed last year's popular "Europa, Europa," is in a far less somber mood with her new "Olivier, Olivier," the entertaining, initially sunny, very spooky opening attraction of the 30th New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center. The film will be shown tonight at 7:30 at Alice Tully Hall and at 9 at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Man in the News; Persistence Pays Off: Jerrold Lewis Nadler
description: Assemblyman Jerrold Nadler's introduction to politics came when he was 7 years old and his father, "a dyed-in-the-wool Democrat," was a struggling poultry farmer in New Jersey.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Anheuser-Busch Companies, St. Louis, filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $735 million of debt securities. * Baxter International Inc., Deerfield, Ill., a maker of hospital supplies and medical equipment, is offering $150 million of 5 percent notes due in 1995 at par through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The noncallable issue is rated A-2 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.& P.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section on Wednesday about the Catskill Food Festival misstated the hours. The festival is on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Review/Film; Vampire With Red Eyes And a Sense of Humor
description: When a foreign actress makes the kind of impression Anne Parillaud made in "La Femme Nikita," she is likely to find herself fielding American movie offers. So there is always the danger that she will wind up in something like John Landis's "Innocent Blood." Mr. Landis's latest overlong, overproduced spectacle finds this elegant beauty playing a blood-soaked, red-eyed vampire. Her voice is sometimes electronically altered a la "The Exorcist," just to add an extra element of fun.

title: Art in Review
description: Ava Gerber Fiction/Nonfiction 21 Mercer Street SoHo Through Sept. 26

title: Citicorp Prices Credit Card Trust
description: Citicorp yesterday priced a $1.33 billion global issue of floating-rate credit-card-backed certificates. The two-part issue is being sold through the Citicorp Standard Credit Card Master Trust 1992-3.

title: Dinkins Joins Velazquez On Victory Trip to San Juan
description: Having helped her to an upset victory over an influential Congressional veteran, Mayor David N. Dinkins went to Puerto Rico today with Nydia M. Velazquez and used her triumphant homecoming to gather political capital of his own.

title: Yankees Look Good Now and Look Forward to Later
description: This is the race for fourth place. The fans yawn. The players all seem to be rookies. The soda goes flat.

title: Fed Looks Into 'Squeeze' In Treasuries
description: The "squeeze" on the Treasury's seven- and 10-year notes has become tight enough to prompt the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to collect information on dealer positions and study the dynamics of the shortage of securities.

title: Executive Changes
description: AIR MIDWEST INC., Wichita, Kan., a unit of Mesa Airlines Inc., named Dick Paquette president and chief operating officer. FOODMAKER INTERNATIONAL, San Diego, a unit of Foodmaker Inc., which operates and franchises Jack in the Box and Chi-Chi's restaurant chains, named Tony Wang president.

title: SHEARSON LEHMAN FIRES 250 MID-LEVEL MANAGERS
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. cut 250 middle-management employees from its 3,000-member trade-processing group yesterday, saying the move would increase efficiency and service quality. Shearson, the nation's second biggest securities firm, has about 31,000 employees and 9,000 brokers. Shearson had a $4 million profit in the second quarter, compared with a $37 million loss a year earlier. Pre-tax income advanced to $163 million from $119 million.

title: Colony Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.The company said Imperial Metals Corp. will acquire 467,953 shares of Colony which were previously under the control but not owned by Imperial.

title: Fighting Intensifies in Armenian-Azerbaijani War
description: Fighting between Azerbaijan and Armenia over the Armenian enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh intensified today amid reports that military and civilian deaths had climbed to more than 500 this week.

title: Dynamics Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 5
description: Year-ago share earnings for the quarter and 9 months are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in February.

title: Devils Name Stevens Team's New Captain
description: The Devils removed BRUCE DRIVER as team captain yesterday and replaced him with SCOTT STEVENS.

title: Review/Art; Matter Turned Into Light and Space
description: Robert Irwin is an optical magician who doesn't believe in fooling the eye. For more than two decades, this 64-year-old maverick West Coast Minimalist has been known for creating installation pieces whose mysterious (and beautiful) visual effects are also utterly comprehensible.

title: Kohl Denies Secret Plan to Force European Union
description: Political and monetary disarray in Europe reached the point today that the German Government was forced to deny assertions that vigorous German support of the French franc in the money markets was part of a secret campaign by Paris and Bonn to push ahead with European union even over the objections of their neighbors.

title: Technology Solutions Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Senior Navy Officers Suppressed Sex Investigation, Pentagon Says
description: In a blistering critique of the Navy's inquiry into sexual assaults at an aviators' convention last year, a Pentagon report made public today says that senior Navy officials deliberately undermined their own investigation to avoid negative publicity.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about the trial of David Hampton, the imposter and con artist who is fighting charges of aggravated harassment against the playwright John Guare, referred incorrectly in some editions to the former president of Channel 13, who had been a target of Mr. Hampton's deception. He is John J. Iselin.

title: In His Own Words
description: GOV. BILL CLINTON In comments yesterday at Merck Pharmaceuticals in Rahway, N.J.

title: INSIDE
description: Tactics of the Siege

title: Bernice Gera, Umpire, 61
description: Bernice Gera, the first female umpire in professional baseball, died of kidney cancer Wednesday in Memorial Hospital West in Pembroke Pines, Fla. She was 61 years old.

title: Juno Lighting Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said all share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split declared in April.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Eating for Less

title: Four N.F.L. Players Get Five Days of Freedom
description: Four National Football League players who are seeking to be unrestricted free agents won a temporary restraining order today that grants them five days to pursue a contract with any of the league's 28 teams.

title: Article 556492 -- No Title
description: Today's question: What is a brasserie?

title: Pacts Elude New York City And Unions
description: A year after most of New York City's contracts with municipal labor unions expired, contract negotiations are stalled, union officials and mayoral advisers say.

title: Banks Reject Sole Canary Wharf Bid
description: Lenders to Olympia & York's Canary Wharf project here have rejected the only firm bid for the troubled real estate development, further clouding the project's future, bankers said today.

title: Money Fund Assets Down
description: The total assets of the nation's 611 retail money market mutual funds decreased by $670.3 million, to $384.06 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Aug. 31 about the wedding of Billie Tekel and Barry Elias misidentified the clergyman. Rabbi Alexander Levin performed the ceremony, substituting at the last minute for a colleague.

title: Ciatti's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Topics of The Times; No Litmus Test Needed Here
description: If Judge Emilion Garza of the U.S. Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals is considered again for a Supreme Court vacancy, the Bush Administration won't even have to ask how he feels about abortion. Judge Garza has gone shamelessly out of his way to answer that litmus-test question without being asked.

title: The Spoken Word
description: POETRY READING, Nuyorican Poets Cafe, 236 East Third Street, Lower East Side. Readings of their own poems by Mike Tyler, Ron Cephas Jones, Pete Spiro and Bahiyyih Watson. Today at 10 P.M. Admission: $5. Information: (212) 505-8183.

title: Tough Help for Homeless; New Dinkins Policy Is to Provide Housing To Those Striving to Improve Themselves
description: The Dinkins administration's new strategy for dealing with the homeless effectively acknowledges that its initial, generous policy had the perverse effect of encouraging many impoverished New Yorkers to declare themselves homeless -- and that a new system was needed to make sure that only the truly homeless were served.

title: Review/Film; Appliance With Craving For Flesh
description: "The Refrigerator" is not the first film in which an inanimate object embarks on a lethal rampage against humanity, but in its crude way it is one of the most amusing. Written and directed by Nicholas A. E. Jacobs and shot on the Lower East Side of Manhattan on a minuscule budget, the comic horror film is set mostly in a tenement apartment dominated by a battered old Norge refrigerator that is quite literally from hell.

title: White House Called Ready to Cut Atom Tests to Keep Texas Project
description: Eager to save an $8 billion research project for politically important Texas, the White House signaled today that it would accept limits on nuclear testing, senior Congressional Republicans and Administration officials said. The limits had been added to a bill that included money for the Texas project.

title: Paul Tully Is Dead at 48; Top Democratic Strategist
description: Paul Tully, the political director of the Democratic National Committee and one of his party's pre-eminent strategists, was found dead in Little Rock, Ark., today. He was 48 years old.

title: Astrosystems Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Twenty-five years after Sir Kenneth Clark first guided television viewers through Western culture, from the fall of the Roman Empire into the 20th century, the "Civilization" series will be seen again.

title: IRAQ MAY APPROVE U.N. AID TO KURDS
description: In an apparent softening of Baghdad's position, the Iraqi Foreign Minister said today that his Government had no objection to the United Nations' mounting a new relief operation this winter to help Kurds in the north of the country.

title: IMPEACHMENT VOTE CLEARED IN BRAZIL
description: Striking a pair of blows to President Fernando Collor de Mello's chances of avoiding impeachment, Brazil's Supreme Court has voted to deny the President more time for his defense and has ruled that the impeachment vote in congress may proceed by public roll-call.

title: Paul E. Garber, 93, First Curator Of National Air and Space Exhibit
description: Paul E. Garber, whose childhood fascination with a kite inspired a lifelong love of aviation that led to the founding of the National Air and Space Museum in Washington, died on Wednesday at the Arlington Hospital in Arlington, Va. He was 93 years old and lived in Arlington.

title: Insurance Stocks Surge Except for Continental
description: Insurance company stocks surged yesterday on the expectation that the high losses from Hurricanes Andrew and Iniki would finally force property-casualty insurers to raise their prices on business insurance.

title: Economic Consensus Is Elusive
description: After a week in which currency speculation bore more fruit than international economic cooperation, finance ministers and central bankers from 172 countries left here saying that more cooperation would get the global economy moving again.

title: Traffic Alert
description: TOMORROW

title: Review/Film; Day-Lewis as Hawkeye in a Cooper Classic
description: "Come, friends," a scout says typically in James Fenimore Cooper's novel "The Last of the Mohicans." "Let us move our station, and in such a fashion, too, as will throw the cunning of a Mingo on a wrong scent, or our scalps will be drying in the wind in front of Montcalm's marquee, ag'in this hour tomorrow."

title: METRO DIGEST
description: ON THE TRAIL WITH CLINTON

title: Mother Denies Abuse of Son Suing to End Parental Tie
description: A 12-year-old boy who wants to choose who will be his parents began a widely publicized trial here today that could substantially alter the legal rights of children and broaden the debate over the structure of contemporary American families.

title: Topics of The Times; Global Cooling?
description: Men are cooler than women, and everyone is cooler than the little red "normal" line on the thermometer, according to a paper published this week in the Journal of the American Medical Association. The commonly accepted notion that 98.6 degrees is normal came from Carl Reinhold August Wunderlich, a German physician who recorded the temperatures of 25,000 Leipzigers in the mid-1800's. But now three doctors in Baltimore have reached the unsettling conclusion that the right number is 98.2 -- a little lower for men and a little higher for women.

title: Righteous Anger Spilled Over at Police Rally; Review Board's Makeup
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Ilya Kabakov Ronald Feldman Gallery 31 Mercer Street SoHo Through Oct. 17

title: Global Bankers' Muted Happy Hour
description: Adventure may be the life of commerce, as Walter Bagehot, the 19th-century English economist, once said, but caution, he added, is the life of banking. And during a monetary crisis, bankers, whether commercial or central, are fretful, even downright dull.

title: Cabano Transportation Group reports earnings for Qtr to July 18
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.The company said that its recent acquisition of Kingsway Transports leads it to predict that full-year revenue will reach about $ 180 million, up from $ 129 million in the previous fiscal year. It said that the first quarter included just five days of Kingsway's results.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats; CLINTON PROPOSES MAKING EMPLOYERS COVER HEALTH CARE
description: Gov. Bill Clinton, who has long sought to capitalize on public concern over rising health-care costs, said yesterday that if elected President he would require private employers to provide health insurance and would have the Federal Government supplement health-care protection for the unemployed.

title: Is Enlightened Ice Age Ushering In the 90's?
description: So Wayne Gretzky glides off the ice at about the same time that Manon Rheaume glides on. Is this the coincidence of a superstar's bad back and an expansion team's good publicity, or is it the face-off metaphor of the season? Could it mean that such faded stars as Gretzky, Larry Bird, Magic Johnson, Mike Tyson and Joe Montana will be replaced by someone newer and more interesting? Or could it actually mean that the Gross 80's are over in sports, that an era of explosive growth, traditional heroes and a school for scandal is finally giving way to the Net 90's reckoning over money, sex and morals?

title: Western Hanover Just Misses Triple Crown
description: Fake Left ended Western Hanover's bid for the pacing triple crown with a strong stretch run to win the 47th Little Brown Jug today in a photo finish.

title: Match Made in Make-Believe Land
description: Yet another silly pay-per-view event encroaches upon us tonight, a dubious two-out-of-three, $500,000 winner-take-all tennis match between Jimmy Connors and Martina Navratilova, which will cost buyers an estimated $24.95 apiece.

title: Philadelphia's Workers Seek Court Relief
description: Unions representing 15,000 nonuniformed city workers asked a court today to prevent the city from carrying out a new labor contract that was imposed by Mayor Edward G. Rendell.

title: 40-Million-Year-Old Extinct Bee Yields Oldest Genetic Material
description: By extracting gene fragments from insects preserved in amber for up to 40 million years, two independent teams of scientists have obtained the oldest DNA ever recovered from fossils.

title: Defaced 'Unity Wall' Is Repainted
description: The "Unity Wall" mural in Crown Heights, depicting scenes from Noah's Ark, interracial cooperation, and black and Jewish cultural symbols, is being replaced after being repeatedly defaced.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS RESISTING POWERS OF CENTRAL BANKS
description: Figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve and other central banks suggest that the ability of the leading economies to defend their currencies on the world's foreign-exchange markets has slipped markedly in the last three years.

title: Wang Expects Year's Loss To Be Worse Than Forecast
description: Wang Laboratories Inc., which filed for bankruptcy protection in August, informed customers and investors yesterday that its results for the fiscal year that ended on June 30 would be far worse than previously announced.

title: Iran-Contra Figure Points to Wider Role for Bush
description: Richard V. Secord, a leading figure in the Iran-contra affair, said today that he believed that President Bush was more involved than has been acknowledged in the arms-for-hostages deals with Iran in the mid-1980's. But Mr. Secord added that he had no direct evidence to support that conclusion.

title: Worldly and the Spiritual Clash in New Age Divorce
description: Few things are more jarring than a forced collision of the spiritual world and the legal. Such is the case in a divorce court here, where a woman who claims to be the medium for a 35,000-year-old warrior has been trying to explain herself, and the riches she made off a movement that swept the nation in the 1980's.

title: Review/Opera; A Familiar Treatment In the Met's 'Butterfly'
description: Having slid through the Metropolitan Opera's repertory off and on for the last 33 years, the company's production of "Madama Butterfly" is about to slide through a 34th. Motohiro Nagasaka's design -- with its two-dimensional cutouts and oversize cherry blossoms -- has a tired and dowdy look and was probably not too handsome to begin with. Fabrizio Melano's current staging looks distracted, as if stagecraft had been more or less abandoned to the whims of its principals. They sang sturdily on Wednesday night and sometimes gave pleasure.

title: Art in Review
description: Isa Genzken Marian Goodman Gallery 24 West 57th Street Midtown Through Oct. 17

title: Norman D. Erlanger, Stockbroker, 83
description: Norman D. Erlanger, a retired stockbroker, died on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: In Manhattan Park, Nominee Lets Abrams Share a Vital Spotlight
description: Just before Bill Clinton took the stage to address a mid-afternoon crowd in Bryant Park in midtown Manhattan yesterday, he whispered to the woman introducing him to be sure to first call attention to a pair of local politicians on hand.

title: Heroic Bus Driver Is Dismissed and Rehired
description: Last June, Donna Smith was praised for her heroism after she piloted a school bus full of terrified kindergarten children, one of them badly wounded, out of a street-side gun battle in New Haven. On Tuesday, she was dismissed by the bus company for refusing to drive a new route that she considered dangerous.

title: G.M. Official Will Become A Top Executive at Textron
description: When rising corporate stars get job offers from other companies, making decisions about what to do generally takes some time. Lewis B. Campbell is an exception to that rule.

title: Do Government Rogues Traffic in Drugs?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CENTEL CORP., Chicago, announced that it and Sprint Corp. had filed applications with the Florida Public Service Commission and the Illinois Commerce Commission for approval of Centel's merger with Sprint. In May, the companies announced a merger agreement. PANASONIC CO., Secaucus, N.J., introduced several notebook-sized computers including one that uses a new low-power chip designed to conserve battery life. Panasonic's model CF-1000 notebook, available in November for a suggested retail price of $2,299, can run up to five and a half hours, or twice that if a second battery pack is installed, the company said.

title: People
description: * James E. Murphy, 56 years old, chairman and chief executive at Burson-Marsteller, New York, was promoted to the new position of chairman and chief executive at Burson-Marstellar U.S.A., New York. Andrew Cooper, 44, president and chief operating officer, will succeed Mr. Murphy as president and chief executive. And Kenneth Rietz, 51, executive vice president of public affairs at Burson-Marsteller, Los Angeles, was promoted to the new position of president of West Coast operations, responsible for the Los Angeles, Sacramento and San Francisco offices.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Pulse -- North Carolina; Presidential Race in North Carolina: Fierce Fight Across Cultural Divide
description: The talk turned to family values, and Representative David E. Price, seeking to score a partisan point, told his audience, "You'd think if the President was so interested in keeping families together, he'd be willing to support time off for new mothers."

title: Stride Rite Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Restaurants
description: The remarkable success of three-month-old Carmine's in the theater district underscores several trends among New York City diners. For one, New Yorkers, in spite of all the talk about a new abstemiousness, love to tackle quantities of food that would make a Jewish mother cry uncle. Second, these culinary sophisticates still have a vestigial soft spot for the outmoded Italian-American red-sauce restaurant. And it is also evident that the public craving for bargains is stronger than ever, whether it is a $19.92 lunch special or a place where you can split a $9 mountain of calamari four ways.

title: Germany Accuses East's Spy Chief of Treason
description: The former head of East Germany's highly successful spy service was charged today by German prosecutors with suspected treason, espionage and bribery over a period of more than 30 years.

title: Irwin Toy Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHAKUFWA CHIHANA, a trade union leader and human rights activist from Malawi, will receive the ninth annual Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Award.

title: A House of Faith Weathers 100 Years of Change
description: THE REV. Michael J. Desmond is feeling fine on this day. First, he got a good-news phone call from Delaware: a young couple wants him to marry them. Second, his church had a visitor, and Father Desmond, who likes things organized, was ready with his notes. Third, and most important, Sunday was approaching.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo; Bush Ad Strikes, but Problems Loom
description: To the relief of gloomy Republican advertising connoisseurs, Bush campaign officials this week finally broadcast a television commercial that they thought might actually help their cause.

title: Quick & Reilly Group reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Art in Review
description: David Maisel and Robert Dawson The Opsis Foundation 561 Broadway (at Prince Street) SoHo Through Oct. 24

title: The Cemetery Called East Timor
description: Indonesia for the first time seems genuinely flustered by the world's protests over its invasion and long-term oppression of East Timor, a former Portuguese colony. But not enough to do anything about it.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about debate over potential changes in the New York City police complaint review board misidentified Richard Schwartz. He is Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign manager.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The General; Schwarzkopf Says 2 Camps Courted Him
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf says the campaigns of Gov. Bill Clinton and Ross Perot both sounded him out about running for Vice President.

title: Siege Tactic: Cut Off Water and Light
description: When dusk falls in Sarajevo, thousands of families are cast back into a 19th-century world of candles and oil lamps. Bathing, even brushing teeth, involves measuring out precious water from plastic canisters and bottles. For most, telephones are a receding memory.

title: On My Mind; Hello Again, Suckers
description: H. Ross Perot, having betrayed and suckered millions of Americans, is giving them one more chance to be betrayed and suckered again.

title: No Headline
description: "I need to emphasize a very important message: We get it. " SEAN O'KEEFE, Acting Secretary of the Navy. [ A1:1. ]

title: Archdiocese Imposes Wage Freeze on 2,400
description: The Archdiocese of New York, buffeted by what it described as sharply spiraling costs, has imposed a salary freeze on its estimated 800 priests and 1,600 lay employees, a spokesman for the Archdiocese said early this morning.

title: Critic's Notebook; Fiction and Reality: Blurring the Edges
description: IN the charming early Federico Fellini film "The White Sheik," a young bride named Wanda, who has arrived in Rome for her honeymoon, wanders off in search of her longtime idol, the White Sheik, the hero of one of those photographed comic strips so popular in Italy in the 1950's. Her head crammed with romantic illusions, Wanda cannot see -- not at first, anyway -- that her glamorous idol is really a fat, vulgar parody of Rudolph Valentino, a small-time actor and buffoon who carelessly lies about his life in order to seduce naive women like herself. She is offered a small part in the comic strip, dresses up as a harem girl, and earnestly plays out her role -- she, alone among the actors, mistakes the illusions of art for real life.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Norex America reports earnings for Year June 30
description: b-After a loss of $ 1,143,000 from discontinued operations, and included charge of $ 596,000 from sale of unit, and a non-recurring charge of $ 4,293,000.c-After extraordinary loss of $ 622,000 from early retirement of debt, and included income of $ 3 million, or 49 cents a share, from discontinued operations, and a charge of $ 3 million from sale of unit.

title: Cybermedic Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Bed Bath & Beyond reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: The company listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Foreign Chips Rise in Japan
description: Foreign semiconductor makers increased their share of Japan's market to 16 percent in the second quarter of this year from 14.6 percent in the first quarter, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, announced today.

title: Market Place; A Survival Move For KLM Airlines
description: FOR years, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines has been able to survive largely because of its aggressiveness in bringing passengers from one part of the world to its hub in Amsterdam and flying them out to another.

title: Tony Tamburello, Pianist and Vocal Coach, 72
description: Tony Tamburello, a jazz pianist and a vocal coach whose clients included Tony Bennett, Judy Garland and Juliet Prowse, died on Tuesday at Our Lady of Mercy Hospital in the Bronx, near his home. He was 72 years old.

title: Senate Votes to Override President's Veto of the Family-Leave Bill
description: Challenging President Bush on a major campaign issue, the Senate voted 68 to 31 today to override his veto of the family-leave bill. But the House delayed action as the Democratic leadership tried to round up votes.

title: Saberhagen Is Eight-Ninths as Impressive as Gooden
description: The 1993 starting rotation for the Mets remains an abstraction of blind optimism and genuine uncertainty. There will have to be an addition made, likely from outside the organization. And there will have to be a lot of medical hopes realized.

title: Byrd Is on the Outside, And Looking Inward
description: As with most things that have happened to the Jets this year, Dennis Byrd's move from defensive tackle to defensive end has fallen short of expectations. In a way, Byrd is the personification of the Jets' season to this point.

title: Perot TV Plans Stir Speculation
description: Like a salmon returning to the stream where he was born, Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire, will appear on CNN's "Larry King Live" Monday night, raising the possibility that he will use the show to announce a resumption of his candidacy for the White House.

title: Edberg, Once More With Feeling
description: Avoidance is still his preferred public posture, and unlike his peers Mats Wilander and John McEnroe, he's not a closet rock star. In fact, he's not a closet anything. But Stefan Edberg craved tennis's No. 1 spot, and to retrieve it, he shed a few layers of introversion on the court and discovered himself.

title: COMPANY NEWS: Safety Questions; Did Storm Endanger A Nuclear Plant?
description: When the worst hurricane in decades roars over a nuclear plant and the plant declares an "alert," the second-lowest ranking in a four-stage emergency system, is that good news or bad?

title: Foote, Cone to Lose No Nonsense Hose
description: The Kayser-Roth Corporation in Greensboro, N.C., has decided not to extend the contract on its No Nonsense panty hose account with Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago, which has handled the brand since 1986. The account is being moved to Lois/U.S.A. in New York, which was one of five participants in a review last fall that Foote, Cone had survived.

title: On Matters of Health, Women's Magazines Give Solid Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: For Children
description: Roosevelt Island Tramway Second Avenue, between 59th and 60th Streets Upper East Side (212) 832-4543 Recommended for all ages Daily

title: Transactions
description: Football National Football League LOS ANGELES RAIDERS -- Resigned Napoleon McCallum, running back. Waived Thomas Benson, linebacker. Hockey National Hockey League

title: For Burned-Out Businesses, More Hope Than Help; Bronx Merchants Say They Have Seen City Agencies' Promises, Too, Turn to Ashes
description: On a sunny day last July, Stanley Bell stood helplessly outside his electronics shop and watched a business he had built up over 40 years vanish amid a swirl of flames and smoke. A scrappy businessman, he vowed to rebuild, determined to stay put in the central Bronx neighborhood that nurtured his company, Belco Distributors.

title: Maple Leaf Gardens reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Income Gap Thins Middle-Class Blacks
description: Two economic trends wedging rich from poor in the United States -- the rise of the two-income family and the loss of blue-collar jobs -- have widened the gulf between haves and have-nots in the black population, a new Census Bureau report shows.

title: Vallone Plan Offers Police Review Role
description: Seeking a compromise in a debate that has pitted the Mayor against much of the police force, Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone is proposing to give the police union some influence in the makeup of an all-civilian review board to investigate police misconduct, lawmakers said yesterday.

title: Review/Photography; Storytelling With a Deceptive Simplicity
description: It is fitting that the retrospective of Duane Michals's work at the International Center of Photography, should come to town at the same time as the Rene Magritte show on view a few blocks down Fifth Avenue at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The photographer's admiration for the Belgian Surrealist master is well known, and in one of his most famous photographs the ghostly figure of Magritte, wearing a bowler hat, is double-exposed onto a blank canvas. (A companion show of Mr. Michals's recent work is at the Sidney Janis Gallery, 110 West 57th Street, through Oct. 10.)

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail; A Clinton Team Maps Plans To Get Out the Indian Vote
description: President Bush entered the 1992 campaign figuring that most of the states of the Great Plains, Rocky Mountains and Southwest were already in his political pocket. But his edge in those regions is eroding, and now Bill Clinton's strategists think they see a way for the Governor to snitch a few extra electoral votes out West.

title: Safety-Kleen Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 5
description: b-Included a $ 7.6 million after-tax charge for estimated costs incurred in conjunction with the company's Puerto Rico operations.c-After income of $ 3.2 million, or 6 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: TOSHIBA BUILDS TINIEST ELECTROMAGNETIC MICRO-MOTOR
description: The Toshiba Corporation of Japan said yesterday that it had developed the world's smallest electromagnetic motor, with a diameter of 0.8 millimeter, or about 0.03 inch. The tiny motor, which can spin as fast as 10,000 revolutions a minute, is too small and too weak to do anything practical now. Experts say, however, that in perhaps 10 years, such motors might be used in tiny micro-machines that could crawl through tiny pipes to remove obstructions, or thread through the digestive tract or bloodstream to diagnose ailments.

title: Seymour Weiss, Long an Adviser On Military Policy, Is Dead at 67
description: Seymour Weiss, a defense and foreign-policy expert who was a retired top State Department official and adviser to President Ronald Reagan, died Wednesday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 67 years old.

title: A Breakthrough Judge: What She Always Wanted
description: The views from Pavia & Harcourt's 12th-floor offices in midtown Manhattan are commanding, and the carpeted halls, in soft pastels, are adorned by modern Italian paintings. But Sonia Sotomayor, a partner at the commercial litigation firm, was boxing up her things the other day to take another job. The new one comes with a pay cut, scant carpeting, dingy lighting and a room without a view.

title: Righteous Anger Spilled Over at Police Rally; To Combat Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Art; Russia's Fling With the Future
description: "THE GREAT UTOPIA," the survey of Russian and Soviet avant-garde art opening today at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, intends to overwhelm the viewer, and unfortunately it does. With more than 800 paintings, sculptures, drawings, photographs, textiles, ceramics, furniture and architectural models, occupying almost the entirety of the newly renovated building, it must surely be, as the museum boasts, the largest show in the history of the Guggenheim. At least, it feels that way.

title: G.M. Faces the Prospect of Another Strike Today
description: The General Motors Corporation, which two weeks ago was recovering from a disruptive 10-day strike at its Lordstown, Ohio, manufacturing complex, faces another strike as early as Friday morning in Lansing, Mich.

title: Art in Review
description: Geoffrey Biddle Klarfeld Perry Gallery 472 Broome Street SoHo Through Oct. 24

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidates on the Issues; Two Proposals for Health Care
description: Medical prices are rising about twice as fast as other consumer prices. The United States spends far more on health care than any other country. Medicare and Medicaid eat up a growing share of the Federal budget. But 35 million Americans have no health insurance. THE PROPOSALS

title: Los Angeles Mayor Won't Run Again
description: Mayor Tom Bradley announced today that he would not seek a sixth term next year, after 20 years in office during which he presided over the transformation of Los Angeles from what was barely more than a collection of suburbs into one of the world's major cities.

title: Capilano International reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net incomeResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Robert Caviano, 42; Founded AIDS Group
description: Robert C. Caviano, a founder of Lifebeat, the music industry's organization to fight AIDS, died on Sept. 22 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Reviews/Theater; Women Taking Their Places, Rightful or Not
description: Two young men (Eric Lutes and Eric Nolan) are drinking at a neighborhood bar and commiserating with each other about the good old days when men were manly and women didn't spend so much time working out in gyms. This smug lamentation is interrupted by the arrival of two women, one of whom (Deborah Laufer) happens to have had a long, disastrous affair with Mr. Lutes. What follows this accidental encounter in Theresa Rebeck's "Big Mistake" is an abrasive and humorous look at a sexist battleground.

title: Parolee Arrested in Slaying While Held in Second Case
description: A 31-year-old convicted murderer, released from prison five months ago, was arrested on Wednesday and charged today in the slaying two weeks ago of a 38-year-old mother of two in the bedroom of her house here on the North Shore.

title: Isco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Candidates On Television
description: The Presidential campaigners have scheduled these television appearances in coming days: Senator Al Gore

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the plan by Bradlees Inc. to acquire and reopen six Alexander's Department Stores that closed in bankruptcy this year in the New York region misstated the opinion of the chairman of Alexander's on the prospect of bankruptcy court approval. The chairman, Robin Farkas, said he did not expect objections from the court, not that he did expect them.

title: New Jersey Sells Refunding Issue
description: New Jersey yesterday priced for public offering a $146.4 million issue of refunding certificates of participation. The issue was won in competitive bidding by a group of underwriters managed by Lehman Brothers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10 GREATER CURRENCY RISKS

title: Mexico May Renegotiate Free Trade, or It May Not
description: Three days after President Carlos Salinas de Gortari appeared to rule out any renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement, he now appears to have ruled it back in. Or something like that.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Wednesday showing the possible impact of cable television legislation misstated the royalties that broadcasters are expected to receive from cable companies. The highest estimate has been $1 billion, not $3 billion.

title:
About Real Estate;
2 Projects Planned Near Brooklyn Starrett Complex
description: For two decades, the East New York section of Brooklyn bordering Jamaica Bay has been dominated by a vast high-rise rental project. Now called Starrett at Spring Creek and originally known as Starrett City, the complex of 46 buildings has 5,881 apartments and a waiting list of 4,000 families.

title: The Perot Tease
description: Ross Perot won deservedly high marks in the spring for energizing millions of disenchanted voters, for talking sensibly about the Federal deficit and for throwing a healthy scare into the political parties. But by summer he had shown himself to be an ego-tripper, trifling with other people's fears. He built a huge army of eager soldiers and then, unable to pay the price of political daring, abruptly fled to his bunker.

title: At the Bar; In Quayle's home state, a lawyer and ex-backer doesn't like the Republican attacks on the bar.
description: Among the otherwise forgettable ad hoc groups supporting this year's Presidential tickets, one seems particularly odd. In fact, it could be called "Masochists for Bush-Quayle," for it is made up of what have become the Republicans' favorite whipping boys and girls: lawyers.

title: Oldsmobile's Review Casts a Shadow Over Leo Burnett
description: ARE there worms in those shiny apples that have become emblematic of the Leo Burnett Company?

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows, performances and art exhibitions in the New York metropolitan region that close soon: Closing This Weekend

title: Frank P. Briggs, 98, a Publisher And Truman's Senate Successor
description: Frank P. Briggs, a rural newspaper publisher from Missouri who succeeded Harry S. Truman in the United States Senate in 1944, died on Wednesday at Samaritan Memorial Hospital in Macon, Mo. He was 98 years old and lived in Macon.

title: Judge Is Confirmed To Court of Appeals
description: George Bundy Smith was confirmed by the State Senate today as an associate judge on the Court of Appeals, the state's top court. Mr. Smith, who is 55 years old and had been a justice in the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan since 1987, was nominated for the post last month by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Pat on Back Before Back of Hand
description: In four years with the Giants, Bob Kratch has started 15 games, including all three this season. On Monday night, in the Giants' 27-14 victory over the Chicago Bears, he played the best game of his career, "an excellent performance," Coach Ray Handley said.

title: 2 Cheese Makers Pick New Agencies
description: Two cheese makers are smiling and saying "Agency."

title: Reviews/Theater; Kyogen, the Comic Relief for Noh
description: Kyogen plays, a tradition in Japan since the 14th century, are small-scale folk comedies that are often presented as interludes during evenings of Noh drama. In them, acting and mime take precedence, although the plays can express an aura of grandness within a framework of intimacy.

title: NEGATIVE RESEARCH REPORT PUSHES MERCK'S STOCK DOWN
description: Merck & Company's stock fell $1.125 cents yesterday after IMS America, a marketing research group that tracks prescription trends, reported that new prescriptions for its drugs were disappointing in August. Merck closed at $45.625 on the New York Stock Exchange, where it was the second-most-active stock, with about 4.4 million shares traded.

title: Dennis Thim, Fashion Journalist, 33
description: Dennis Thim, the European editor and correspondent of Women's Wear Daily and the fashion magazines W and M, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Paris. He was 33 years old and lived in Paris.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Off the Trail -- Visits With Americans; Showing the Good Ol' Boys How to Play Their Own Game
description: Barbara Christmas looked absolutely victorious in a tailored suit and pearl earrings as she came back into town recently to settle political scores with the Good Ol' Boy establishment.

title: Clinton Hits Hard in New Jersey (Close), Relaxes in New York (Ahead)
description: About 2,000 people came to hear Gov. Bill Clinton talk about health care at the Merck & Company headquarters here today, and with egalitarian self-interest, each came with a personal agenda for the candidate to address.

title: CUNY Was Known as 'Proletarian Harvard'
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Foley, Not Flutie, but So What?
description: The football progress at Boston College can be measured by the small piece of paper on a cafeteria bulletin board that caught Glenn Foley's eye.

title: Jewelmasters reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Advisory Group Calls Many Bus and Subway Routes Erratic
description: Surveying conditions from the rider's vantage point -- waiting at the stop -- a study by a New York City Transit Authority advisory group has concluded that "many bus and subway routes operate with erratic and undependable service, undermining customer confidence."

title: 2 Held in Scheme to Cheat Wary Lottery Winner
description: When a refugee from Vietnam who lives in Queens won $8.3 million in the New York lottery last February, he expressed fear that he would soon be victimized by people trying to steal his winnings and said he did not want his winning publicized. He was apparently right.

title: Sun Microsystems' Suit Role
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., the leader in the $15.3 billion market for computer work stations, acknowledged today that it had provided loan guarantees to a software company that brought an antitrust suit against the Open Software Foundation, a computer industry research organization.

title: Advice of Stalin: Hold Korean War P.O.W.'s
description: Stalin advised Communist leaders in China and Korea to hold back 20 percent of American pilots captured during the Korean War and use them as bargaining chips with the United States, according to Soviet documents delivered to the United States Government today.

title: Dr. John A. Collins, 58, Educator Who Led Change in Transfusions
description: Dr. John A. Collins, a medical educator who led an Army research team in Vietnam that made a significant change in blood transfusion practices for casualties, died on Monday. He was 58 years old and lived in Stanford, Calif.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Sharon Isbin Guitarist Juilliard Theater

title: Walter Miller, 64, Lawyer and Member Of Civic Committees
description: Walter A. Miller, who practiced law in Brooklyn for 64 years, died on Thursday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 87 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Mideast Arms Sales Reveal Policy Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Bad News for Science News
