Bill Clinton at the headquarters of Merck & Company in Rahway, N.J., referred imprecisely to an invitation from Merck, which was solicited by the office of Gov. Jim Florio. Mr. Florio's office asked that Merck invite Mr. Clinton to appear, not that Mr. Florio be included.

title: U.S. Paging Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an after-tax non-recurring, non-cash gain of $ 2,065,000, or 77 cents a share, from a litigation settlement.c-Net lossThe shares outstanding reflected the impact of the issuance, since the June 3 intitial public offering, of 1 million shares for the 1992 year-end and fourth quarter.It also reflected the conversion of the preferred stock and the about 1-for-2.2 reverse stock split completed prior to the completion of the initial public offering.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Bosnia, in Arms Plea to U.N., Says Sarajevo May Fall Soon
description: The Bosnian Government has sent an urgent appeal to the United Nations Security Council warning that Sarajevo is in "imminent danger" of falling to besieging Serbian nationalist troops unless Bosnian forces are exempted from a United Nations arms embargo.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ross Perot; Nominees' Camps Make Their Cases to Perot Backers
description: Top delegations from both Presidential campaigns conducted a careful courtship of the supporters of Ross Perot today, but the Texas billionaire kept everyone dangling. He suggested he would announce by Thursday whether he would re-enter the race.

title: James J. Herron, Executive, 83
description: James J. Herron, a retired executive of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation in New York, died on Friday at North Florida Regional Hospital in Gainesville, Fla. He was 83 years old and lived in Edison and Gillette, N.J., before moving to Gainesville four years ago.

title: Data Translation Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Germans Plan, Then Cancel, Celebration of a Nazi Missile
description: Fifty years ago, a team of German scientists successfully tested a modern rocket and ushered in the space age.

title: Patterns
description: The Quiet Italian Piazza Italia, the Italian Trade Commission's monthlong promotion at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street, runs until Oct. 9. But last Thursday's runway show of the Genny, Byblos and Complice fall styles, sponsored by Henri Bendel, was the last fashion event.

title: Observer; Incident At Hyannis
description: A man races to a pay telephone. Something of great importance has occurred or is about to occur. Perhaps something truly dreadful will happen unless timely telephonic communication averts it.

title: Iraq Opposition Says Parley In North Unifies Its Ranks
description: Strengthening its drive to topple the Baghdad Government, the Iraqi opposition has announced a unification of ranks after meetings in Kurdish-controlled northern Iraq, and has called on all Iraqis to join in its efforts.

title: CST Entertainment Imaging reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit for forgiveness of debt of $ 28,057 for the quarter and 1,062,612, or 8 cents a share, for the year, and both the quarter and year included a non-recurring charge of $ 1,093,000 for the write-down of the company's film library and settlement of a lawsuit.c-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 106,768 and an extraordinary credit of $ 410,618, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, both for forgiveness of debt.

title: SANTA FE PACIFIC SIGNS NEW UNION CONTRACT
description: The Santa Fe Pacific Corporation's railway unit said yesterday that it had signed a new contract with the United Transportation Union to allow two-man crews to operate trains on the eastern half of the Santa Fe system. In exchange, the company will give each of the 1,800 employees affected by the agreement a $10,000 lump sum payment and a deferred pension payment of $65,000. The payments replace a productivity fund, which was used to give workers on smaller crews extra pay, the company said. The company said that no workers would be furloughed as a result of the new contract, but workers may choose to leave with a $75,000 payment. A similar contract with employees of the railway's western lines was put into effect in January.

title: Insuring Pool In Final Days In New Jersey
description: At midnight Wednesday, 720,000 New Jersey drivers will begin entering the private automobile insurance market in the final phase of Gov. Jim Florio's two-year plan to dismantle the state's high-risk insurance pool.

title: Jerusalem Journal; Cry of the Ancient Kin: Don't Doubt Our Judaism!
description: At the start of the Jewish New Year, a period of spiritual reflection, Jews who were airlifted here from Ethiopia complain that Israel's religious and civil authorities treat them as somehow less Jewish than others.

title: Business and Health; Competing Plans For Californians
description: CALIFORNIA, hit hard by a recession compounded by military cutbacks and permanently lost jobs in electronics, is giving special attention to health care policy and political issues. At least six million Californians do not have health insurance. With 9.8 percent unemployment, even more people are in danger of losing coverage.

title: Assessing Germany: Potential or Peril?
description: In a Europe convulsed by financial turmoil, people are coming to terms with the economic power of Germany. What seems clear to many is that a Germany in isolation would be far more of a threat than a Germany locked into European institutions, and that Germany's economic power is far less menacing than its military power ever was.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Volunteers; Perot Representatives: Their Cause Is the Texan, Even When He Disappoints
description: When he was a teen-ager, John Bishop was a page for Senator Barry Goldwater, the conservative Republican from Arizona. In his 20's, he was a self-described "hippy" hanging out in San Francisco's Haight-Ashbury district. He is now a businessman from Sante Fe, N.M., who says he is willing to stick by his new cause -- Ross Perot -- no matter how much the Dallas billionaire may have disappointed him in the past or might again in the future.

title: Morris Is Good-Luck Arm, And Toronto Will Rub It
description: Having barreled through September at a maddening pace, many players heading toward the post-season must be doing a great deal of soul-searching.

title: SOUTHWESTERN BELL WILL MOVE HEADQUARTERS TO TEXAS
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation said yesterday that it would move its headquarters to San Antonio from St. Louis by late March. The telephone holding company said the move would put it closer to its primary growth market in Texas, which represents about 60 percent of the company's business, as well as investment opportunities in Mexico and South America. About 500 people work at the holding company's headquarters..

title: Kimble Shooting for the Top Again
description: Cuffing the ball 45 feet from the basket, Bo Kimble says he would hear, "Shoot it," from the Los Angeles Clippers fans and "Don't dare shoot it" from the Clipper bench.

title: Critic's Notebook; Today's Anxiety Stalks a Revival Of a Musical Satire on Politics
description: At each performance of its new production of "Of Thee I Sing," the 1931 Gershwin musical satirizing Presidential politics, Arena Stage takes a straw poll of the audience's own Presidential preferences. So far Clinton-Gore is whipping Bush-Quayle by an 8-to-1 margin -- no surprise in this overwhelmingly Democratic city. But the Arena's "Of Thee I Sing" and the audience response to it send a more complicated message about the mood inside the Beltway. While major change may or may not be in the wings for the capital, one senses that the correlative of change, anxiety, has already arrived.

title: Kent Is Easy to Figure, But His Statistics Aren't
description: Jeff Kent's numbers are rich with potential and risk. There is power -- 10 of his 21 hits with the Mets have been for extra bases. And there is peril -- he has struck out 27 times in 96 times at bat.

title: Researchers Develop 'Smart' Window to Cut Energy Consumption
description: IN an effort to make buildings and vehicles more energy efficient, and reduce energy consumption in the United States, researchers at Tufts University have developed a window that can regulate the amount of sunlight flowing into a building or car and the amount of heat flowing out.

title: Veris (49ers) and Jackson (Miami) Hook On
description: In what could be the first sign of unlimited free agency coming to the National Football League, Garin Veris and Keith Jackson, two of four players who were granted temporary free agency by a Federal court ruling last week, today became the first to reach agreements with new teams.

title: Tax. Blame. Regret. Elect.
description: L et's just shoot straight. George Bush has repeatedly told the American people that by his standard for judging what taxes or fees are, he raised them only once, and Bill Clinton raised them 128 times. If that is not a lie, then it is its identical twin.

title: After War, Vietnam Deported Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Hanson Overseas Finance B.V., a unit of the British holding company Hanson P.L.C., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $1.25 billion of debt securities. * Rhone-Poulenc S.A., a French holding company with operations in chemicals and pharmaceuticals, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $750 million of debt securities. * South Washington County, Minn., is offering $24.85 million of tax-exempt general-obligation refunding bonds for Independent School District No. 833 through Kemper Securities. The issue is priced to yield 5 percent for a maturity in 1999 and up to 6.15 percent for maturities in 2009 through 2011. It is rated A by Moody's Investors Service. Common Stock * John Alden Financial Corp., Miami, an insurance holding company, is making an initial public offering of 7.35 million shares of common stock at $15 a share with First Boston Corp. and Merrill Lynch the managers of the U.S. syndicate offering of 5.88 million shares. Ratings * Bemis Co.'s senior debt rating has been upgraded to A, from A-, and its commercial paper to A-1, from A-2, by S.& P. The company, a maker of packaging and industrial products, is based in Minneapolis.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Sept. 21 about Mike Ditka, the Chicago Bears' coach, misstated the New York Giants' history against the Bears in Chicago. Before this season, the Giants had not won a football game in Chicago since 1962, when the Bears played at Wrigley Field.

title: Don't Undermine Basic Research
description: Biomedical research is facing its annual mo ment of truth the House-Senate conference tomorrow to decide on appropriations for the National Institutes of Health. This year, basic research faces the ax. That would hurt medicine.

title: Mr. Bush Sells Out Arms Control
description: One happy consequence of the end of the cold war is that defense budgets around the world are shrinking. One unhappy consequence is that nations are scrambling to peddle arms abroad in order to keep their arms makers in business.

title: 3Com Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Police Dept. Report Assails Officers in New York Rally
description: Acting Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly yesterday ordered 42 New York City police officers disciplined, in a report that condemned both on- and off-duty behavior in the recent demonstration at City Hall.

title: Mets Fall Twice to Phillies
description: The Mets, doing their best to preserve the last remaining element of drama to their season, kept alive their chances of finishing in last place in the National League East by being swept in a doubleheader by the Phillies last night at Shea Stadium. Both scores were 7-6.

title: The Talk of Hollywood; Achieving A State Of Grace By Water
description: Norman Maclean hated Hollywood. Maclean, the author of the classic, elegiac memoir "A River Runs Through It," once told Robert Redford that Hollywood was the land of grease and the weasel. Mr. Redford recalled Maclean's words: "After the handshake you notice how greasy your hand is, and they always try to weasel out of a deal."

title: Marge R. Manderson, Civil Rights Advocate, 64
description: Marge R. Manderson, a program officer with the Southern Regional Council for more than 35 years, died Wednesday at her home in Atlanta. She was 64.

title: Forest at South Pole
description: Fossils from a forest that grew nearly 300 million years ago in the Antarctic indicate that the region was warmer and more supportive of plant life than scientists had previously thought.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 21 about New York City's search for a film commissioner referred incorrectly to a labor dispute in New York last year between the major motion picture studios and film craft union members. The studios boycotted New York for seven months during a contract dispute over compensation; there was no strike by cinematographers and stagehands. An accord was reached last summer. A reader pointed out the error in a letter dated Aug. 31; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Little Switzerland reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BOXING Hill Regains Title in Unanimous Decision

title: In Oakland, the Return of the Native Is Bittersweet
description: Jose Canseco's return was not exactly triumphant. His back hurt. His feelings still hurt a little, too. But at least the fans didn't forget him.

title: Wellco Enterprises Inc.  reports earnings for Year June 27
description: b-Included a net gain of $ 522,000 from sale of securities.

title: CMS/Data Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: SEARS SHIFTING AIM BACK TO RETAILING
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that it planned to dispose of its securities business, Discover credit card and real estate operations and to sell up to 20 percent of its Allstate insurance subsidiary in a public stock offering.

title: Intermetrics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Woodstock at 25: Adults Take Over
description: For Johnny Jules, who sleeps under the stars on a sway-backed pink couch in this rural Catskills town, the site of the Woodstock Festival in 1969 is sacred ground where the seeds of peace and brotherly love were sown.

title: A BBDO Exhibit Spotlights Two Quiet, Creative Auteurs
description: A RETROSPECTIVE of the creative output of BBDO New York is focusing attention on two executives there who, uncharacteristically for the ego-driven advertising business, usually remain behind the scenes.

title: NCR Shows Pen-Based Computer
description: For computer visionaries, the pen has always loomed mightier than the keyboard as a way of entering data into a computer. If computer users could tap on a screen with a pen or use one to write out a few instructions in normal human scrawl, they would no longer be confined to desks or chairs, but could wander wherever they would typically carry a clipboard or a briefcase, whether a factory floor or a courthouse.

title: Seoul Gets Some Diplomatic Backing in China
description: South Korea's President, Roh Tae Woo, said on Tuesday that China's top leaders had endorsed his policy of persuading North Korea to abandon its nuclear-weapons program in return for a promise of normal relations with the West and substantial economic assistance from Seoul.

title: In Their Own Words
description: PRESIDENT BUSH

title: Ousted Haitian Chief, at U.N., Denounces Vatican
description: The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the ousted Haitian leader, denounced the Vatican at the United Nations today, calling it the only state in the world to recognize the Government that overthrew him.

title: Davstar Industries Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to June 30
THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Strategy; 2 Camps Regard A Perot Revival With Less Fear
description: Strategists in the Bush and Clinton campaigns agree that a revived candidacy by Ross Perot would not be the powerful third force that it seemed last spring. But the Bush forces are hoping that it will help shake up a race that has seemed ominously stable for a President lagging in the polls.

title: Johnson Goes From Dream Ride to the Rat Race
description: Pat Riley visited with Magic Johnson last week in Los Angeles. There was no need to pop the question. The gleam in Johnson's eyes was a happy announcement that he would be returning to the Lakers.

title: Seniors and Juniors
description: Critics of Social Security and Medicare have long charged that as older adults get more, children get less. The accusation has promoted the belief that seniors are "greedy geezers" while the nation's children are ever more deprived. But now the seniors are fighting to restore their image by helping the kids; after all, they weren't born yesterday.

title: Environmental Politics Is Making the Kitchen Hotter
description: WOLFGANG PUCK, the celebrity chef whose duck- and shrimp-topped pizzas have become the snack of Hollywood stars, couldn't wait to join the Pure Food Campaign. After years of fighting with the Federal Government over how he must label the frozen version of his pizzas, he is evangelical about the need to test and label genetically engineered foods, for which the Pure Food Campaign is vigorously lobbying.

title: Pharmakinetics Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes $ 1.05 million in pre-tax reorganization gains in the quarter and $ 902,000 in pre-tax reorganization gains in the year; the year also included a gain of $ 5.9 million on the sale of the company's holdings in Royce Laboratories and a loss of $ 1.2 million on the sale of the company's IBR subsidiary.c-Net loss and included $ 6.73 million in pre-tax reorganization charges in the quarter and year.

title: At $3 Billion, Where Is Disaster Relief?
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: Football National Football League

title: A Rash of Injuries Shifts Burden Onto Washington
description: When defensive left end Dennis Byrd dislocated his right shoulder during the 18-10 loss to the Los Angeles Rams on Sunday, the already thin Jets defensive line got even thinner. For Marvin Washington, though, the challenge thickened.

title: NORTHERN TELECOM BUYS 7.5% STAKE IN MMB
description: The Canadian telecommunications company Northern Telecom will take a 7.5 percent stake in MMB, the key holding company for both the Matra S.A. military electronics group and the Hachette S.A. publishing company, an MMB official said yesterday. "This shows that Northern Telecom will become a long-term industrial partner of the group," the MMB spokesman said, adding that Northern Telecom's investment in MMB would cost about $50 million.

title: Script Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included provisions of $ 200,000 in the quarter and $ 700,000 in the year, for bad debts, and non-recurring expenses of $ 300,000 and $ 500,000 in the quarter and year, respectively.c-Net income and included a gain of $ 25,900, or 2 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, and a gain of $ 31,200, or 2 cents a share, in the year, both from tax-loss carryforwards.

title: 9 Killed in Southern Lebanon As Rival Militia Units Clash
description: In a new surge of fighting in southern Lebanon, nine people were killed today, including an Irish soldier serving with the United Nations peacekeeping force.

title: Nation Split, Havel Aspires to a New Political Life
description: Vaclav Havel, the once and probable future President, is like an athlete at halftime. Having left the field in July so he would not have to preside over the breakup of Czechoslovakia into two countries, he is reflecting on the gains and losses of the first half and girding for the second.

title: TPEX Exploration Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net lossc-Net income

title: Jury Fought Prosecutor on Bomb Plant
description: Before the Government accepted a plea agreement with the contractor running an illegally polluted nuclear bomb factory, the grand jury hearing the case so badly wanted to indict the people who ran the plant that it wrote the indictments itself, a member of the jury has said. But the prosecutor blocked the grand jury, the juror said, and ultimately, no individuals were charged.

title: Esta Huttner, 83, Dies; Started a Foundation
description: Esta Brodey Huttner, a founder and longtime board member of the Karen Horney Foundation, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83 years old.

title: Winter May Kill 100,000 In Bosnia, the C.I.A. Warns
description: United States intelligence experts and United Nations officials are warning that winter weather could lead to well over 100,000 deaths in Bosnia and Herzegovina from hunger and exposure if the fighting continues to hamper relief efforts and assistance is not increased.

title: CHRONICLE
description: How do you go about planning the celebration of a 250th birthday? To start with, "You must have a lot of candles," DANIEL P. JORDAN, the executive director of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation, said yesterday. Mr. Jordan is in the throes of mapping out the logistics for an 18-month-long commemoration of Jefferson's birth on April 13, 1743.

title: At Last, Giants' Baker To Hit Coliseum Turf
description: The last time Stephen Baker stood in the Los Angeles Coliseum, his uniform belonged to a security company. His job was to keep wild fans off the field, monitor the stands, escort the Raiders' cheerleaders to their cars after games.

title: Correction
description: In yesterday's column it should have been noted that in the diagramed position, East can defeat the contract by two tricks by returning a trump.

title: Market Place; Is the Worst Over For Tokyo Stocks?
description: AFTER falling for more than two and a half years, the Tokyo stock market seems to have recovered some of its lost ground and stabilized, leading a growing number of economists and analysts to say the worst is over.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 19 about the author William A. Swanberg and a related correction in this space last Thursday referred erroneously to the subjects of his last book, "Whitney Father, Whitney Heiress." They were William Collins Whitney, Secretary of the Navy in the first Cleveland Administration, and his daughter, Dorothy. The book did not deal with the publisher John Hay Whitney, who in any case did not have a daughter named Dorothy.

title: Nestor Inc. reports earnings for Year June 30
Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Cooks in Voting Booth
description: To the Editor:

title: Jumama Journal; Bedouin's World Now: House and a Pickup Truck
description: Dressed in a billowing white robe and carrying an old double-barreled shotgun, Mohammed Issa padded softly in bare feet through the rolling white sand dunes along the Mediterranean coast.

title: Gelman Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 352,000, which included an extraordinary product liability settlement of $ 558,000, before tax.c-Net lossd-Net incomeLatest year's loss from continuing operations of $ 859,000 included $ 2.5 million after-tax charge related to the anticipated settlement of environmental lawsuits.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Timothy S. Healy; A Priest Finds a Bully but Secular Pulpit
description: TO the library staff, he's Dr. Healy; to his secretary, he's Tim. In his Washington years, he was Father Healy, and now and then, Father Tim. At Il Brunello, an Italian restaurant on West 56th Street he discovered and enjoys, he's simply "Buon giorno, signore."

title: 3Com Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Boeing Asks To Sell Jets To Iran Air
description: The Boeing Company has tentatively agreed to sell nearly $1 billion of commercial jetliners to state-owned Iran Air, if American policy changes to allow such exports, two Boeing spokesmen and a lawyer for Iran Air said today.

title: An Old Pro Aches for a Title
description: Another potential victory had evaporated into the chilly night air Monday, tacking another loss onto an already dreary season, but the Yankees did not dwell on it. The players showered quickly, dressed even more quickly and bolted for the door. Every player except Don Mattingly.

title: Review/Film; Mixing Fiction and Fact on Palestinian Conflict
description: Amos Kollek, who wrote, directed and acted in "Double Edge," a political drama set in contemporary Jerusalem, happens to be the son of Teddy Kollek, the Mayor of that strife-torn city. The director's father also appears in the film, which opens today. He is one of several prominent real-life figures who are interviewed by Faye Milano (Faye Dunaway), an imperiously self-assured correspondent for a newspaper called The New York Herald. During the film, the reporter, who has a three-week assignment in the region, methodically sets about soliciting views of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict from leaders on both sides.

title: Barry Jewelers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 49,229,000, which results from the conversion of bondholders' long-term debt to equity and the forgiveness of interest expense as part of the conversion under the company's plan of reorganization, which became effective June 30, 1991.c-Net loss

title: AIDS-Like Illness Is Found to Be Rare
description: SCIENTISTS from around the world said yesterday that they had found nearly 100 cases of an AIDS-like illness in which there was no detectable evidence of the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Revco D.S. Inc.  reports earnings for 12wks to Aug 22
description: b-After an income tax benefit of $ 2,953,000.

title: Dollar Falls Sharply Again, Mainly Against the Mark
description: The dollar fell sharply again yesterday, pushed lower by concerns that the Federal Reserve Board will respond to continued weak economic data by cutting short-term interest rates again soon, possibly as early as Friday.

title: Bush to Visit Newark Union For Support
description: President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton will both be in New Jersey today to pick up support, financial and fraternal, for their campaigns. Mr. Clinton will attend a fund-raising event in Somerset, and Mr. Bush will visit a construction union's offices in Newark in what the local's leader pictured as a prelude to an endorsement.

title: Phibro-Mobil Pact
description: Phibro Energy Inc., a unit of Salomon Inc., said it planned to license an integrated energy trading system to the Mobil Oil Corporation. Phibro's software unit, MO2 Technologies Inc., will provide Mobil's sales, supply and trading divisions with Next Computer work stations running MO2 's energy trading information, Phibro said. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Millions Cast Votes in Angolan Election Amid Fears of a Return to Violence
description: Under intense international scrutiny, millions of Angolans voted today in the first broadly contested democratic elections in this war-ravaged country's history.

title: Why G.M. Buyer Unnerves Suppliers
description: The hype is the billions of dollars annually that Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriotua promises he will save the General Motors Corporation in lower outlays for parts and materials. The cold reality is embodied in a nondescript factory here that makes millions of seat belts every year for Cadillacs, Buicks, Pontiacs and Oldsmobiles.

title: Search for Police Leader Enters the Final Phase
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins began the final round in his selection of a new police commissioner last night as resentment simmered against him in precinct houses throughout New York City over a report sharply critical of police conduct at a City Hall demonstration earlier this month.

title: Wedding Information reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $ 478,079 from discontinued operations.c-Net incomeThe company attributed the losses in the latest periods primarily to losses from operation as well as from the sales of the assets of Colorado Designs Inc. and America's Corporate Image.

title: A Crucial Linkup in the U.S. Data Highway
description: The keepers of the National Science Foundation's supercomputer arsenal have created a blueprint for combining their 21 machines into a continental weapon capable of attacking the most formidable scientific problems.

title:
Real Estate;
Vertical Mall Going Ahead In California
description: A NEW YORK CITY developer says he is close to getting leases on 50 percent of the space in an office building that he plans to convert into a vertical retail mall at a key intersection in downtown San Francisco.

title: Public & Private; A Feeling Called Mama
description: At Children's Village, a residential treatment center for 300 kids in New York's Westchester County, there are boys who will tell you that Mama walks on water. Could be that Mama said she was coming on visiting day and didn't show. Could be that Mama said they'd live together soon and then disappeared. Could be that Mama hit hard and said mean things.

title: Robert Kreidler Memorial
description: A memorial service for Robert N. Kreidler, president of the Charles A. Dana Foundation, is to be held at 4:30 P.M. on Oct. 14 in the Tishman Auditorium of the New School for Social Research at 66 West 12th Street. Mr. Kreidler died on Aug. 30 at age 62.

title: Clarcor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 213,000, or 2 cents a share, and $ 745,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Wine Talk
description: "THE reports of my death," wrote Mark Twain, "are greatly exaggerated."

title: Czechs More Eager Than Slovaks to Separate
description: To the Editor:

title: Foxmoor Industries reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included extraordinary one-time writedown of $ 94,000 for certain assets.

title: Crucial Charge Is Dismissed In Weinberger Perjury Case
description: A Federal judge today dismissed one of the five felony charges against Caspar W. Weinberger. The charge accused the former Defense Secretary of having illegally concealed private diaries from Congress during its investigation of the Iran-contra affair.

title: Campaign Concerns Prompt White House To Drop Waste Plan
description: The White House has dropped a proposal to allow manufacturers to dispose of hazardous wastes in town dumps, senior Bush Administration officials said today, because of concern that the Bush campaign has become vulnerable to Democratic criticism on the environment.

title: William Douglas-Home, 80, Dies; English Writer of Stage Comedies
description: William Douglas-Home, a prolific English playwright of light comedy, died on Monday at his home in Winchester, England. He was 80 years old.

title: Bergen Brunswig reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss of $ 1,110,000 for the quarter and income of $ 3,876,000, or 10 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations, and the quarter and year included an extraordinary credit of $ 3,976,000, or 11 cents a share, which represented gain on disposition of Commtron.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,136,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 6,076,000, or 14 cents a share, for the year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 BRAZIL'S HOUSE IMPEACHES COLLOR

title: Deficit Narrowed at Revco
description: Revco D.S. Inc. said today that its loss in its first quarter after emerging from bankruptcy proceedings narrowed to $1.54 million from $14 million a year earlier.

title: Price Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Strong Words for a Police Riot
description: A heavy cloud of politics hangs over Acting New York City Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly's preliminary report on the police riot at City Hall. The report is thick with language critical of the unruly behavior but apparently thin on charges against individual rioters. Even so, the report is no whitewash; it serves the public's interest by maintaining the Police Department's credibility.

title: INSIDE
description: Niagara Falls Copter Crash

title: Johnson, Unbowed by H.I.V., Will Return to Pro Basketball
description: Undaunted by his infection with the virus that causes AIDS, Magic Johnson announced his return to professional basketball yesterday after a one-season absence.

title: Corrections
description: A diagram in Science Times yesterday about surgery to treat epilepsy in children reversed two labels for areas of the brain in some copies. In those copies that included references to the temporal lobe and the basal ganglia, the basal ganglia should have appeared at the left.

title: Staurovsky Let Go by Jets
description: The Jason Staurovsky era as Jets place-kicker ended yesterday after only four games -- all losses -- when the Plan B free agent from the New England Patriots was waived. In his place, the Jets signed Cary Blanchard, a free agent released Monday by the New Orleans Saints.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Debates; BUSH SHIFTS STAND, SAYING HE'S READY TO HOLD 4 DEBATES
description: President Bush challenged Gov. Bill Clinton today to four debates on consecutive Sundays in a surprise move that was intended to shake up the Presidential race and silence Democratic accusations that he fears his opponent.

title: Navy Planning to Cancel Long-Troubled Radar System
description: Reversing the Navy's longstanding support, Acting Navy Secretary Sean O'Keefe will recommend that the Pentagon cancel a $2 billion electronic radar-jamming system that has failed crucial flight tests on fighter planes it is designed to protect, senior Navy officials said today.

title: Review/Film; Mamet's Real Estate Sharks and Their Prey
description: They're guys on the edge. They are real estate salesmen on the North Side of Chicago, working out of a shabby office with a water cooler, trying to make ends meet by selling second-rate home sites in Florida and Arizona with names like Glengarry Highlands and Rio Rancho. Everything they earn comes from commissions, which can mount up. Yet it's not easy selling real estate even in the best of times. When money is tight, forget it.

title: Rangers Say New Lemieux Pact Won't Affect Messier
description: Neil Smith, the president and general manager of the Rangers, said tonight that if Mario Lemieux signs a big new contract with the Pittsburgh Penguins next week, as seems likely, it would not have any immediate effect on the Rangers' pay scale, including the salary of their best player, Mark Messier.

title: California Amplifier reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
Weak Dollar Brings Rise in Rates
description: A sharp decline in the dollar kept United States credit markets from enjoying any gains yesterday from the sort of economic reports that usually propel bonds higher.

title: Heads of Store Clerks' Union Held in Theft
description: Two officials of a union representing department store employees have been arrested on charges that they embezzled almost $1 million from their union's welfare fund, Federal prosecutors announced yesterday in Brooklyn.

title: Sports of The Times; Magic Words For Earvin: 'Go for It'
description: YOU could call it courage. You could call it ego. You could call it denial. You could call it love. Whatever label you want to put on it, the decision belonged to Magic Johnson, and he made it: "I'm back."

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail; Quayle Sees Good Side To What Perot Decides
description: Vice President Dan Quayle says Ross Perot "certainly sounds" like a candidate to him, and he has some thoughts about whether a Perot candidacy would help the Bush-Quayle ticket or the Clinton-Gore ticket.

title: Vivra Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Food Notes
description: More Coffee Bars

title: No Headline
description: "God has put me here to play basketball, to do my thing on the court. So that's where I'm going to do my thing, on that court." -- MAGIC JOHNSON. [ A1:4. ]

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ross Perot; Grass-Roots Drive Shows Hand of Oz
description: As Ross Perot awaits the word from his supporters about re-entering the Presidential race, there are increasing signs that his grass-roots organization is neither as large nor as independent as he purports it to be. There are also signs that the support he cites may not be as strong as he maintains.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: FORD MOTOR CO., Dearborn, Mich., and Nissan Motor Company of Japan issued separate recalls to fix faulty brakes and seat belts on about 3,500 of their jointly built Mercury Villager and Nissan Quest mini-vans. GRUMMAN CORP., Bethpage, L.I., has been awarded a $7.9 million contract that could be worth $220 million from the Army to make intercom systems for combat vehicles. UNISYS CORP., Blue Bell, Pa., and California Republic Bank, Bakersfield, Calif., announced an agreement for a 10-year information systems outsourcing contract valued at $56 million.

title: Pique and Prejudice in South Africa
description: No sooner had South Africa's two most formidable leaders agreed to resume talks on a new democratic constitution than their jealous rival for the world's attention threw a tantrum. Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, leader of seven million Zulus, stamped his feet and vowed not to take part in talks, elections or an interim government unless he gets more respect. His performance is not only pathetic, it is dangerous; the peril of inciting an ethnic bloodbath is every bit as palpable as Chief Buthelezi's wounded vanity.

title: Aharon Appelfeld, Writer of Contradictions
description: Aharon Appelfeld is a Jew and an author. That is certainly not a unique or even uncommon combination, but with this writer it raises more questions than it answers.

title: Dr. W. Henry Sebrell, 91, Expert On Nutrition and Use of Vitamins
description: W. Henry Sebrell Jr., a pioneer in vitamin research and an international authority on nutrition, died yesterday at his home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 91 years old.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats; Gore Says Bush's Efforts to Befriend Iraqi Leader Led to Gulf War
description: Attacking President Bush's conduct of foreign policy, Senator Al Gore asserted today that the Administration's efforts to befriend Saddam Hussein in the years before he invaded Kuwait led directly to an unnecessary war.

title: Personal Health
description: THE symptoms can run the gamut from headaches and chest pains to memory loss and extreme apathy. The diagnoses can range from heart disease to Alzheimer's. But the real cause is often depression, a disorder of epidemic proportions that is typically unrecognized, misdiagnosed or improperly treated.

title: Robert Fairburn, 81; Headed Expansion Of Match Company
description: Robert G. Fairburn, the retired head of the Diamond Match Company who led the expansion of the leading producer of matches into other industries, died on Saturday at the Community Hospital in Monterey, Calif. He was 81 years old and lived in Carmel, Calif.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Camacho Charged With Driving Counts
description: HECTOR (MACHO) CAMACHO was pulled over by a police officer in Lake Placid, Fla., on Sept. 21 and charged with failure to stay within one lane of traffic on a rural highway and driving with a suspended license, according to the police. Camacho, 30 years old, was also issued citations for possessing two driver's licenses and giving false information to obtain a driver's license.

title: InstaCool Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said it has written-off $ 316,000 of tooling and inventory as part of its downsizing.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about President Bush's veto of legislation to restrict American trade with China omitted a word in some copies, thus misstating the prospects of a Congressional vote to override. Senate Republicans predicted that the veto would in fact be sustained.

title: College Plan Leads to Criminal Inquiry
description: An effort to reach out to nontraditional students in this tiny community of Hasidic Jews has created multimillion-dollar troubles for Rockland Community College and led to a criminal investigation into possible fraud, theft and conspiracy.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Watch; Ducking Them, Perot Points to Issues
description: It somehow seemed fitting 10 days ago when Ross Perot, the ultimate media candidate, said that he might re-enter the Presidential race simply to buy television time to talk about the issues.

title: Safeway Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 5
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $ 27.8 million from early retirement of debt.c-After an extraordinary loss of $ 12.7 million from early retirement of debt in the quarter and 9 months, and included a one-time, after-tax gain of $ 16.9 million related to the gain on a common stock offering by an unconsolidated affiliate, in the both periods.

title: CANCELED ARMY CONTRACT BLAMED FOR LAYOFFS
description: Textron Lycoming Turbine Engine will lay off 200 workers by the end of October and as many as 1,200 more during the next year if business does not improve dramatically. The military contractor employs 3,300 people at its headquarters in Stratford, Conn., where most of the cuts will be made, and 400 in Greer, S.C.

title: Inquiry Into Investment In Olympia's Buildings
description: The Toronto Stock Exchange has begun an investigation of whether a big Canadian real estate holding company failed to disclose properly an investment in some Olympia & York properties in Manhattan. The investment, made three years ago, has only now come to light.

title: Hospital Executives' Pay Rose Sharply in Decade
description: The rise in compensation for executives at nonprofit hospitals in the 1980's was one of the fastest-growing components of the overall rise in medical costs, with the earnings of a few executives at the most prestigious institutions approaching or exceeding $1 million.

title: 9 Men Posing as Police Are Indicted in 3 Murders
description: Equipped with badges and plastic handcuffs, a gang of kidnappers posing as police officers staged the arrests of five New York City drug traffickers over an 18-month period and held them for hundreds of thousands of dollars in ransom, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Broadcasters, to Satisfy Law, Define Cartoons as Education
description: It might seem like an ordinary television cartoon, but the Saturday morning adventures of Bucky O'Hare, a rabbit in space who fights alien toads with guns and lasers, is in fact "educational and informational."

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Porsche Cuts 1,000 Jobs as Demand Slows
description: One week after unceremoniously dumping its chairman, Porsche A.G. unexpectedly announced today that it was eliminating 1,000 jobs and restructuring all areas of the company. The German sports car maker said the weak global economy made the moves unavoidable.

title: Leading Indicators Drop 0.2%
description: The Government's chief index for predicting the economy slipped two-tenths of 1 percent in August, suggesting to analysts that the current torpor will extend at least into early 1993.

title: Bridge
description: The last deal of a match is a particularly dangerous one, and players make errors of judgment more often than they would earlier in the proceedings. This is partly a matter of fatigue but partly the result of a feeling that it is almost over and one's teammates are waiting eagerly to compare scores.

title: Cow's Milk And Children: A New No-No?
description: THE Physicians Committee on Responsible Medicine, whose interests include both preventive medicine and alternatives to animal research, has declared war on that great American icon milk. "Parents," the committee said in a statement released in Boston yesterday, "should be alerted to the potential risks to their children from cow's-milk products." It added, "Milk should not be required or recommended in Government guidelines."

title: Mozambique Peace Pact Signing Called Off
description: Only two days before the planned signing of a treaty to end 16 years of war in Mozambique and bring food to millions of starving people, Italian mediators called off the event today, saying the rebel leader had refused to attend.

title: Cricket's a Major Sport In Metropolitan Area
description: To the Editor:

title: Transat A.T. Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: The Pop Life
description: A Life in Rock

title: Review/Television; Case Closed A Little Too Neatly
description: Back for a third season, its formula more finely tuned than ever, NBC's "Law and Order" gets involved in an incendiary case tonight and then, quite uncharacteristically, does a cop-out.

title: Senate Approves a Tax Bill Offering Benefits for Many
description: Six months after the Los Angeles riots unleashed a Congressional drive on urban aid, the Senate today finally approved a broad package to give tax incentives to businesses investing in impoverished city neighborhoods -- along with a medley of tax benefits for every other economic group.

title: Vogue Names New Editor
description: Laurie Jones, the managing editor of New York magazine for 16 years, has been named managing editor of Vogue.

title: 'It Doesn't Take a Hero': It's Not the Last Word, but It's Firsthand and Fast
description: Ulysses S. Grant's "Personal Memoirs" were written 20 years after the Civil War. Dwight D. Eisenhower's "Crusade in Europe" was published four years after D-day marked the beginning of the end of World War II. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf's autobiography, "It Doesn't Take a Hero," now appears a few moments (well, about a year and a half) after the cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war, which still has loose ends, including the same dictatorial leadership in Iraq. Considering the haste of General Schwarzkopf's book (written with the acknowledged help of Peter Petre of Fortune magazine), it's a remarkably smooth job, with excellent battlefield maps.

title: Barnes & Noble Drops Offer
description: Barnes & Noble Inc. announced yesterday that it had canceled its proposed plans to sell to the public 6.8 million common shares for $102 million. Instead, the publishing company said it would sell $100 million of new equity to its principal shareholders and a private investor group.

title: Consumers' Use of Shopping Coupons Is Up
description: The weak economy is creating a nation of coupon clippers.

title: Questions on Race
description: Without making a ruling or filing a lawsuit, the Department of Education has managed not only to change the way the law school at the University of California at Berkeley admits minority students, but also to cast a pall of uncertainty over all college admissions policies that have to do with race.

title: 3 NEWARK OFFICERS ACCUSED OF AMBUSH IN CAR-THEFT CASE
description: A grand jury accused three Newark police officers today of taking the law into their own hands four months ago by ambushing a teen-age car-theft suspect and trying to cover up their actions after one of them fired a shot from an illegal handgun that critically wounded the youth.

title: Quiet on the Set: Costs Mire New York in a Film Slump
description: Chris Rosen has a steadily growing circle of friends in Los Angeles, a city that holds little appeal for him -- or them. But that's where a number of New York film technicians are migrating as a two-year slump in the movie business drags on.

title: Assumptions of Bias Insult New Collegians
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Another Burns is making plans for a birthday. GEORGE BURNS'S 100th falls on Jan. 20, 1996, and the comedian said from Los Angeles yesterday: "I'm booked to play the Palladium in London when I'm 100, and I hope the Palladium is still there. I know I will be."

title: Part-Time Superstar Welcomed By Lakers
description: In what is literally an off-the-wall development, the Los Angeles Lakers are unretiring Magic Johnson's number, the "32" jersey that hangs from a Forum wall.

title: Helene Curtis Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NASA PICKS HUGHES AIRCRAFT FOR SATELLITE DATA BASE
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company has been selected by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to build a computer data base containing all information known to scientists about the earth. Hughes beat out the TRW Corporation to win the 10-year contract in which it will build a data and information system for the Earth Orbiting System. The program, which will collect environmental data from satellites, is expected to cost NASA about $3 billion, according to a General Accounting Office report.

title: Niagara Crash Of 2 Copters Kills 4 People
description: As hundreds of stunned tourists looked on, two sightseeing helicopters collided over Niagara Falls this afternoon, causing one to plummet into a wooded hillside, where it crashed, killing all four people on board.

title: Books of The Times; It's Not the Last Word, but It's Firsthand and Fast
description: It Doesn't Take a Hero By Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, written with Peter Petre. Illustrated. 530 pages. Linda Grey/Bantam Books. $25.

title: Yields on Deposits at Banks Have Another Down Week
description: Yields of bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit trended down in the week ended today, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a Florida-based interest rate publication.

title: Czechs More Eager Than Slovaks to Separate; Unjust to Meciar
description: To the Editor:

title: Sears Is Unlikely To Switch Agencies
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company's proposed restructuring is unlikely to affect its longstanding agency relationships, company executives said. Sears spent almost $1.2 billion on advertising last year, according to Advertising Age, making it the nation's fourth-largest advertiser.

title: Small Garage Gives Big, Ritzy Indy-Type Racers a Run for the Money
description: Along Route 611 in this town a few miles north of Philadelphia is the Ritz Garage, an antique-car showroom. A few yards behind it is another garage, one that by Indy-car standards is decidedly less ritzy.

title: Theater in Review
description: The American Living Room Reupholstered Ohio Theater 66 Wooster Street SoHo Through Oct. 11 Two one-act plays. Curators, Tim Maner and Kristin Marting; lighting, Cindy Breakfield; production manager, Rachelle Anthes. Presented by Tiny Mythic Theater Company, Mr. Maner and Ms. Marting, artistic directors; Michael Hurst, managing director. SOAP OPERA, by Ralph Pape; directed by Elizabeth Franzen; stage managed by Tina Trimble. WITH: Julienne Greer, Shannon Malone and Gerard J. Schneider. DIALOGUE WITH A PROSTITUTE, written and directed by Howard Ross Patlis; based on Dacia Maraini's "Dialogue Between a Prostitute and One of Her Clients"; translated by Gillian Hanna; stage managed by Tina Magnuson; assistant stage manager, Susan Nanes. WITH: Susan Huffaker, Anthony Marshall and Howard Ross Patlis.

title: The Freedom to Worship, the Freedom to Park; With a Nod Toward Mecca, Weary Car Owners Give Thanks for a Parking Reprieve
description: New York is a city that never stops asking for more, and its residents clearly know whom to ask.

title: U.S. Paging Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an after-tax non-recurring, non-cash gain of $ 2,065,000, or 77 cents a share, from a litigation settlement.c-Net lossThe shares outstanding reflected the impact of the issuance, since the June 3 intitial public offering, of 1 million shares for the 1992 year-end and fourth quarter.It also reflected the conversion of the preferred stock and the about 1-for-2.2 reverse stock split completed prior to the completion of the initial public offering.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Saberhagen Proves He Is Ready to Deal
description: Bret Saberhagen will not finish the season on the disabled list. It is an achievement of modest satisfaction for the right-hander and the Mets. The question now is whether it is an accomplishment substantial enough to get the principals to the bargaining table during the off-season.

title: For Sears' Stores, Do-or-Die Time
description: While the decision of Sears, Roebuck to detach its financial services businesses is what shareholders, analysts and consultants have demanded with increasing insistence for years, it will leave the battered retail business to sink or swim.

title: Driver Hit by Chunk Of Concrete Is Killed
description: A Reading, Pa., man was killed last Saturday night when someone dropped a 40-pound chunk of concrete through the windshield of his van as he drove under an overpass on Route 78 in Somerset County, N.J., the New Jersey State Police said yesterday.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo; Those Chicken Georges And What They Mean
description: In examining the Clinton campaign's developing strategy for unnerving, unsettling and eventually unhorsing George Bush, it is illuminating to consider the matter of the President and Chicken George.

title: Amex Planning to Enter Nontrading Businesses
description: After years of building up the businesses of trading in stocks and options, the American Stock Exchange is examining ways to branch into new lines like pensions and insurance.

title: Brazil's House Impeaches Collor; Suspended, He Faces Senate Trial
description: President Fernando Collor de Mello was impeached today by the lower house of the Brazilian Congress, clearing the way for a trial on charges that his family and friends had accepted huge bribes on his behalf in return for Government favors.

title: A Museum Devoted to the Culinary Arts
description: THE sign at the entrance to the building reads "Johnson & Wales, Culinary Archives and Museum," but the atmosphere is more reminiscent of a colorful flea market, where shelves and tables are overflowing with a hodgepodge of cooking equipment, prints and assorted culinary memorabilia.

title: Grilled Chicken Meets Some Fancy Greens
description: MOST recipes that call for grilling can be made indoors on a stove-top grill. Broiling, when used as an alternative, does not produce the desirable flavor that comes from cooking over an open flame.

title: For the Creative or Obsessive, 100,000 Ways to Make a Mark
description: SOME people fantasize about climbing Mount Everest or winning the lottery. "I dreamed of building a showplace for rubber stamps," said Gary Dorothy, whose store here, Stampa Barbara, is acknowledged by stampophiles to be the first and largest of its kind in the world. Mr. Dorothy's all-rubber-stamp emporium celebrated its seventh birthday this year.

title: ROME BANK LINKED TO ATLANTA LOANS
description: A Federal judge said today that raw, classified Central Intelligence Agency documents revealed that billions of dollars in illegal loans to Iraq made by the Atlanta branch of an Italian bank were known to the bank's top officials in Rome.

title: To Fill Its Schools, a Rural Town Opens Its Homes
description: In the old days in the rural West, students who lived on distant ranches sometimes boarded with a family in town during the school year, rather than ride 40 miles of dirt back roads to class.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Which segues nicely to the involvement of KEN BURNS. Mr. Burns, the producer and director of the documentary series "The Civil War," will be at the party to announce that he will make a film on Jefferson in conjunction with the celebration But the film will take several years to complete.

title: Maytag's Accounts To Leo Burnett
description: The Maytag Corporation said yesterday that it will move advertising and public relations for its Magic Chef brand, effective Jan. 1, to Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago from the Keller Crescent Company in Evansville, Ind. Keller Crescent will continue to handle some special projects for the premium-priced line of kitchen appliances. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Making Coal More Useful By Cooking Out the Water
description: The Powder River Basin in Wyoming has huge amounts of very clean coal, but nature does not organize itself for mankind's benefit: the deposit is a long way from market and shipping costs are bloated because the coal has a low energy content per pound.

title: Arthur Mosher, 82, International Expert On Agricultural Aid
description: Arthur T. Mosher, a former president of the Agricultural Development Council, an international agricultural development organization, died Sunday at his home in Black Mountain, N.C. He was 82 years old.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Iraq Says It Will Not Assist U.N.'s Efforts to Help Kurds
description: A senior Iraqi official told the Secretary General today that Baghdad will not cooperate with his plans to launch a new relief operation to help the Kurds this winter if the Security Council seizes frozen Iraqi assets.

title: Farm Prices Unchanged
description: Prices received by American farmers were unchanged in September and 5.4 percent below levels a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: My Story: The Holes
description: My story of the draft, recounted in unvarying language for more than 20 years, was initially conceived for two purposes -- first, to fulfill the autobiographical requirements of the examined life, and, secondly, to grant myself permission to move on, secure in my assessment that I had acted honorably and lawfully.

title: First Team Sports reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Hadron Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Critic's Notebook; Taking the Spanish Out of Spanish Dance At the Lyons Biennial
description: "Spanish dance has been a purely Parisian phenomenon," the French Romantic poet Theophile Gautier once noted wickedly. Gautier (who was also the originator and librettist of "Giselle") was writing during a 19th-century invasion of Paris by hugely popular Spanish dancers, and if his remark was ironic, the myth if not the reality of Spain is still highly attractive to foreigners.

title: Trading a Can of Film For a Dream Come True At Independent Market
description: With only a half-hour to go before the screening of her film at the Independent Feature Film Market, A. G. Melkom was rapidly approaching the end of her tether. Loaded down with fliers for the film, "Splinters," a black comedy that turns on what she calls "splintered personalities," she rode up the escalator at the Angelika Film Center in Greenwich Village for a final assault on the milling throng of buyers, agents, producers and film-festival officials.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Wichita, Kan., is offering $50 million of tax-exempt general obligation sales-tax bonds through the First Boston Corporation, with yields ranging from 2.9 percent in 1993 to 5.4 percent in 2002. The issue is rated double-A by both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Bailout Near For Insurer
description: New Jersey regulators said today that they expected to get the insurance industry's backing for the $800 million bailout of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company by the end of the week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Rutgers

title: Acier Leroux Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.The company said that the 1992 results do not include the sales of Multifer Inc., acquired on July 6.

title: Moscow Fears for Troops in Tajikistan
description: A civil war is intensifying in Tajikistan, causing increased alarm in Moscow over some 10,000 Russian troops who are caught in the middle.

title: I.B.M. Says Buyouts Will Trim 40,000 Jobs
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that twice as many employees as originally anticipated had taken incentives to retire early or resign, which will mean the elimination of 40,000 jobs this year. It also said it was planning to cut back its manufacturing in response to "rapid changes in technology, shifting marketplace demand and prolonged worldwide economic weakness."

title: Dinkins's Drug Chief Quits Over Tight Budget
description: Frustrated by what he described as a lack of Federal and state financing for the treatment and prevention of addiction, David C. Condliffe, who has served for two years as director of New York City's drug policy office, said yesterday that he had resigned.

title: SLIDE IN SHARES OF MEDICAL CARE AMERICA ENDS
description: Shares of Medical Care America Inc. rebounded slightly on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday after plunging a total of nearly $35 a share on Friday and Monday. The stock of the Dallas company began to plummet last week after it said third-quarter earnings would be below estimates.

title: Under the Sign of a Topless Car Wash, Frustration
description: The residents were not pleased by the distinction. They were particularly offended by a sign painted on the building at 1690 Richmond Terrace to advertise the car wash. The major elements of the fresco are two women with exaggerated lips, breasts and buttocks. One is shown dressed only in high-heeled shoes and a G-string just large enough to show off a stars-and-stripes motif.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: CALF'S liver has long been a delicacy in France, where the methods of preparation are endless. In this country it has gained in popularity over the last 20 years or so, but it is still far from a staple on restaurant menus.

title: American Nursery Products reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a $ 5.2 million restructuring charge related to the disposal of certain assets for the quarter and year.c-Included a $ 9.5 million restructuring charge related to the disposal of assets for the quarter and year.

title: FUEL SPILL CITED IN A NAVY CRASH
description: The Navy said today that a prototype of its V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft that crashed in the Potomac River in July had suffered an engine failure and fire when lubricating oil and transmission fluid inexplicably spilled into the engine during flight.

title: France Moves to Take Bigger Part in Defining New Role for NATO
description: France, which has long promoted the idea of a separate European military force, suggested today that it was ready to take part more actively in NATO's efforts to find a new role for the Atlantic alliance in a post-cold-war world.

title: Mr. Perot: Where's the Cattle?
description: There was never a question about Ross Perot's appeal to millions of disenchanted Americans, or about his ability to articulate widespread frustration with economic decline and political stalemate. The big question about him was always this: Is he fit to lead? With Mr. Perot flirting shamelessly with a late re-entry into the Presidential race, that question burns more brightly than ever.

title:
Campus Journal;
Businesses That Rallied For a College Now Use It
description: When the College of Engineering and Mathematics at the University of Vermont faced extinction at the hands of budget-cutters last fall, the outpouring of support from the local business community was crucial in saving it.

title: O'Brien Environmental Energy Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: G.E.-Silicon Graphics Deal
description: GE Capital Computer Leasing and Silicon Graphics Inc. said today that they would jointly provide a computer-leasing program for companies.

title: Medicis Pharmaceutical reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $ 1.4 million non-recurring, non-cash charge for expenses, and after an extraordinary loss of $ 3,824,043 from early extinguishment of debt.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Editors' Note
description: A picture on Sept. 22 with an article about the influence of women in the Peruvian guerrilla group Shining Path, showed two women and a man in captivity with the group's leader, Abimael Guzman Reynoso. The Peruvian Government, which released the videotape from which the photo was taken, said the three were detained in the Sept. 12 raid in which Mr. Guzman was arrested.

title: Early Onset Found For Panic Attacks
description: THOUGH usually not diagnosed until people are in their 20's, panic attacks frequently occur first in sixth- and seventh-grade children, a new study has found.

title: Blueprint for a Wider War
description: Everything in the Yugoslav conflict follows from Serbia's fundamental goal of creating a larger, ethnicallly pure state. Only counterbalancing force -- Western air power, arms and training for the Bosnians -- can halt Serbian aggression. Only a military standoff will lead to a lasting peace, by reversing Serbian expansion.

title: Henry Jaffe Is Dead; TV Producer Was 85
description: Henry Jaffe, a former show-business lawyer who became an award-winning television producer, died on Sept. 11 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 85 years old.

title: Executive Changes
description: RALSTON PURINA CO., St. Louis, named W. Patrick McGinnis chief executive of its grocery products group. CROWELL & MORING, Washington, appointed Robert Pettit partner of the law firm, where he will practice communications law. He was previously general counsel for the Federal Communications Commission, Washington.

title: There's Little Delay In Free-Agent Game
description: With three of the four celebrated National Football League free agents now signed, sealed and delivered to new teams, was there any question that clubs would be quick to seek their services?

title: Microwave Filter Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Snails and Pastries From an Ambassador of Cretan Cuisine
description: IT was definitely an odd menu. After nibbling sticks of firm, salty sheep's-milk cheese dipped in honey, the guests dined on barley rusks topped with tomato, two dishes made with snails, a frittata of pork and greens, and rabbit stewed in red wine with onions. They ate the dessert, fried pastries filled with fresh sheep's-milk cheese seasoned with mint and drizzled with honey, with their fingers.

title: Review/Film Festival; Independence in Africa and Death in High Places
description: There are some remarkable similarities between "Lumumba: Death of a Prophet" and "Allah Tantou," two documentaries, each relating to the African independence movement, that the New York Film Festival is presenting today at 6:15 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall.

title: MARION MERRELL SAYS PATCH SUPPLY NOW MEETS DEMAND
description: Marion Merrell Dow Inc. said yesterday that United States pharmacies were fully stocked with its Nicoderm smoking cessation patch and that it was discontinuing an allocation system for the product. A shortage of Nicoderm developed in late February, soon after its United States introduction. Production of the patch was increased to meet "forseeable" demand in the United States and Canada, where Nicoderm was introduced this summer, a company spokesman said.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY DRUG DEALERS KIDNAPPED AND KILLED

title: Physicians Support Johnson's Comeback
description: Medical experts yesterday applauded Magic Johnson's decision to return to professional sports. They said that he should be able to return to the court without limitations and that the physical stresses of playing basketball should not hasten the progression of his disease.

title: Deutsche Bank Names U.S. Chief
description: Deutsche Bank, pushing to take advantage of its financial strength and expand its American business when some other banks are licking their wounds, said yesterday that it had hired John A. Rolls to be chief executive officer of its business in North America, effective Nov. 1.

title: The Draft: My Story
description: In 1966, the Selective Service granted me a 2-S student deferment, which remained in effect until I graduated from college in 1970. One night in December 1969, I learned from the radio that I had received the number 27 in the draft lottery. I returned to my dorm room where for the next two hours I received a series of highly emotional phone calls from concerned family members and friends.

title: How New York Lags in Treating Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Clumsy? Sue New York City.
description: Today, despite all its problems and expenses, New York City is subject to trial by jury virtually every time someone trips on a crack in the sidewalk, slips on ice or drives into a pothole. For four months this year, the law firm I work for donated my services to the city. My job was to defend it in the rash of cases that are filed daily for injuries caused by these urban defects.
